    "pages": }\n'''Karyn Ellen Polito''' (born November 11, 1966) is an American attorney, businesswoman, and politician who served as the 72nd  from 2015 to 2023. Polito was a Republican member of the  for the 11th  district from 2001 to 2011. Polito was first elected lieutenant governor in 2014 with her running mate, . They were both re-elected in , and declined to seek reelection in .\n\n\nPolito is a lifelong resident of . She graduated from . Shortly after graduating from  with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1988, she received her Juris Doctor from  in 1991.\n\n\nAn attorney, Polito co-owns and operates a commercial real estate development firm.\n\nPolito is a member of the . Her experience in politics and government includes stints as a Shrewsbury  member (1993-2000), a member of the Shrewsbury Zoning Board of Appeals (1994-1995), and a Shrewsbury  (1995-1998). Polito was the commissioner of the  from 1999 to 2000. In 1998, Polito ran for the  in the  district. However, she lost the general election to .\n\n\nIn 2000, Polito was elected State Representative for the , which covers the town of Shrewsbury and precincts 1 and 4 of the adjacent town of  in . She served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives from 2001 to 2011, winning every election without any opposition.\n\n\nOn March 1, 2010, Polito announced she would run for the office of . She was unopposed in the Republican primary. Polito lost in the general election to Democratic candidate , but won 45% of the vote, receiving the most votes of any Republican running for office in Massachusetts in .\n\n\n\n\n\nOn December 3, 2013, Polito announced her candidacy for Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts. The leading GOP candidate for Governor, , endorsed her candidacy. She was not opposed in the September 2014 primary. Baker and Polito won the , defeating Democratic candidates  and , respectively, 48.40% to 46.54%.\n\n\n\nIn August 2018, Baker and Polito formally launched their re-election campaign. Both were successful in the Republican primary election held on September 4, 2018, with Polito running unopposed. Baker and Polito faced challengers  and  of the  in the general election. The Baker/Polito ticket defeated the Gonzales/Palfrey ticket by a margin of 1,781,341 votes to 885,770.\n\n\nKaryn Polito has been described as a socially moderate Republican who is generally conservative on most other issues. , a non-partisan organization that records a politician's position on issues, considers her to be a \"Moderate Conservative.\" Polito did not vote for President  in 2016 and announced that she did not support Trump's re-election.\n\n*Polito has supported  and eliminating  for elected officials.\n*She has been supportive of state tax cuts.\n*She said she is proud of her pro-choice record, noting high ratings from  and .\n* Polito had an A+ rating from Gun Owners' Action League (GOAL), and an A− rating from the .\n* As State Representative in 2007, Polito voted yes on a constitutional amendment defining marriage as between one man and one woman. She did support same-sex civil unions. In 2013, however, Polito reversed her position and expressed public support for same-sex marriage. \n*Polito opposed Donald Trump's executive order to  on the southern border of the United States.\n\n\nPolito resides in  with her husband, Stephan M. Rodolakis, and their two children. Rodolakis is an attorney specializing in bankruptcy proceedings.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official government website\n*  official campaign website\n*  (archived)\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert K. Coughlin''' is an , , and real estate executive from . A , he served in the  from 2003 to 2007 from the Eleventh Norfolk District, encompassing his hometown of , , and the Eighth Precinct of . He later served as Undersecretary of Housing and Economic Development and then President of the . He is currently a member of the life sciences team at JLL.\n\n\nFrom age five, Coughlin yearned to follow in the footsteps of his father, Dedham Selectman Paul P. Coughlin. After graduating from , the younger Coughlin earned a degree in  from the  in 1991. There, he served in the  and was a member of the rugby club.\n\n\nCoughlin's career started at age 20, when he became the youngest member of Dedham's School Committee. In 1995, he became the youngest member of Dedham's Board of Selectmen. He served as both vice chair and chair of the board.\n\nIn 2002, Coughlin ran for state representative from the 11th Norfolk district, defeating incumbent  in the Democratic primary and Joseph A. Pascarella in the general election.\n\nAs state representative, Coughlin started by sitting on the Joint Committee on Health Care, the House Long-Term Debt and Capital Expenditures Committee, and the House Homeland Security and Federal Affairs Committee. During the 184th General Court, Coughlin became Vice Chair of the Joint Committee on Revenue, and he sat as a member on the Joint Committee on Financial Services and the Joint Committee on Health Care Financing.\n\nCoughlin left the General Court to serve as the Undersecretary for Business Development in the Executive Office of Housing and Economic Development for Governor . While in this position,  reported that Coughlin waited six weeks to tell his bosses he was talking to recruiters about a biotech council job, even though he was working on state biotech initiatives. Coughlin denied the allegations.\n\n\nCoughlin served as president and CEO of the Massachusetts Biotechnology Council from 2008 to 2021. MassBio's mission is to advance Massachusetts' leadership in the life sciences, to grow the industry, to add value to the healthcare, and to improve patient lives. In his last year there, he was paid $1.2 million.\n\nAs of early 2021, Coughlin is an executive with JLL. Coughlin's son struggle has . Coughlin also manages a group called Bobby's Brigade, an organization in partnership with the  to raise funds to help find a cure for CF.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n -->\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David Paul Linsky''' (born October 16, 1957) is an American lawyer and politician who currently represents the 5th Middlesex District in the .\n\n\n\nA lifelong resident of , Linsky graduated from  and went on to earn his B.A. from  and his J.D. from .\n\n\nHe is a graduate of the Career Prosecutor School in . He served on the Natick Democratic Town Committee. From 1980 to 1999, Linsky was a Natick Town Meeting Member. From 1984 to 1988 he served on the Natick Conservation Commission.\n\n\nFrom 1983 to 1988 and again from 1991 to 1999, Linsky was an Assistant District Attorney in . As an ADA he prosecuted hundreds of cases including sexual assault, murder, and white collar crime.\n\n\nLinsky was first elected to the House in 1999 in the special election to succeed , who resigned after he was appointed as a judge in Middlesex District Court. Linsky defeated former Natick Selectman John F. Moran in the Democratic primary 3,181 votes to 2,105. In the general election he defeated Republican Kenneth B. Hoyt and Independent Jerry L. Pierce 3,846 votes to Hoyt's 1,837 and Pierce's 47.\n\nLinsky served as Chair of the House Committee on Post Audit and Oversight for twelve years, and formerly served as the House Chair of the Joint Committee on Federal Stimulus Oversight.\n\nLinsky is considered a national leader in state legislation in the area of gun violence prevention, was an original supporter of Massachusetts' first in the nation Universal Health Insurance Law, the forerunner to the Affordable Care Act, and was an early leader in Massachusetts Equal Marriage movement.\n\nHe also was instrumental in securing funding for several new public schools in his District, including Natick High School and the Kennedy and Wilson Middle Schools.\n\n\nHe and his former wife Lois have three children.\n\nOn July 1, 2021, the Internal Revenue Service filed a lien against Linsky for $154,067 in unpaid income taxes related to his law office income. Linsky stated that the debt was due to \"a number of family issues and business issues, unrelated to [his] work as a state representative\". He also stated that he was on a payment plan to repay the taxes, had already paid back some of the money, was current in his payments, and was appealing the lien.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

A member of the , he previously represented the  in the  from 1989 to 1993.\n\n\nPacheco was born on October 29, 1952 in Taunton, Massachusetts to Emily L. Pacheco (née Henriques) and Richard Pacheco.\n\nA graduate of  , Pacheco received an associate degree from the  at the , a bachelor's degree from New Hampshire College (now ), and a master's degree from .\n\n\nPacheco entered politics in 1980 when he was elected to the Taunton School Committee. He served until 1989, including two years as chair from 1987 to 1988. From 1982 to 1988, he also served as chief assistant to Mayor .\n\nIn 1988, with incumbent  running for Senate, Pacheco was elected to the 3rd Bristol district of the Massachusetts House of Representatives. He defeated fellow Taunton residents Carol Doherty and Gail Tardo in the Democratic primary and faced no opposition in the general election. Doherty would later be elected to the seat in a special election in 2020.\n\nIn 1992, Pacheco ran for Senate and defeated incumbent  Erving H. Wall Jr.\n\nIn 2001, Pacheco ran in the  caused by the death of Congressman . He finished fourth in the Democratic primary with 13% of the vote, placing behind colleagues , , and the eventual winner .\n\nIn 2016, Pacheco served as a , casting his vote for .\n\nOn February 13, 2024, Pacheco announced he would not seek another term.\n\n\n\n\n* Chairperson, Senate Committee on Post Audit and Oversight\n* Chairperson, Joint Committee on Emergency Preparedness and Management\n* Vice Chair, Joint Committee on Telecommunications, Utilities and Energy\n* Senate Committee on Global Warming and Climate Change\n* Joint Committee on State Administration and Regulatory Oversight\n\n\nPacheco lives in Taunton with his wife Barbara, a few blocks from where he grew up.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Leonard \"Lenny\" Mirra''' is a former American  who served in the . He is a  resident and a member of the .\n\nMirra represented the Second Essex District in the Massachusetts House of Representatives. For the majority of Mirra’s tenure, the Second Essex included the towns of , , , , , precinct 2 and 3 of , 's ward 4 precinct 3, and Haverhill's ward 7 precinct 3.\n\nFollowing redistricting efforts in 2021, the Second Essex district now includes Georgetown, Newbury, Rowley, Ipswich, Hamilton, and Topsfield’s first precinct.\n\nMirra worked in the construction industry for 30 years. He spends his free time fishing and gardening.\n\n\nIn the 2022 midterm elections, Mirra initially won his election by 10 votes. After a recount it was concluded that he lost to challenger Kristen Kassner by 1 vote. After the loss, Mirra took legal action, but the Essex County Superior Court of Massachusetts dismissed the suit claiming that the court lacked jurisdiction on the matter. Mirra's suit was also dismissed on appeal.\n\nOn January 4, 2023 the Massachusetts House of Representatives formed a special committee to review the results of the 2022 Second Essex District’s Election. As a result, Mirra served as a \"hold-over\" Representative. On January 31, 2023, the special committee voted 2-1, recommending to the full House of Representatives that Kristin Kassner be sworn in as the winner of the election. Mirra left office on February 3, 2023, following the swearing-in of Kristin Kassner.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He was first elected to the DA's office in 2010 and is currently serving his fourth term as the lead  in . \n\nHe previously served as a  for the  district (1992–2010) in the  and a  for the  and  districts (1977–1993) in the . Morrissey.\" ''''. p. 64. .\n\n\n\n\nMorrissey is a native and lifelong resident of . After graduating from  in 1972, he earned his  in history from the  and a  from . Morrissey earned a  from  in 1985 and was admitted to the  on December 17, 1985. \n\nHe began his thirty-plus year career as a  upon election to the , representing the  from 1976 to 1979 and the  from 1979 to 1993. He was then elected to the , where he served as state senator for the , representing the  and towns of , , , , and  from 1993 to 2010. \n\nMorrissey's first term as Norfolk District Attorney began after winning the 2010 District Attorney General Election. He was sworn in early, on January 2, 2011, to succeed , who had resigned from his position as Norfolk DA to serve in the .State House News Service , ''Wicked Local Burlington'', January 1, 2011.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNorfolk District Attorney Morrissey's office announced the arrest of  on February 2, 2022, in connection with the  of off-duty  Officer  in . Read, who was O’Keefe's girlfriend, was initially charged with , to which she pleaded not guilty in  District Court. \n\nOn June 9, 2022, the Norfolk District Attorney's office issued a press release stating that Karen Read had again been taken into custody by the  pursuant to new developments in the investigation of . A new  was issued following a decision by a   to  Read for   including , motor vehicle  while operating , and  of a  causing personal injury and death.. (2022, June 9).The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Norfolk District Attorney's Office, ''nfkda.com''. Retrieved October 4, 2014, from https://archive.today/20241005002911/https://www.nfkda.com/Press_Releases/06-09-22%20Murder%20Indictment%20and%20Arrest%20in%20January%20Death.pdf Read was arraigned on June 10th at  in . He strongly condemned  propagating “false narratives and accusations” related to the case circulating online. Morrissey attributed ongoing incidences of  and  and their families to the spread of  through . He cautioned citizens that online  should never be “used as a pre-text to attack and harass others,” stating, “what is happening to the witnesses – some with no actual involvement in the case  is wrong...it needs to stop now.” In the video, Morrissey refers to his message as \"''the first statement of its kind\"'' in his twelve years as Norfolk District Attorney.\n\nThe first jury  began at  in April 2024. Some testimony from law enforcement officers assigned to the investigation raised public suspicions of alleged  and general incompetence, which prompted some questioning of the integrity of cases investigated and prosecuted by the Norfolk District Attorney's Office under Morrissey. A mistrial was declared and the case is currently scheduled for re-trial in January 2025, pending appeal.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Althea Garrison''' (born October 7, 1940) is an American politician from ,  who previously served a single term in the  (1993–1995) and a partial term as an  councilor on the  (2019–2020). She is considered the earliest  person known to have been elected to a state legislature in the United States. She was  against her will by the '''' after her 1992 election. She is a , having been an unsuccessful candidate for political office more than forty times.\n\nIn her only successful campaign, Garrison won election as a  to the Massachusetts House of Representatives in 1992. She served one term from 1993 to 1995, losing her bid for reelection in 1994. Both before and after this, she has run for office many other times. Her campaigns have seen her run under different party affiliations, varyingly running as Republican, a , and an . Garrison, in the 2010s, described her political ideology as \"independent \".\n\nGarrison served as an at-large member of the Boston City Council from January 2019 to January 2020 due to a vacancy left by 's election to the . Because Garrison was the next-place finisher in the ,  rules gave Garrison the right of first refusal to assume the seat vacated by Pressley. Garrison lost her bid for re-election .\n\n\nBorn in , as the youngest of seven children, Garrison attended Hahira High School there. Garrison moved to Boston to attend beauty school, but went on to enroll in  and received an associate degree there. Garrison later received a B.S. degree in administration from , an M.S. degree in management from , and a certificate in special studies in administration and management from .\n\nAccording to records in the  Probate Court, Garrison petitioned for a name change to Althea Garrison in 1976. The petition stated that the name Althea Garrison \"is consistent with petitioner's appearance and medical condition and is the name by which he  will be known in the future.\" \n\nBesides her one term in the Massachusetts House, Garrison has worked as a clerk in human resources for the Massachusetts state comptroller's office, where she used her vacation time to run for office.  She served for four years on the .\n\n\n\nIn 1982 and 1986, Garrison ran unsuccessfully for the Massachusetts House of Representatives as a Democrat. She ran unsuccessfully for Boston City Council in , , , , and . During the 1991 campaign, the '''' noted that she had run for office nine times, although Garrison herself later described the race as her 10th or 11th bid for office. In the 1991 race, Garrison finished in third place in the District 7 .\n\n\nIn 1992, Garrison ran successfully for the 5th Suffolk district in the Massachusetts House, representing the  and  areas of Boston. Garrison's 1992 election to the legislature was made possible in part by the fact that she challenged some of the signatures that the then-incumbent representative, , had submitted to qualify for the Democratic primary ballot. Her challenge was successful and meant that Garrison did not have to run against an incumbent in the general election. In the general election, Garrison defeated Democratic candidate Irene Roman, 2,451 votes to 2,014.\n\nThe fact that Garrison had been formerly known as a male was not widely publicized until shortly after she was elected to the legislature. When the ''Boston Herald'' asked whether she was a man, Garrison denied it and ended the conversation when asked about her past, including her name change.\n\nIn the Massachusetts House, Garrison consistently voted in favor of s, resulting in her being endorsed for re-election by the Massachusetts  and eight unions. On many votes, she voted with the Democrats in the legislature rather than with the Republicans. However, she opposed  and .\n\nGarrison was defeated in her 1994 bid for re-election by Democratic nominee  by a margin of 2,108 votes to 1,718.\n\n\nGarrison has run for office at least 44 times, all but once unsuccessfully.\n\n* 2001: \n* 2002: special election for the 1st Suffolk district in the  as a Republican\n* 2002: 1st Suffolk district in the Massachusetts Senate as a Republican candidate, losing in the primary 68.9% to 31.0% to Walter R. Campbell.\n* 2003: at-large seat in the \n* 2005: at-large seat in the \n* 2006: 5th Suffolk district in Massachusetts House as a Republican candidate\n* 2008: 1st Suffolk district in the Massachusetts Senate as an independent candidate, losing 79.0% to 25.0% to .\n* 2009: District 7 seat in the \n* 2010: 5th Suffolk district in the Massachusetts House, finishing third in the Democratic primary\n* 2011:  to fill a vacancy on the Boston City Council, District 7, eliminated in February preliminary election\n* 2011: District 7 seat in the \n* 2012: 5th Suffolk district in the Massachusetts House as an independent candidate, losing 77.6% to 21.7% to .\n* 2013: at-large seat in the \n* 2014: 5th Suffolk district in the Massachusetts House as a Democratic candidate, losing in the primary 65.3% to 34.3% to .\n* 2015: District 7 seat in the \n* 2016: 5th Suffolk district in the Massachusetts House as an independent candidate, losing 83.9% to 15.6% to Evandro Carvalho.\n* 2017: at-large seat in the  (fifth place, top four elected)\n* 2018: 5th Suffolk district in the Massachusetts House as an independent candidate, losing 88.7% to 11% to .\n* 2019: at-large seat in the  (seventh place, top four elected)\n* 2020: Register of Probate for  (third place)\n* 2021: at-large seat in the \n* 2022: 5th Suffolk district in the Massachusetts House as a Democratic candidate (third place)\n* 2023: District 7 seat in the \n}}\n| width = 55em\n| align = left\n| bgcolor = \n}}\n\n\n\n\n\nGarrison took the at-large seat of former councillor  on the Boston City Council, as Pressley left the City Council following her November 2018 election to Congress from . City rules require that vacancies for the at-large council seats are filled by the next-placed candidate in the previous election, which was Garrison in November 2017. Garrison was sworn in on January 9, 2019. Garrison claimed that she had, despite ideological differences, supported Pressley's campaign for the House of Representatives with the knowledge that, if Pressley were elected, Garrison would have the opportunity to be Pressley's City Council successor by virtue of her own finish in the previous city council election.\n\nGarrison differed ideologically from the rest of the city councilors.  She was noted to be the only strong  on the Boston City Council. She was noted to be a strong supporter of then-president  and an ardent backer of the . Around the time she joined the Boston City Council, Garrison described herself as an \"independent conservative\". She once explained, \"I'm basically a conservative, but I also have some liberal ideas,\" and also explained, \"I am a conservative, I am independent also,\" calling herself \"a Black conservative.\" In a separate instance, she described herself and her voter base as being \"moderate to conservative\". She described her views as more closely aligned with the Republican Party than the Democratic Party.\n\nAs a city councilor, Garrison supported reviving  in the city. In April 2019, she introduced a  petition for the city to seek state permission to reinstate rent control in the city. The petition was heavily criticized by many fellow city council members. She also voiced support for eviction control and price controls related to development. Garrison was supportive of the controversial \"Operation Clean Sweep\" effort by the police in August 2019 which saw 34 arrests in a two-day period in the so-called \"\". Garrison proposed a pro-police resolution in the aftermath of 's 2019 \"Straight Pride Parade\" and unrest that occurred related to it. Garrison opposed a proposal by Councilor  to generate revenue by imposing fees for residential parking permits. While believing that planning and development needed to be \"community based\", Garrison dismissed a proposal by Councilor Wu to abolish the current  as merely being a ploy for reelection by Wu. Dorchester Reporter |url=https://www.dotnews.com/2019/garrison-vote-just-me-not-any-others |website=www.dotnews.com |publisher=Dorchester Reporter |access-date=29 July 2023 |language=en |date=October 24, 2019}}\n\nIn late-February 2019, Garrison proposed a measure to hold a hearing on the possibility of withholding city payments to the  over the state of its service. At the time, the MBTA was proposing divisive fare increases. The measure was signed-onto by a majority of councilors. Councilor Michelle Wu had introduced a similar measure the year prior.\n\nBoston City Councilors can invite local religious leaders to deliver the City Council's convocation. In her first turn to select the convocation, Garrison invited pastor and right-wing perennial candidate Roy Owens. Owens is vocally anti-.\n\nGarrison was a candidate for re-election in the  election, but finished seventh in the general election field of eight candidates. In that election, she had urged voters to unseat the three other three sitting at-large city councilors (, , and Michelle Wu), and urged voters to \"bullet vote\" by casting a vote only for her in the at-large councilor column instead of voting for multiple (up to four) candidates.\n\nIn December 2019, the  Garrison was one of only three city councilors to vote against a home rule petition requesting that the state allow the city to impose a .\n\n\nGarrison is a . After being outed by the  in 1992, Garrison did not publicly discuss her gender identity until 2023, when she shared that she identifies as  and had begun the process of socially and medically transitioning in the 1960s. Before 2023, despite it being public knowledge that she was transgender, Garrison avoided publicly discussing the topic of her being a transgender individual, and had not publicly identified herself as being transgender; merely identifying herself as a woman, without any further elaboration.\n\nGarrison is known not to embrace the use of technology, remarking in 2018, \"I don't do computers, I don't do technology.\"\n\nGarrison is also seen as adverse to granting the news media access to herself, with Quincy Walters of  writing in a 2018 profile, \n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* , first out transgender person to be elected to state legislature (but resigned before being sworn in)\n* , first out transgender person to be elected and serve in a state legislature\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Barbara A. L'Italien''' (born January 3, 1961) is an American politician from the state of , serving from January 2015 to 2019 as the State Senator from the 2nd Essex and Middlesex District. She was previously the director of government affairs for the , . From 2003 to January 2011 she was a member of the  representing the 18th  District.\n\nIn 2017, she announced her candidacy for Congress, representing , held by , who announced August 9, 2017 that she would not be seeking another term in Congress in 2018. She lost the primary to , who then won the general election.\n\n\nL'Italien was born in , and later graduated from  in 1978. She attended  and graduated with a  degree in  in 1984.\n\nPrior to her election to the House of Representatives, L'Italien worked for Elder Services of Merrimack Valley as a case manager and with the  Greater Lawrence Psychological Center working the  hotline for intakes and referrals. She also worked with  West Suburban Elder Services with the title of Supervisor of Case Management and Elder Abuse.\n\n\n\n\nL'Italien is the first State Representative to represent the 18th Essex district, which was created by  following the . She held office from 2003 to 2011.\n\nIn the district's first campaign in 2002, L'Italien defeated  Kathleen Sachs and  Alfred DePietro, winning by less than 1,000 votes (47–41% over Sachs).  In 2004, she defended the seat against Republican Maria Marasco, winning with 58% of the vote.  In 2006 and 2008, Republican Lawrence Brennan ran against L'Italien, but she defeated him with 56% of the vote in 2006 and 55% in 2008.  In 2010 she was defeated for re-election by Andover Republican , who won with 53% of the vote.\n\nRepresentative L'Italien was the author of the landmark legislation on Autism insurance coverage, House Bill 4935 (formerly H. 3809), which requires insurance companies to provide coverage of evidence-based, medically necessary autism therapies, such as applied behavior analysis.\n\n\nAfter her House term ended in January 2011, she became director of government affairs for the newly elected ,  until 2012.\n\n\nL'Italien was elected to the  in November 2014 to succeed  in the 2nd Essex and Middlesex seat. She defeated Andover Republican Alex Vispoli in the general election (winning 50% of the vote). She took office January 7, 2015. In the 2016 election, she defeated Lawrence Republican Susan LaPlante winning in all four towns with over 63% of the vote. She served as the Chair of the Joint Committee on Consumer Protection and Professional Licensure and the Joint Committee on Elder Affairs, as well as the Vice Chair of the Senate Committee on Bills in the Third Reading.\n\n\nOn July 23, 2018, L'Italien appeared on '''' and criticized the . Fox had intended to book , a Democrat running for Congress in  and booked L'Italien by mistake.\n\n\n\n* (Massachusetts legislature)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Royal Lee Bolling''' (June 19, 1920 – July 16, 2002) was a Massachusetts politician and head of a prominent African-American political family. While serving in the  in 1965, he sponsored the state's , which led to the desegregation of Boston's public schools.\n\nBolling was a decorated  veteran, earning a  as a member of the segregated \"Buffalo Soldiers\" . He was also the founder of a successful real estate business, which he ran for 50 years.\n\n\nBolling was born in , to Granville and Irene Bolling. At the age of eight, he moved with his family to Framingham, Massachusetts. He grew up in a small yellow house on Walnut Street near . He first showed a talent for politics when he ran for president of his predominantly white  class and obtained endorsements from Massachusetts governor  and Boston Mayor . He became the school's first African-American class president and was re-elected twice before graduating in 1940.\n\nHe attended Howard University for a time, performing as a  in D.C.-area nightclubs to earn money for tuition, before leaving school to join the military. After the war he moved to  and continued his studies at Harvard University and Boston University Law School. While still a student he founded a real estate agency, from which he retired circa 1992.\n\n\nIn 1943, Bolling joined the segregated  of the U.S. Army (also known as the \"Buffalo Soldiers\"), eventually rising to the rank of first lieutenant. He fought in German-occupied Italy, earning the , , four , and the  for \"extraordinary leadership and valor under fire.\"\n\n\n\nIn 1961 he was elected to the , where he served six two-year terms. He represented the 11th Suffolk District (Ward 12) from 1961 to 1964 and the 7th Suffolk District from 1965 to 1968 and 1971 to 1974 (Wards 9 and 12 from 1961 to 1968 and Wards 8, 9, and 12 from 1971 to 1974). After a failed run in 1974, he ran again and in 1982 he was elected to the , where he represented the  from 1983 to 1988. He was defeated in the 1988 primary election by his longtime rival .\n\nBolling authored over 200 legislative initiatives in the course of his career. In 1963, he proposed the original Racial Imbalance Act, a version of which was signed into law by Governor  in 1965 and which led to the desegregation of Boston's public schools. He was instrumental in establishing Boston's  program, and secured the initial funding for . He advocated for the creation of the Second Suffolk Senate District, which led to the election of Boston's first black state senator, , in 1974.\n\nIn 1985 he sponsored the bill to redevelop the grounds of ; dozens of  townhouses have since been built on the site, with many more planned. Bolling was an early advocate for , and chaired the Hispanic Commission, the state's first commission on issues affecting Latinos. He also chaired the senate's Public Service Committee. Widely recognized for his diplomatic skills, Bolling was chairman of the Special Legislative Committee on Foreign Trade and was hosted by heads of state around the world.\n\nHe was a member of the , the , the , , and .\n\n\nHe married Thelma \"Angela\" Greene in 1943 and had 12 children. His first son, , served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives; his second son, , was Boston's first African-American City Council president.\n\nBolling's wife died of  in 2002. A month later, Bolling died at his vacation home in Oak Bluffs, , Massachusetts, also of pancreatic cancer.\n\n\nSenator Bolling Circle in  was named for Bolling in June 2006, at a dedication ceremony attended by former governor , former state senate president , and many other Massachusetts politicians.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Brian Augustine Joyce''' (September 5, 1962 – September 27, 2018) was an American politician who was a  for the . He served for nine terms, representing the Norfolk, Bristol and Plymouth district, which includes ,  Precincts 1A, 1B, 2A & 2B, ,  Precinct 4,  Precincts 3-6, , ,  Precincts 2 & 3, , and .\n\n\nJoyce was born in . He graduated from  in 1980. He received his bachelor's degree from  in 1984, and he graduated magna cum laude from  in 1990. He practiced law in .\n\n\n\n\n\nDuring his tenure in the Senate, Joyce distinguished himself as a fierce advocate for the rights of disabled children and elderly citizens. He was credited with securing hundreds of millions of dollars for public schools in his district, and he was instrumental in the revitalization of the Neponset River and Blue Hills reservations.\n\nIn 2004, after Massachusetts became the first U.S. state to legalize same-sex marriage, Joyce preserved equal marriage rights by filibustering a bill that would have banned same-sex marriage. At the time, Joyce explained his decision by stating that \"I believe in an America where no religious body seeks to impose its will, directly or indirectly. Tradition as a rationale for discrimination is not persuasive.\"\n\nIn May 2006, Joyce traveled to Pakistan in support of 's efforts to court the allied nation in the , where he talked foreign policy on state-run , joining then  and New Mexico Attorney General  on a top Pakistani talk show.\n\nJoyce strongly opposed the  during his tenure in office, and he tried repeatedly to ban the Center's use of electric shock treatment on disabled children. The Judge Rotenberg Center has been condemned for torture by the .\n\n\nDuring his final term in office, Joyce served in the following roles:\n* Assistant Majority Leader\n* Chair, Senate Committee on Bills in the Third Reading\n* Chair, Special Senate Committee to Improve Government\n* Vice Chair, Senate Committee on Redistricting\n* Joint Committee on Health Care Financing\n\n\nOn February 17, 2016, the  and  conducted a raid at Joyce's Washington Street law office. Joyce was under scrutiny for various ethical improprieties alleged by '''' reporters, including having his campaign fund pay for his son's high school  party and accepting free or discounted services from a  in Randolph, Massachusetts. According to the FBI, the raid was part of a federal investigation, though no charges have been filed at that time.\n\nThe nature of the raid has again raised recurring questions about the close relationship between the ''Boston Globe'' and the office of . The Boston's U.S. Attorney's Office has since come under increased scrutiny for abuses of power for political purposes. Many of the Globe's allegations were proven inaccurate by other journalists, who expressed concern that the Globe may have knowingly printed misleading stories about Joyce.\n\nOn February 23, 2016, Joyce announced that he would not seek re-election to the Massachusetts State Senate for the next term.\n\nDuring the winter of 2016, The Boston Globe reported that the federal government has seated a  to look into Joyce's conduct.\n\n\nIn December 2017, Joyce was indicted by a federal grand jury on charges he collected over $1 million in bribes and kickbacks that he laundered through his law office and another personal business. He was arrested by Federal agents on December 8, 2017, for the multiple felony counts of the indictment.\n\nLegal experts have expressed doubt over the merit of the charges against Joyce, and many of the governments' allegations were later disproven. Prosecutors' attempt to disqualify Joyce's attorney was met with alarm by members of the Boston legal community, who viewed it as an unprecedented infringement on a defendant's Sixth Amendment rights. The ACLU, along with the Massachusetts Bar Association and dozens of individual Massachusetts attorneys, jointly filed an amici curiae brief defending Joyce's Constitutional right to counsel and rebuking the Government for its overreach. The conduct of federal prosecutors in the case has exacerbated ongoing concerns over the legal ethics of the Boston U.S. Attorney's Office.\n\nJoyce pleaded not guilty in December 2017 to charges including , , ,  and scheming to defraud the  (IRS). Joyce was released on a $250,000 bond.\n\nThe 102-page indictment accuses Joyce of turning his law office into a criminal enterprise, going so far as to accept hundreds of pounds of free coffee from a local  owner.\n\nIn January 2018, Joyce's former accountant, John Nardozzi, was indicted on federal charges that he helped prepare and file false tax returns for Joyce, misclassifying over $2 million of personal expenses as business expenses, in order to reduce Joyce's tax burden. In October 2019, Nardozzi was convicted by a jury of helping Joyce cheat the IRS out of approximately $600,000 in tax payments, and in January 2020, Nardozzi was sentenced to 18 months in federal prison.\n\nOn October 8, 2018, US Attorney Andrew Lelling announced that he had dismissed all criminal charges against Joyce, in light of his untimely death.\n\n\nIn the early morning hours of September 26, 2018, Joyce was involved in a single car crash when he reportedly swerved to avoid hitting a , crashing through a telephone pole, and finally stopping after hitting a fence.\n\nOn September 27, 2018, Joyce was found dead in his home in Westport, with no foul play suspected.\n\nOn December 4, 2018, Massachusetts state medical examiner's office reported Joyce's death was caused by an overdose of  and ruled the manner of death was \"acute pentobarbital intoxication\" and remains undetermined, pending a “thorough death investigation.”\n\n\nJoyce was a lifelong resident of Milton, Massachusetts, where he lived with his wife, Mary. They had five children.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Taylor Bennett''' (born September 12, 1985) is a former   and former member of the . He began his collegiate career at  before transferring to the . He majored in International Affairs at Georgia Tech. He later enrolled as a graduate student majoring in Information Systems Security at Louisiana Tech in the fall of 2008. Taylor also obtained a  degree from .\n\nHe also played football professionally in Sweden in the .\n\n\n \n| pastteams           = \n*  (2009)\n}}\n\nTaylor Bennett attended  in  from 2000 to 2004.\n\n\nBennett was selected as the Yellow Jackets' backup quarterback before the 2004 game against the . Prior to the 2007 season, he started in two games; in 2005 against the  when  had , and in the 2007  against the  when  was academically ineligible to play. At the Connecticut game, Bennett became only the second quarterback in  history to complete a pass for a touchdown in his first ever collegiate play from scrimmage. The only other quarterback to do this was former  quarterback . In May 2007, Bennett was given a Spring Team honorable mention by  in recognition of his outstanding performance in spring practice.\n\nBennett had a mediocre showing as the starting quarterback in Georgia Tech's 2007 season, finishing 7–6, 4–4 ACC, including a loss to Fresno State. After the ,  was named as Georgia Tech's new head coach. Many believed that Bennett would not fit well into Johnson's , and in February 2008 Bennett announced that he planned to transfer to another school for the 2008 season. On April 28, it was announced that Bennett would transfer to , and the  would allow him to play in the 2008 season rather than sitting out a season as most transfers are required to do.\n\nBennett won the starting job for the Bulldogs during 2008 fall camp. He led his new team to a victory over the  of the  in the 2008 season opener. Unfortunately, this proved to be the highlight of Bennett's season with the Bulldogs. Over the first five games of the season Bennett completed only 39 percent of his passes. He threw 2 touchdowns and 5 interceptions and led the team to a 2–3 record. After a disappointing loss to , in which Bennett threw 2 interceptions, head coach  announced that sophomore Ross Jenkins would start the next game against . Bennett saw little action for the rest of the season. He went 5 for 11 in only 2 games for no touchdowns and 1 interception.\n\n\nDuring the 2009 season, Bennett was the starting quarterback for the  in Stockholm, Sweden: the season ended with the club's 11th national championship. The Mean Machine had a 8–2 record in the  regular season.  Taylor finished the season with 1756 yards passing, 26 touchdowns, and just 3 interceptions. The team won its league playoff semi-final and then won the championship game 24-20 over the . \n\nIn the EFL  the Mean Machine went 1-1, losing in the group playoff stage 22-6 to the Porvoo Butchers of Finland.                  The  from Austria won the 2009  EFL final, defeating the  30-19.\n\n\nA member of the , Bennett ran in a special election to replace Republican  for the right to represent District 80 in the Georgia House of Representatives. He won a runoff election against former  mayor J. Max Davis on August 11, 2015 to capture the seat.\n\nIn 2016, Bennett was defeated for reelection by Atlanta attorney .\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Alfred Sylvester Brothers''' (November 4, 1919 – September 6, 2002) was an American politician who served two terms in the .\n\n\nBrothers was born on November 4, 1919, in . He graduated from 's  and . During  he served in the all-black  and was awarded the . While in the Army, Brothers became close friends with . Brothers suggested Brooke move to Massachusetts and later talked him into entering politics. Brooke represented Massachusetts in the  from 1967 to 1979 and was the first popularly elected African-American senator. After the war, Brothers entered in the construction and real estate business and he and Brooke had their offices in the same building (an old theater they rented from ).\n\n\nBrothers represented  in the Massachusetts House of Representatives from 1961 to 1965. He represented the , which covered Boston's Ward 12. In 1964 the district lines were redrawn and Brothers lost his bid for reelection in the .\n\nBrother was a close campaign advisor to Brooke and held several positions within 's Boston office, retiring in 1986 as the director of the civil rights and contract compliance division.\n\n\nBrothers died on September 6, 2002, at Good Samaritan Medical Center in . He was survived by his wife and two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

As clerk of courts, he instituted the one-day–one-case jury system.  He was succeeded as clerk of courts by his nephew, , after holding the position for 48 years.     "pages": }\n'''Joseph Patrick Kennedy III''' (born October 4, 1980) is an American politician and diplomat who has been the  since 2022. Prior to this, Kennedy served as the  for  from 2013 to 2021. A member of the , he represented a district that extends from 's western suburbs to the state's . He worked as an assistant district attorney in the  and , offices before his election to Congress. In January 2021, he became a  commentator.\n\nA member of the , he is a son of U.S. Representative , a grandson of  and  , a grandnephew of U.S. President  and U.S. Senator , and a great-grandson of U.S. Ambassador to Great Britain \n\nBorn in Boston, Kennedy was raised in the area with his twin brother, Matthew Rauch Kennedy. After graduating from  with a bachelor's degree, he spent two years in the  as a member of the , before earning a  at  in 2009. He resigned from his role as assistant district attorney in early 2012 to run for the U.S. House of Representatives seat held by the retiring . Kennedy was sworn into office in January 2013, and sat on the . In 2020, Kennedy unsuccessfully challenged incumbent Senator  for the Democratic nomination in the . He was succeeded by fellow Democrat, and distant cousin-in-law, .\n\nSince leaving office, he has founded Groundwork Project, which focuses on boosting local community organizing efforts throughout the United States. He has also joined several advisory boards and has appeared as a political commentator for . On June 4, 2021, President  appointed him to be a member of the . In December 2022, Kennedy was named the  by President Biden.\n\n\nKennedy was born on October 4, 1980, in  in , to Sheila Brewster (Rauch) (b. 1949) and . He was born eight minutes after his fraternal twin brother, Matthew. The twins are the eldest grandsons of Senator  and . Kennedy is also the great-great-grandson of , one of the original trustees of , and a direct descendant of ''''  . They were raised in Brighton and the coastal town of , also spending summers on . From birth, Kennedy was surrounded by politics; in 1980, his parents worked on the  of U.S. Senator , the boys' grand-uncle. Kennedy's father was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1986. His parents divorced in 1991. The twins spent the following years moving between Brighton and .\n\n\nAfter graduating from  School in Cambridge, Kennedy and his brother enrolled at , where he majored in  and engineering. Kennedy's reputation as a  earned him the college nickname \"Milkman\", as his teammates on the club  team would jokingly order him glasses of milk at bars. At Stanford, Kennedy roomed with future  player .\n\nAfter graduating in 2003, Kennedy joined the ; a fluent Spanish speaker, he worked in the 's  province from 2004 to 2006, helping local tour guides in the 27 Charcos reserve in the Río Damajagua Park. He reorganized the group with some outside backing, directing the guides to rebuild parts of the park and develop skills to make the operation more attractive to tourists. \"We basically created a union,\" said Kennedy, who reported that the group's efforts won higher wages for employees while increasing the tour companies' revenue. According to a press release, his other activities in the Peace Corps included \"stints as an Anti-Poverty Consultant for the Office of the President of the  and a Research Analyst for the .\"\n\n\n (2011)|179x179px]]\nIn April 2006, Kennedy returned to , where he and his brother co-chaired Ted Kennedy's . The same month, Kennedy enrolled in . There, he worked for the , providing legal aid to low-income tenants with foreclosure cases in the wake of the , and as a technical editor for the ''Harvard Human Rights Journal'', on a staff with his classmate and future wife, Lauren Anne Birchfield. In 2007, he and Birchfield co-founded ''Picture This: Justice and Power'', an after-school program for youths in Boston's  neighborhood. He began an internship at the Cape and Islands District Attorney's Office in 2008.\n\nAfter earning his  in 2009, Kennedy was hired at the  District Attorney's Office as an  (ADA). He considered running for the Cape-based U.S. House seat held by retiring Rep.  in early 2010 but decided against it. In September 2011, he joined the  District Attorney's Office, also as an ADA. He resigned several months later, in preparation for the announcement that he would seek political office. Boston.com |url=https://www.boston.com/uncategorized/noprimarytagmatch/2012/01/05/joseph-p-kennedy-iii-family-scion-explores-run-for-barney-franks-house-seat |access-date=August 17, 2020 |publisher= |date=January 5, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230417005833/https://www.boston.com/uncategorized/noprimarytagmatch/2012/01/05/joseph-p-kennedy-iii-family-scion-explores-run-for-barney-franks-house-seat/ |archive-date=April 17, 2023 |url-status=bot: unknown }}\n\n\n\n\n\n (center), and his predecessor  (right), 2012 ]]\nIn January 2012, Kennedy announced he would form an exploratory committee to run in the newly redrawn . Kennedy explained, \"I will then begin to reach out to the people of the Fourth District, in order to hear directly from them about the challenges they are facing and their ideas on how we can restore fairness to our system. I will make a final decision about entering the race in the weeks thereafter.\"\n\nHe officially entered the election in February 2012. In an announcement video, Kennedy declared, \"I believe this country was founded on a simple idea: that every person deserves to be treated fairly, by each other and by their government\". In the same video, Kennedy vowed to fight for a \"fair job plan\", a \"better educational system\", a \"fair tax code\", and a \"fair housing policy\".\n\nWhile several Democratic candidates had prepared to enter the race, the field nearly cleared once Kennedy announced his candidacy. His family roots made him the overwhelming favorite among Massachusetts Democrats. In the September 6 primary, he faced Rachel Brown, a  acolyte, and Herb Robinson, an engineer and musician, winning the primary with around 90 percent of the vote. He was elected to the  on November 6, 2012, defeating  candidate , winning over 60% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nIn the 2014 election, Kennedy ran unopposed in the primary and general elections. On November 4, 2014, he was re-elected to a second term with 184,158 votes (98%).\n\n\n\n\nIn 2016, after running unopposed in the Democratic primary, Kennedy was re-elected to a third term, defeating Republican David Rosa by more than 40 percentage points.\n\n\n\n\nKennedy was mentioned as a potential candidate for the  but declined, running for re-election to the House and saying he had no plans to run for any other office. He was re-elected unopposed.\n\n\n\n\n, in 2018.]]\n]]\nKennedy was sworn into the  on January 3, 2013, and assigned to the  and the . He praised the technology committee assignment as an opportunity to secure federal funding, including  and  grants, for life sciences companies in his district. As a freshman in his party, he was unable to secure a seat he had sought on the .\n\nDuring a February science committee hearing, Kennedy questioned  president Richard Templeton about the company's efforts to compensate cancer-stricken former employees of its , nuclear facility. A prolific fundraiser, he launched his , the 4MA PAC, in April. As a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, he traveled in May with four other legislators to , where they met with President  and members of the military. That month, he was named chairman of Governor 's  Advisory Council.\n\nOn July 24, 2013, Kennedy was one of seven members of the  (CPC) to vote against the Amash-Conyers amendment to limit Section 215 of the , which tried to restrict  surveillance programs. In contrast, a majority of both CPC members and of Democratic members of Congress voted for the amendment, while Kennedy stood out as a supporter of the party leadership. His vote has been criticized as a sign for a lack of commitment to .\n\nKennedy was a member of the .\n\n\n\nOn January 26, 2018, House Minority Leader  and Senate Minority Leader  announced that Kennedy would deliver the Democratic response to President Donald Trump's 2018 State of the Union address. His selection came after criticism that the  had relied too heavily on its oldest leaders since the . In choosing Kennedy, the party was seen as trying to bridge the gap with a new face attached to . On January 30, he gave the response to television cameras and a live studio audience in the automotive body shop of  at , . The location was meant to emphasize the role immigrants have in American society. He spent the opening minutes of his speech boasting about the economy and industrial history of Fall River, a city in . His audience included Diman Regional Technical School students. He praised , and spoke in Spanish about . He also took numerous swings at Trump, criticizing the  for \"rolling back civil rights by the day\" and attacking the administration for \"targeting the very idea that we are all worthy of protection\". He accused Trump of turning American life \"into a zero-sum game\", and said that Democrats intended to aid the middle and lower classes. He closed by characterizing the state of the union as \"hopeful, resilient, enduring\".\n\n\n\n\n\nOn August 26, 2019, Kennedy announced he was considering a primary challenge against incumbent Senator , and on September 21, he formally announced his candidacy. He announced that he would not seek re-election, instead challenging Markey in the Democratic primary for the 2020 United States Senate election in Massachusetts. On September 1, 2020, Markey defeated him in the Democratic primary. Kennedy became the first member of  to lose an election in Massachusetts., '''', Jonathan Martin, September 1, 2020. Retrieved September 2, 2020.\n\nHis defeat was widely attributed to his inability to explain his reasons for running. Additionally, Markey had strength among  and , buoyed by active youth involvement. Kennedy was endorsed by House Speaker , while Markey had the support of Senate Minority Leader , former Vice President , Senator , Representative , the youth-led , and ''''. The race was considered a showdown between the Democratic establishment and its new and growing progressive wing, although the lines between the two were blurred, as Kennedy was a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, endorsed by many members, and Markey had been in Congress 43 years at the time.\n\n\n in 2023]]\n\n\nOn December 19, 2022, President Biden announced Kennedy would replace  as . Mulvaney retired in 2021.\n\nAlthough not strictly a diplomatic role, he is the fifth Kennedy family member to serve as a diplomat/foreign envoy. Cousin  was  from 2013 to 2017 and has been  since June 2022. Aunt  has been  since January 2022. Aunt  was  from 1993 to 1998. Uncle  was  from 1968 to 1970. Great-grandfather  was  from 1938 to 1940.\n\n\n\nKennedy has co-sponsored legislation to study , supports measures to expand the , opposes discrimination in employment, housing, education, and health care, and supports removing barriers to equal opportunities for , including improving access to , housing, voting, and education. He supports , recognition of a national  and was a member of the Congressional Transgender Equality Task Force. In the area of , he is an advocate of legislation to end  and  and is a supporter of the .\n\n\nKennedy helped raise funds in 2016 for the defeat of  to  in Massachusetts. He also voted against the  in 2015 which limits the enforcement of federal law in states that have . In November 2018 he changed his stance towards cannabis and endorsed its legalization at the federal level, however. In January 2020 he co-sponsored a bill to federally legalize cannabis known as the .\n\n\nKennedy co-sponsored the , and supports aggressive action to reduce , enforce  standards, protect  from  extraction, promote  alternatives to  and , and invest in related infrastructure and scientific research. He supports strict  and the elimination of exemptions to the , and opposed the United States' withdrawal from the  under President Donald Trump.\n\n\nKennedy has helped pass legislation to guarantee access to  and , and co-sponsored legislation to . He has also co-sponsored legislation to reduce racial discrimination in housing, favors increasing the portion of federal grants earmarked for  es, and supports .\n\n\nKennedy supports strengthening  and , and favors having Medicare negotiate  directly with s. Kennedy is also a supporter of .\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n (left) speaking with Kennedy (center) and his wife Lauren in 2019]]\nKennedy married  lawyer Lauren Anne Birchfield, a graduate of the  and a finalist for the , in , on December 1, 2012. The couple met in Harvard Law School, where they took a class taught by future U.S. Senator . On December 29, 2015, Birchfield gave birth to their daughter, Eleanor. On December 20, 2017, Kennedy announced the birth of their second child, a son, named James. The family lives in .\n\nKennedy's net worth is about $43 million, which made him among the wealthiest members of Congress.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n** , February 18, 2020 – \n** , August 11, 2020 – \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Steve Thompson''' (born December 22, 1950) is an  politician. He is a member of the  from the 33rd District, serving from 1991 to 2015. He is a member of the Democratic party. He also served in the  from 1981 to 1991.\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Lester Garfield Maddox Sr.''' (September 30, 1915 – June 25, 2003) was an American politician who served as the 75th  from 1967 to 1971. A  , Maddox came to prominence as a staunch  when he refused to serve black customers in his Atlanta restaurant, the Pickrick, in violation of the . As he was ineligible to run for a second consecutive gubernatorial term, he sought and won election as , serving alongside his successor as governor, .\n\n\nMaddox was born in , the second of nine children born to Dean Garfield Maddox, a , and his wife, the former Flonnie Castleberry. Maddox left school shortly before graduation to help support the family by taking odd jobs, including real estate and grocery. He received his high school diploma through correspondence courses. During , Maddox worked at the  factory in  producing\nthe  bomber.\n\n\nIn 1944, Maddox, along with his wife Hattie Virginia (''née'' Cox, 1918–1997), used $400 in savings to open a combination grocery store-and-restaurant called Lester's Grill. Building on that success, the couple then bought property on Hemphill Avenue near the  campus to open up the Pickrick Restaurant.\n\nMaddox made the Pickrick a family affair, with his wife and children also working with him. Known for its simple, inexpensive , including its specialty, , the Pickrick soon became a thriving business. The restaurant also provided Maddox with his first political forum. He placed advertising which featured cartoon chickens in the Atlanta newspapers. Following the 1954 '''' decision of the , these restaurant ads began to feature the cartoon chickens commenting on the political questions of the day. However, Maddox's refusal to adjust to changes following the passage of the  manifested itself when he filed a lawsuit to continue his segregationist policies. Maddox said that he would close his restaurant rather than serve s. An initial group of black demonstrators came to the restaurant but did not enter when Maddox informed them that he had a large number of black employees. In April 1964, more African Americans attempted to enter the restaurant. Maddox confronted the group with a bare  handle. Maddox provides the following account of the events:\n\nMostly customers, with only a few employees, voluntarily removed the twelve Pickrick Drumsticks, (a  for pickaxe handles) from the nail kegs on each side of the large dining room fireplace. They had been forewarned by the arrival of Atlanta's news media of an impending attempted invasion of our restaurant by the racial demonstrators and once the demonstrators and agitators arrived, the customers and employees pulled the drumsticks (pickaxe handles) from the kegs and went outside to defend against the threatened invasion.\n]]\nThe \"invasion\" Maddox referred to was three black seminary students who had asked to be seated.\n\nMaddox gained the approval of segregationists by leasing and then selling the restaurant to employees rather than agreeing to serve black customers. He claimed that the issue was not hostility to blacks, but constitutional property rights. He even built a monument to \"private property rights\" near the restaurant.\n\nThe  at the  contains the following account of the closing of his restaurant:\n\nMaddox closed the Pickrick on August 13 and reopened the business on September 26 as the Lester Maddox Cafeteria, where he pledged to serve only \"acceptable\" Georgians. During a trial for contempt of court on September 29, Maddox argued against the charges because he was no longer offering service to out-of-state travelers or integrationists. On February 5, 1965, a federal court ruled that Maddox was in contempt of court for failing to obey the injunction and assigned fines of two hundred dollars a day for failing to serve African Americans. Maddox ultimately closed his restaurant on February 7, 1965, rather than integrate it; he claimed that  and communists put him out of business.\n\nThe building was purchased by Georgia Tech in 1965; it was used for many years as the placement center and was later known as the Ajax building. It was demolished in May 2009.\n\n\n\n\nDuring his ownership of the Pickrick, Maddox, a Democrat, failed in two bids for mayor of Atlanta. In 1957, he lost to incumbent , for whom the  is named. Hartsfield had pursued a more moderate approach to racial issues. In 1961, Maddox lost to , with whom he split the white vote. Allen's ability to garner virtually all of the black vote provided his margin of victory.\n\nIn 1962, Maddox ran for  as a Democrat, against , a candidate with whom he shared segregationist and  views. In an effort to differentiate themselves from each other, each attempted to paint the other as an extremist. Geer won the race, 55–45%, but Maddox gained attention across the state.\n\nIn the following years, Maddox proclaimed himself a \"Society of Liberty\" martyr intent on opposing a central government which thwarted states' rights and gave special protection to minority groups. He was recognized by his rimless eyeglasses, dome-shaped forehead, bald head, and nervous energy. It was said of Maddox, \"We have a populist revolution in its truest sense moving here. White people who work with their hands see in Lester Maddox a man of their own kind and are fighting to elect him [as governor].\"''Atlanta History'', p. 38 '''' magazine termed Maddox a \"strident racist\"; '''' viewed him as a \"backwoods demagogue out in the boondocks\". According to one account, the former restaurateur's appeal transcended race to embrace a right-wing brand of \"populism\", picturing government, rather than big business, as the villain.\n\n\n\nWhen Maddox sought the Democratic nomination for governor in 1966, his principal primary opponent was former governor . That election was still in the era of Democratic Party dominance in Georgia, when winning the Democratic primary was . There was no Republican primary at the time, but there were voters who identified with the Republican Party. Republicans cast ballots in the  Democratic primary election, and some chose the candidate they believed would most likely lose the general election to their nominee, . In the primary, Arnall won a plurality of the popular vote, but he was denied the required majority. Maddox, the second-place candidate, entered the  against Arnall.   finished in a strong third place. Again, some Republicans voted in the Democratic primary runoff. Arnall barely campaigned in the runoff, and Maddox emerged victorious, 443,055 to 373,004.\n\nMaddox quipped that he had been nominated despite having \"no money, no politicians, no television, no newspapers, no , no , and we made it!\" He joked further that Johnson had been \"the best campaign manager I've got even if he did put me out of business\", a reference to the closing of the Pickrick Restaurant to avoid desegregation. On winning the runoff, the  Maddox, who neither smoked nor drank alcohol, described God as his \"campaign manager\".\n\nStunned Arnall supporters announced a write-in candidacy for the general election, insisting that Georgians must have the option of a moderate Democrat beside the conservatives Maddox and Callaway. In his general election campaign, Maddox equated the Callaway Republicans to the  and the 1864  waged in Georgia by   . He criticized the Callaway family  mill, which he alleged had kept wages at $10 a week in . Maddox said that Callaway was unable to relate to farmers, small businessmen, and the unemployed: \"He would be a lot better off if he knew about people as well as dollars.\"  Maddox said that  had hired off-duty police officers to maintain segregation at the tourist park in , but a superior court judge verified that Callaway had an open admission policy at the facility.\n\nCallaway won a  in the general election, becoming the first Republican gubernatorial candidate to top the polls in Georgia since the close of , and Maddox finished second. More than 52,000 wrote in Arnall's name. Under the election rules then in effect, the state legislature was required to elect one of the two candidates with the highest number of votes, which meant that the lawmakers could not consider Arnall. With the legislature overwhelmingly dominated by Democrats, all of whom had been required to sign a Democratic , Maddox became governor. He was sworn in on the evening of January 10, 1967, minutes after the legislature certified his election.\n\n\n\nMaddox campaigned hard for states' rights and maintained a segregationist stance while in office. Upon the , he denied the slain civil rights leader the honor of lying in state in the Georgia state capitol after being told by undercover agents in the Atlanta Police Department that there was a planned storming of the state capitol by participants in the crowd of mourners. No evidence has ever emerged that this was anything more than a rumor; the undercover agents provided no evidence for it other than their statement. As a precaution, Maddox stationed 160 state troopers to surround the capitol. Regardless, the funeral procession, attended by tens of thousands; was entirely peaceful. Maddox called MLK an \"enemy of the people\" after his assassination and refused to attend his funeral. Maddox considered personally raising flags  that had been placed at half-mast at the State Capitol after MLK's assassination and reportedly decided against doing so because news cameras were nearby. In 1968, Maddox endorsed the former Democrat , the then pro-segregation  candidate in the . After leaving office, Maddox said \"“I’m still a segregationist. I’ve told you that 15 times. When are you going to start believing me?”\n\nWhen he was asked what might be done to improve the abysmal conditions in Georgia prisons, Maddox replied that what was really needed was a better class of prisoner. Maddox's chief of staff was , who went on to serve two terms as governor in the 1990s and as 's successor in the U.S. Senate.\n\nMaddox received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from  in 1969.\n\nIn 1968, a small Atlanta repertory company produced a play entitled ''''. The play ridiculed Maddox and imagined him winning the , then starting a war with the . The show came to Broadway and ran for forty-one performances at the  before closing. Maddox was a supporter of the  because of his anti-communist views, and he often told Georgia about the threats of communist and socialist influences.\n\n\n\nIn the 1966 campaign, the '''' forecast that as governor, Maddox would \"tell off the federal government forty times a day, but four years after his inauguration, he would have accomplished little else\". Once in office, however, Maddox accomplished the following:\n\n* Maddox was favorably influenced by Murray M. Silver, Esq., General Counsel of the Georgia Department of Labor, and Commissioner Sam Caldwell to hire blacks and to approve legislation affecting unemployment insurance of automobile workers within the state.\n* Maddox integrated the Georgia State Patrol, appointed the first African American to head a state-wide government department, appointed the first African American Georgia Bureau of Investigation agent, appointed the first African American to a draft board in Georgia, integrated Georgia's farmer's markets' lines, and directed state troopers not to address African Americans as \"niggers\".\n* Maddox introduced Little People's Day where normal people could meet the governor twice a month. After 4 escaped African-American convicts met with him on Little People's Day and informed him about terrible conditions in state prisons, Maddox launched an investigation of state prisons and ordered state prisons to make improvements. \n\nYears after Maddox's gubernatorial term ended, Republican  described Maddox as a \"far better governor than his critics will ever admit\". Blackburn, a former U.S. representative, also noted that no accusation of corruption was made against Maddox, whose administration was characterized by economic development and the appointment of African Americans to state executive positions.\n\n\nUnder the Georgia constitution of 1945, Maddox was  from running for a second consecutive term. He therefore waged his second bid for lieutenant governor, the first having resulted in defeat to Peter Zack Geer in 1962.  Although Maddox was elected as a Democratic candidate at the same time as 's election as governor, the two were not s; in Georgia, particularly in that era of Democratic dominance, the winners of the primary elections went on to easy victories in the general elections without campaigning together as an official ticket or as running mates.  Carter and Maddox found little common ground during their four years of service, often publicly feuding with each other.\n\nShortly after that election, Maddox appeared as a guest on '''' on December 18, 1970.  During a commercial break, fellow guest and former football player  asked Maddox if he had \"any trouble with the white bigots because of all the things you did for blacks\".  On the air, Cavett substituted the word \"admirers\" in place of \"bigots\", enraging Maddox. After demanding an apology from Cavett, and getting a carefully worded form of it, following further conversation, Maddox still walked off the show. Making light of the incident during a subsequent appearance by Maddox, Cavett walked off this time, and Maddox applauded. \n\nBecause the lieutenant governor was a mostly ceremonial role, Maddox spent most of his time as lieutenant governor preparing for a run for governor in 1974. Maddox was considered to be a near shoo-in to regain the governor's mansion in 1974, with the New York Times predicting that only Johnny Wayne could beat him for Georgia governor. However, Maddox was instead forced into a runoff for the Democratic nomination, where he was shockingly defeated by .\n\n\nWhen Carter ran for president in , Maddox ran against him as the nominee of Wallace's former , saying that his former rival was \"the most dishonest man I ever met\".  Maddox and running mate , the former mayor of , , received 170,373 votes in the election (less than 1% of the vote) and no electoral votes.\n\n\nWith his political career seemingly over and with massive debts stemming from his 1974 gubernatorial bid, Maddox began a short-lived nightclub comedy career in 1977 with an  musician, , who had worked as a busboy in his restaurant.Bobby Lee Fears was a native of Atlanta, who had previously worked as a guitarist and vocalist for the Fabulous Denos, who had a number of releases on the King label. He later joined an early incarnation of the  before cutting around three solo records under his own name and using the alias Bobby Dixon. Fears had served time in prison for a drug offense before Maddox, as lieutenant governor, was able to assist him in obtaining a pardon. Calling themselves \"The Governor and the Dishwasher,\" the duo performed comedy bits built around the Governor's subjugation over the Dishwasher, the Dishwasher's lack of intelligence, and musical numbers with Maddox on  and Fears on .\n\n\n\n\nAfter  was shot down in 1983, with   aboard, a special election was held to fill his seat in Congress. Lester Maddox stated his intention to run for the seat if McDonald's wife, Kathy McDonald, did not. However, Kathy McDonald decided to run, and Maddox stayed out of the race; she lost to Democrat .\n\nMaddox had been using drugs from a Bahamian cancer clinic to treat his prostate cancer. In July 1985, he revealed that the clinic had been shut down by Bahamian officials after its drugs had been found to be contaminated with the  virus. Maddox underwent testing, and two months later announced that he was free of the virus.\n\nDuring the  in January of that year, Maddox attended a rally organized by members of the  after the group had attacked several dozen marchers who were protesting against racial discrimination in the county. , a white supremacist who had previously been imprisoned for bombing a  in 1958, was also at the rally.\n\n\nMaddox made one final unsuccessful bid for governor in 1990, then underwent heart surgery the following year. In the 1990 Democratic primary for governor, Maddox finished with about three percent of the vote. He remained a visible figure in his home community of  for the remainder of his life. In 1992 and 1996, Maddox crossed party lines and endorsed unsuccessful populist Republican  for the presidency. His last public speech was in Atlanta in 2001 at the annual national conference of the . The CCC, of which Maddox was a charter member, is considered by the  and the  to be a  group.\n\n\nIn 1935, Maddox married seventeen-year-old Hattie Virginia Cox. Maddox's wife nursed him through all his illnesses and supported his political and business career, even though he had to spend much time away from the family.\n\n\nOn June 25, 2003, after a fall while recuperating from intestinal surgery in an Atlanta , Maddox died of complications from  and . He and his wife Virginia are both interred at Arlington Memorial Park in  in northern Fulton County, Georgia. Due to a successful business career, Maddox was relatively wealthy when he died.\n\n\nAfter Maddox's death in 2003, , the former , said of the former governor: \"He had a reputation as a segregationist, but he told us he was not a segregationist, but that you should be able to associate with whoever you wanted. He went on to do more for African Americans than any governor of Georgia up until that time.\" This view is not universally shared. In its obituary of the former governor, '''' called him an \"arch segregationist\"; to support this contention, the ''Times'' noted that his convictions included \"the view that blacks were intellectually inferior to whites, that integration was a Communist plot, that segregation was somewhere justified in scripture and that a federal mandate to integrate [all-white] schools was 'ungodly, un-Christian and un-American.'\" Despite this, the obituary notes that after becoming governor, Maddox \"surprised many by hiring and promoting blacks in state government and by initiating an early release program for the state prison system\".\n\nThe Interstate Highway 75 bridge over the  at the boundary of  () and  (Atlanta), is named the \"Lester and Virginia Maddox Bridge\".\n\nMaddox was the primary inspiration for 's 1974 song \"\".\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*Bruce Galphin, ''The Riddle of Lester Maddox'' (Atlanta: Camelot, 1968).\n*Brad Rice, \"Lester Maddox and the Politics of Populism,\" in ''Georgia Governors in an Age of Change: From Ellis Arnall to George Busbee'', ed. Harold P. Henderson and Gary L. Roberts (Athens: University of Georgia Press, 1988).\n*Bob Short, ''Everything Is Pickrick: The Life of Lester Maddox'' (Macon, Ga.: Mercer University Press, 1999).\n\n\n\n* from Creative Loafing, March 20, 1999 (with link to his personal rebuttal to the article)\n* \n*, March 7, 1986, Georgia's Political Heritage Program.\n*, April 17, 1986, Georgia's Political Heritage Program.\n*\n*\n* from the \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
