    "pages": }\n'''Ruthzee Louijeune''' (born 1987) is an American politician and lawyer serving as president of the . She has been an at-large member of the  since January 2022, and has served as the council's president since January 2024. She is the first  to serve on the council.\n\n\nLouijeune is the daughter of  to the United States from .\n\nShe was raised in the  and  neighborhoods of Boston. She attended Charles H. Taylor Elementary School, and graduated from  in 2004. During high school, she interned in the office of State Representative  as part of the Ward Fellowship Program.\n\nLouijeune moved to  in order to attended , where she graduated with a  in 2008. After earning her undergraduate degree, she moved to , where she attended  and , earning a  in  and a  in 2014. At Harvard Law School, she was a student attorney at the .\n\n\nLouijeune worked as an attorney for . Louijeune also served as senior  for 's . In 2021, Sean Philip Cotter of the '''' described Louijeune as being a  of Warren.\n\nLoujuene founded Opening PLLC, a legal and advocacy firm. The firm conducts consulting and works on affordable  agreements in Boston.\n\nLouijeune has been involved as a volunteer with the Massachusetts Affordable Housing Alliance, representing low-income individuals in the housing court. In her work with them, she has fought against  and to promote homeownership. She has worked with them in their efforts to increase homeownership opprountities in Boston for first-generation home buyers. She is considered to be a housing advocate.\n\nDuring the , Loujeune volunteered with Guild Works  to deliver food to food insecure and financially struggling residents of .\n\n\n\n, Senator , and Louijeune at a 2022  event]]\n during the 2023 South Boston St. Patrick's Day Parade]]\n]]\n\nLouijeune was elected to  in . As a first-time candidate Louijeune had a strong showing in the 2021 election, finishing third in the at-large race behind incumbent council members  and . She is the first  to serve on the council. Her election the city council was regarded as demonstrating their growing clout in the area's politics. According to  data,  is home to the third-largest  population in the United States. She took office in January 2022.\n\nIn her first term, Louijeuene served as chair of the Civil Rights Committee and vice-chair of the Housing and Community Development Committee\n\nIn June 2022, the Boston City Council unanimously adopted a resolution introduced by Louijeune and Councilors  and  which apologized for the city's historical role in the .\n\nIn late 2022, Louijeune proposed an amendment to have the city regulate . In late 2022, Louijeune played a key role in the passage of a 20% pay increase for members of the Boston Council, which was  by Mayor . Wu supported an 11% increase, which had been the recommendation of Boston’s compensation advisory board, but opposed a 20% increase.\n\nLouijeune and her City Council colleague Kendra Lara authored a resolution that was passed by the Boston City Council in late 2022 which urged Mayor  to raise the affordable housing unit requirements for new residential developments from 13% to 20% and to lower the threshold for which the requirements apply from buildings with nine or more units to buildings with five or more. The resolution also urged Wu to transition from utilizing -designated area median income and to instead determine base affordability based upon the average income of a neighborhood.\n\nIn late 2022, Louijeune gave her support to the idea of permitting immigrants who have legal immigration status to cast votes in elections for city offices. More than 28% of Boston's city population are immigrants with legal immigration status. Fifteen other cities in the United States had already adopted similar measures. In December 2023, Louijeune voted to give City Council approval to a home rule petition that, if signed by the mayor, approved by the state legislature, and signed by the governor, would have granted such voting rights in local elections.\n\nIn April 2023, the council unanimously adopted a resolution introduced by Louijeuene and  expressing support for an effort by  and  at  to form a .\n\nAfter a judicial ruling required the city to adopt a new City Council district map to be used in the 2023 Boston City Council election, , as , tasked Louijeune with heading the process of drawing such a map in her capacity as the chair of the Civil Rights Committee. Flynn had assigned this task to Louijeune in order to avoid having Liz Breadon (as head of the Redistricting Committee) oversee it. The adoption of a new map needed to be completed on an accelerated timeline in order to avoid a delay to the municipal elections. Over the course of two weeks weeks in which five lengthy hearings were held, a map was agreed upon by the Civil Rights Committee. In late-May, the resulting map was adopted by the full council in a 10–2 vote and signed into law by Mayor Wu. Louijeune's leadership in resolving the contentious redistricting matter raised her profile in the city's politics and won her praise. Emma Platoff of '''' called the passage of a new map, \"a feat many feared would come too late if it happened at all,\" managing to  adopt a new map in quick enough time to hold municipal elections on schedule.\n\nIn August 2023, ''Boston Herald'' political columnist Joe Battenfeld characterized Louijeune as having quickly become a \"rising star\" on the city council. He wrote that she had become, \"a fast-moving leader of the body in less than two years.\" Other Boston political commentators had similarly called her a \"rising star\" on the council.\n\n\n during the 2024 South Boston St. Patrick's Day Parade]]\n and Lieutenant Governor  (both dressed in costumes for a -related skit) and Mayor ]]\nLouijeune received the most votes in the at-large race of the , being re-elected to a second term. Two days after the election, Louijeune claimed that she believed she had secured enough support from fellow individuals elected to the incoming city council to be elected the council's next president. On January 1, 2024, after the new council was sworn-in, it voted unanimously to elect her as its president.\n\nBill Forry of the '''' observed of Louijeune’s path to being elected council president, }}\n\nForry also noted that Louijeune's election as council president marked a notable moment for Boston’s Haitian diaspora community, and found it to be “poignant” that the vote coincided with .\n\nLoujuene served as a  to the . Several weeks before the convention, incumbent president  (the party's  presidential nominee)  his  and endorsed vice president  to instead be the party's presidential nominee. Shortly after this, Loujuene indicated her support for  and intention to support her at the convention. After Republican presidential nominee  began spreading the  (a false conspiracy theory about a Haitian immigrant community in ) in September, Louijeune condemned Trump and participated in a protest decrying Trump's rhetoric.\n\nIn 2024,  called Louijeuene \"Boston's brightest rising political star\", and ranked her at #75 on its 2024 list of the \"Most Influential Bostonians\".\n\n\nLouijeune lives in Boston's Hyde Park neighborhood. In addition to , Louijeuene is  in  and . She also has conversational fluency in .\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| office = Member of thefrom the  district \n| term_start = January 7, 2013\n| term_end = \n| predecessor = \n| successor =  \n| parents = Catherine Curley DeckerTim Decker  , April 17, 2012\n}}\n'''Marjorie C. Decker''' is an American politician serving as the State Representative for the 25th Middlesex district in the . She is also House chair of the Joint Committee on Public Health. Since 2016, she has also been employed by the class action law firm Berman Tabacco. \n\nIn 2024, she faced a primary challenge from Evan MacKay, a labor leader and graduate student at . Hand recount results indicated that Decker narrowly defeated MacKay.\n\n\nDecker was born and raised in  and is a third generation Cantabrigian. Her father was a disabled Vietnam war veteran who worked as a security guard, while her mother was a nursing assistant. She grew up in public housing in , and graduated from the .\n\nDecker received her  in social thought and political economy from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, an MPA from the University of Massachusetts Boston, and a  from the  of Harvard University in 2007. \n\n\nShe served seven consecutive terms on the  in  from 1999 to 2013 and was the youngest woman ever to be elected to the Cambridge City Council, and served as Vice Mayor from 2004-2006.\n\nIn 2012, she was elected as a state representative to the Massachusetts legislature, succeeding her former employer .Levy, Marc, , ''Cambridge Day'', Thursday, September 6, 2012 She is the co-chair of the Joint Committee on Public Health. Decker has written legislation to ban toxic chemicals in firefighter protective gear, which was signed into law. She has also sponsored a bill which has not yet passed for the transition the commonwealth to 100 per cent clean energy for electricity by 2035.\n\n\nAs lead House negotiator, Decker developed legislation to create resources on maternal health, which was signed by the Governor in August 2024. The maternal health bill expands access to midwifery care and out-of-hospital births, and bill mandates insurance coverage for midwifery services while expanding MassHealth coverage to services for pregnancy and post-partum care including doula services. The bill also regulates freestanding birth centers, and mandates postpartum depression screenings and data collection on pregnancy loss. \n\n\nIn 2018, Decker co-authored legislation aimed at closing a loophole in Massachusetts law to ensure that police officers cannot claim consensual sexual conduct with individuals in their custody. The proposal seeks to eliminate ambiguity regarding consent in such situations, which would align state law with zero-tolerance federal policies. This initiative followed high-profile cases where officers were accused of sexual misconduct.\n\n\nIn 2024, she faced a primary challenge from Evan MacKay, a graduate student in Sociology at . Official recount results from the Cambridge Election Commission indicated that Decker defeated MacKay by 41 votes., Cambridge Day, Marc Levy, September 12, 2024. Retrieved September 12, 2024.\n\n\nShe has received the endorsement of the Massachusetts , , , the , and more than a dozen other labor unions., as well as the Massachusetts Black and Latino Caucus. A majority of Cambridge City Council members have signed an opinion letter endorsing her, describing her as a \"trusted partner\".\n\nShe received the endorsements of Governor , Senator , and local Congressional Representatives  and .\n\nIn August 27, she received the endorsement of .\n\n\n\n\nHouse rules currently require committee votes to be kept at the State House in the committees' respective offices and available for public inspection during regular office hours. An amendment to make committee roll call votes available on the Legislature's website has been proposed and voted down along party lines since 2011. Decker voted against such amendments in 2018, 2019 , and 2021  in the annual  rules bill. All amendments failed to pass a large majority, with the 2021 vote failing by a vote of 41-117. \n\nIn 2022, a non-binding ballot question organized by her later political opponent was presented to voters in her district, asking whether their representative should support changes to House rules to make each legislator's committee vote available on the Legislature's website. 94.2% of voters in Decker's district supported the measure.\n\nIn 2024, Decker said that committee votes \"should be online\".\n\n\nIn 2020, the  (DCR) expanded  along  in Cambridge to include Saturdays. After considerable public debate and a  vote in support of expanded hours, the DCR limited the park space to Sundays only in April 2023. In June 2023, Decker emailed constituents, stating, \"I have not ever publicly or privately advocated against Saturday closings.\"  \n\nHowever, emails released as part of a  request in July 2023 appeared to contradict this account. In a March 25 email, Rebecca Tepper, Secretary of the , noted a \"falling out\" between Decker and fellow Representative Mike Connolly, who supported the extended closures. Tepper twice described Decker as \"staunchly opposed\" to the Saturday closures and indicated that Decker had \"reiterated her position that she was opposed to the park and hoped that none of her colleagues would attempt to force this on her district.\"\n\nThis incident was covered in multiple episodes of a Cambridge Community Television program '''What's that about?'.'' Following these revelations, Decker publicly denied the claims, stating on X (formerly Twitter): \"The email from Secretary Tepper does not, and never has, reflect my current position or any position I have articulated in the past. The fact is that I have never stated any personal opposition to the closure of Memorial Drive on Saturdays.\"\n\n\nSince 2016, Decker has worked for the class action law firm Berman Tabacco, which paid her over $100,000 annually. Decker has not commented on the nature of the employment since it was revealed through a public records request in 2024, brushing off criticism about the second job and explaining that she is producing sufficiently for her constituents. Decker's opponents have cited the employment as a potential conflict of interest.\n\n\nDecker lives with her husband and two children in Cambridge.  \n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* , official page at Massachusetts State Legislature\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Tania Fernandes Anderson''' (born January 4, 1979) is a an-born American politician and  executive who is a member of the  for the 7th district. A , she was elected in  to succeed  and represents , , and part of the . She is the first practicing  elected to the Council.\n\n\nFernandes Anderson was born in , , and moved to  when she was 10. She graduated from . The first formally undocumented African-born immigrant elected in Boston, MA, she is the executive director of Bowdoin Geneva Main Streets, a  supporting .\n\n\n\nElected in , Fernandes Anderson took office in January 2022.\n\nIn June 2022, the Boston City Council unanimously adopted a resolution introduced by Fernandes Anderson and Councilors  and  which apologized for the city's historical role in the .\n\nIn her first term, Fernandes Anderson chaired the Ways and Means Committee, which has a purview centered on budget-related legislation. In June 2023, the city council voted 7–5 to approve an operating budget for the following fiscal year as it had been amended by the committee. Many of the amendments that the committee had made to the budget faced heavy criticism from dissenting council members. Mayor  soon  a majority of the budget amendments, including amendments which would have resulted in decreased funding to the city's Office of Veterans Services and its police department, an amendment aimed at increasing citizen input in budgeting, as well as decreases of funding for the city's Transportation Department, Public Works Department, and the . After Wu's vetoes, the city council held votes on overriding six of the vetoes, but were only secured the necessary threshold to override a single veto.\n\nIn October 2022, Fernandes Anderson offered a resolution calling for “Boston's Hijab Day”, in recognition of , a 22-year-old woman who died while in the custody of Iranian authorities. Amini had been arrested for improperly wearing the hijab. The city council agreed to mark September 23, Amini's birthday, as the “Day of Woman, Life and Freedom” in connection with human rights protests in Iran, but declined to recognize it as “Boston's Hijab Day”.\n\nFernandes Anderson was vocal on the . At an October 18, 2023 city council hearing where resolutions were presented about the  and subsequent war, Fernandes Anderson made comments calling for a return of  and an immediate ceasefire by both sides and introduced a resolution calling for an immediate de-escalation and ceasefire. She was criticized for characterizing the Hamas-led October 7 attack in her resolution as a \"military operation\" rather than an act of . Councilors  and  opposed holding an immediate vote on Fernandes Anderson's ordinance, and it was referred to the . In December 2023, Fernandes Anderson presented a citation purportedly from the entire city council to two  students praising them for a pro-Palestine student  that they had organized in Boston schools. The students were then, at the invite of Fernandes Anderson, given time to make a presentation and proceeded to make remarks that were characterized as being \"divisive\". Numerous councilors reported having felt \"blindsided\" by the citation and presentation, including Council President . Flynn claimed that he had not been accurately informed by Fernandes Anderson as to what the citation and presentation related to, and that he would not have consented to either had he been familiar. Flynn claimed that the presentation went against council practice of disallowing presentations by outside individuals on controversial topics.\n\n\nIn July 2023, Fernandes Anderson admitted guilt and agreed to pay a $5,000 civil penalty after violating conflict of interest laws by hiring her sister and son to paid positions on her Boston City Council staff, according to the Massachusetts State Ethics Commission. After her 2021 election to the Boston City Council, Fernandes Anderson appointed her sister as her full-time Director of Constituent Services.  She initially set her sister’s salary at $65,000 and then approved an increased to $70,000 in 2022, while also giving her sister a $7,000 bonus, according to the disposition agreement signed by Fernandes Anderson. In 2022, she also appointed her son as her office manager at an annual salary of $52,000 and then less than two weeks later, gave her son a pay raise to $70,000. In a statement released to the public, State Ethics Commission executive director David Wilson said, \"Fernandes Anderson's actions as a Boston City Councilor concerning the appointment and compensation of her sister and son violated the conflict of interest law's prohibition against municipal employees participating in their official capacity in matters in which they know members of their immediate family have a financial interest.\"  Both her sister and her son's employment were terminated in August 2022.\n\n\nFernandes Anderson was reelected , defeating a challenge by , a  and former officeholder. When the  was being administered collectively to city councilors by Mayor Michelle Wu at the January 1, 2024 inaugural meeting of new council term, Fernandes Anderson failed both to raise her hand and verbally recite the oath. A video showing Fernandes Anderson's failure to perform her oath of office  after being posted to the  account on , with the account's post including commentary accusing Fernandes of hating the United States. She responded that she had \"internalized\" the oath with a private prayer, and called commentary on it \"anti-immigrant racist vitriol.\" However, because the  requires that city councilors recite their oath of office in order to serve, Mayor Wu and the city government declared that Anderson's tenure on the council had lapsed and ordered that city council records be amended to discount Fernandes Anderson's vote on the selection of Ruthzee Louijeune as council president, since Fernandes Anderson had not been eligible to cast any council votes (the choice of Louijeune as council president had been unanimous, therefore this had no material impact). Fernandes Anderson was allowed to re-assume her office as a city councilor after taking her oath on January 4, 2024.\n\nIn February 2024, Fernandes Anderson introduced a request to hold a hearing to explore the possibility of Boston adopting  for access to the city by motor vehicles. Fernandes Anderson touted congestion pricing as a possible solution to allieviation traffic woes on the city's roadways.\n\n\nFernandes Anderson has been a  mom of 17 children. In a 2023 council meeting, Fernandes Anderson mentioned that one of her sons has served in the . Fernandes Anderson is a practicing .\n\nFernandes Anderson is married to Tanzerious Anderson, who is currently incarcerated for murder.\n\nOn August 2, 2023, Fernandes Anderson was a robbery victim in Boston. While she was surveying an area populated by homeless people, a man grabbed her cell phone and ran away. After summoning the police, officers conducted a search of the homeless encampment, recovered the phone and returned to her. Fernandes Anderson subsequently criticized the  for allowing details of the crime to be made public. She also criticized the media for reporting the incident, calling it “propaganda.”\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael John Barrett''' (born June 27, 1948) is an American politician noted for having been elected to serve in three completely different state legislative districts over the course of his political career.  At present he is the state senator for the  of . Barrett served in the  earlier, in 1987–1994, representing another district (Cambridge, Belmont, Watertown and the Allston-Brighton neighborhood of Boston), before moving to his present home in suburban Lexington in 1996. Even earlier, in 1979–1985, he served in the  from a district comprising Reading, North Reading and a portion of Wilmington.\n\n\nBarrett was born in . He was the second oldest in a family of ten children, graduated from Reading (MA) High School in 1966,  ''magna cum laude'' in 1970, and  in 1977, after which he clerked for the U.S. District Court in \n\n\nBarrett was elected to the Massachusetts House of Representatives in 1978. He ran for a seat in the  in 1984, losing the Democratic primary in the  to .\n\n\nIn 1990, during his first stint as state senator, Barrett wrote an '''' cover story in which he advocated a longer school day and year for American students. A year later, he was named one of nine commissioners on the National Education Commission on Time and Learning, created by the U.S. Congress to examine the issues raised in the ''Atlantic'' article.\n\nIn 1992 Barrett drafted and saw through to enactment domestic violence legislation for Massachusetts that was precedent-setting in the United States, in that it required judges to consult a comprehensive computerized registry of offenders before they ruled on requests for restraining orders. He was also successful as lead sponsor of major environmental legislation regulating uses of toxic materials in manufacturing within the state.\n\n\nIn 1994 Barrett ran unsuccessfully for . Departing the state senate the following year, he was named CEO and general counsel of the Visiting Nurse Associations of New England, a large home health care provider network. Several years later, he embarked on a consulting career focused on the emergence of the Internet and the development of online services involved in health care.\n\n\nIn December 2011, after a 16-year absence from politics, Barrett announced his candidacy for state senate in the 3rd Middlesex District. In September 2012 he won the Democratic nomination after an intensely contested five-candidate race. He went on to beat Republican nominee Sandra Martinez in the November 6th general election. The 3rd Middlesex District covers nine communities: , , , ,  (precincts 3, 8 and 9), ,  (precincts 1, 4 and 5),  and .\n\nIn January 2013 Barrett was named Senate Chair of the Joint Committee on Children, Families and Persons with Disabilities. In 2015 Barrett was named chair of the Senate Post-Audit and Oversight Committee, a unique body charged with overseeing implementation of all state programs run by the governor and his appointees.  In 2017 he was appointed Senate Chair of the Joint Committee on Telecommunications, Utilities & Energy. The committee's jurisdiction covers everything from cell phones to alternative energy to public utility reform to .\n\n\nBarrett lives in Lexington with his wife. They have twin daughters.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Susan Holmes''' (born October 8, 1942) is an  politician, farmer, former teacher, and former postmaster from Georgia. Holmes served as a  member of the  from 2011 to 2023.\n\n\nHolmes was born in . Holmes graduated from .\n\n\nHolmes earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Education from .\n\n\nHolmes is a cotton and dairy farmer in Jasper County, Georgia. Holmes is a former teacher and postmaster.\n\nIn 1998, Holmes became the first woman mayor of , until 2010.\n\nIn January 2007, Holmes was appointed by President George W. Bush as the State Executive Director of the Farm Service Agency for Georgia.\n\nOn November 2, 2010, Holmes won the election and became a  member of  for District 125. Holmes defeated David Gault with 64.74% of the votes.\n\nOn November 6, 2012, Holmes won the election unopposed and became a  member of  for District 129. On November 4, 2014, as an incumbent, Holmes won the election unopposed and continued serving District 129. On November 8, 2016, as an incumbent, Holmes won the election unopposed and continued serving District 129. On November 6, 2018, as an incumbent, Holmes won the election unopposed and continued serving District 129. On November 3, 2020, as an incumbent, Holmes won the election and continued serving District 129. Holmes defeated Sharonda Bell and Joe Reed with 69.61% of the votes.\n\n\n* 2001 Citizen of The Year. Presented by Monticello-Jasper County Chamber of Commerce.\n\n\nHolmes' husband is Paul Holmes. They have three children. Holmes and her family live in . Holmes was initially slated to sign as a Georgia False Elector, but refused to join. Georgia False Electors were recruited by the Georgia Republican Party to support Donald Trump's failed effort to subvert the results of the 2020 presidential election.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| known_for   = Commentary on issues related to women in gaming\n}}\n\n'''Brianna Wu''' (born July 6, 1977) is an American  and . She co-founded Giant Spacekat, an  studio, with Amanda Warner in . She is also a  and  on matters relating to the .\n\nIn 2018, Wu unsuccessfully  in . Wu began a second campaign for the primary in 2020; in April, she announced her departure from the race, due to the COVID-19 lockdown preventing in-person campaigning.Fox, Jeremy C. (April 28, 2020).  ''''.\n\n\nWu was born in  and raised in  by adoptive parents. She grew up in an entrepreneurial environment; her father was a retired US Navy doctor who opened his own clinic, and her mother ran a series of small businesses. She enrolled at the , studying  and  and writing for '''', but left in 2001 without a degree.\n\n\nAt the age of 19, Wu formed a small animation studio to create an animated . The venture was unsuccessful, resulting in her withdrawal from college and a move to , to work in political fundraising for several years. She later worked as a journalist until she was inspired by the release of the  to work as a  and create a .\n\nIn 2010, she co-founded the company Giant Spacekat with Amanda Stenquist Warner. Wu was co-host of the weekly ''Isometric'' podcast on . The podcast was launched in May 2014 and covers the video game industry. On April 18, 2016, the ''Isometric'' podcast was ended. The same hosts, including Wu, started a new podcast called ''Disruption'' on Relay FM, covering technology and culture. \n\n\n\nWu is credited as head of development for her company Giant Spacekat's game, ''''. It features female protagonists, said to echo the founders of the game studio. The game was demonstrated at  in March 2013, where it was listed as one of the 10 best indie games of the conference. The game, created with the  for a total budget of several hundred thousand dollars, was released for  devices in July 2014.\n\n\nWu decided immediately after the  to run for a Congressional seat in the greater Boston area, focusing in part on  and , but also on the wider Massachusetts economy. She challenged Rep.  of the , in an announcement she made on Twitter. Wu stated, in a radio interview, that Lynch did not sufficiently represent the , citing his positions on  and ; Lynch is a centrist on the former and supportive of the latter. Wu also came out in favor of  and . Wu feels that Massachusetts proportionally contributes more to the  than it receives in return and wants to use it as leverage in negotiations.  She hopes that the  area can rival  as a technology hub. Wu moved to the 8th district in order to challenge the incumbent Lynch.\n\nWu also cited opposition to then-president , what she perceived as failures by Congress on technology issues, and what she perceived as the failure of the Democratic Party to emotionally connect with its voters as reasons for shifting from game development to politics.\n\nProfessor Thomas Whalen of  said that, while the labor union-connected Lynch was native to 's traditionally conservative 8th district, recent years of changing demographics could help Wu. Meanwhile, David S. Bernstein, a long-time political reporter for '''', did not think Wu has a chance of unseating Lynch.\n\nOn Twitter in February 2017, Wu received media attention after she posted warnings about the , along with voicing her concerns over giving private  companies sole access to the . She wrote, \"Rocks dropped from [the Moon] have power of 100s of nuclear bombs\". She later deleted the tweets after receiving criticism.\n\nIn late October 2017, Wu used the  service  to raise awareness for her congressional campaign. This appears to be the first instance of anyone using Twitch in this manner. \"One of the reasons Millennials feel disenfranchised is politicians don't speak to them in ways that feel genuine,\" said Wu. \"Twitch is one of the most important ways to engage younger people.\" When asked, neither Twitch, the , nor the  were aware of anyone having had done so. Wu was playing '''' during the stream.\n\nWu lost to Lynch in the Democratic primary held on September 4, 2018, having received approximately 23% of the vote to Lynch's 71%.\n\n\nWu began a second campaign for the 2020 election, again with an emphasis on tech issues such as 's proposal to break up giant new media companies such as ,  and . On a  panel, Wu said, \"for whatever reason, our Department of Justice has been more reluctant to pursue  cases against companies in the last few years, certainly since the Bush years.\" She differs from certain elements of Warren's proposal, citing privacy concerns.\n\nShe endorses the , legislative goals aimed at shifting the United States to 100 percent renewable energy by 2035.\n\nIn April 2020, due to the impact of the  on her campaign, she suspended her congressional bid.\n\n\n\nIn 2008, she married , four-time winner of the .  In 2020, she and  co-founded Rebellion PAC, a  with a focus on running advertisements in opposition to Donald Trump and in support of  get-out-the-vote efforts. She is a . \n\nSince the outbreak of the , Wu received media attention for her vocal support of . She has argued in '''' that \"my fellow leftists are betraying our Jewish allies\" and \"the casual  I’d looked past in progressive spaces [are] impossible to ignore.\"\n\n\n\nIn October 2014, Wu posted multiple  about Gamergate advocates, ridiculing them for \"fighting an apocalyptic future where women are 8 percent of programmers and not 3 percent.\" While she was monitoring 's pro-Gamergate chanboard (/gg/), anonymous users posted sensitive personal information about her, including at least one post containing her address. Subsequently, Wu began receiving multiple, specific rape and death threats including her address, causing Wu to flee her home. These threats have been widely attributed to Gamergate supporters. In December, Wu said that she had received emails that contained images of mutilated dogs from people who identified as Gamergate supporters, following the recent death of her dog.\n\nAlong with  and , Wu was one of the targets of Gamergate harassment. In February 2015, she said, \"by attacking me so viciously, they're helping give me the visibility to usher in the very game industry they're terrified about.\" Wu started a legal defense fund for women targeted by Gamergate. As of late 2014, the Wu family was also offering a cash reward for information leading to the prosecution of those who sent the death threats.  By February 2015 she said she was spending a full day a week contacting law enforcement, and was only attending events in the US with a security detail. In March 2015, she said she had received 48 death threats during the previous six months. As of May 2019, she and her husband were still living under aliases.\n\nIn early 2017, the  (FBI) closed its investigation of the matter. The FBI identified four men who sent threats and obtained confessions from two of them, one of whom stated that they had sent the threat as a \"joke\" but \"understood that it was a federal crime to send a threatening communication to anyone and will never do it again\". The  for the  declined to prosecute, giving no specific reason.  Reacting to the report, Wu stated the FBI did not care about the investigation and that she was \"livid\". In the wake of the 2019 , however, she said that the FBI needs dedicated agents who understand online culture ( in particular).\n\nIn August 2021, '''' reported that \"despite the attempts to discredit her, wreck her career and destroy her sense of safety, Wu has now become a vocal proponent of forgiveness for those who apologize and show they have grown.\" However, \"insults and continued harassment\" still outnumbered apologies \"10-to-1\".\n\nWu said that she was diagnosed with  as a result of the harassment.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n*  (August 9, 2019) '''' ( by Brianna Wu on toxic  culture)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Victoria Neave Criado''' (born December 29, 1980) is an American  and politician serving as a  member of the  for  in . She unseated  incumbent Kenneth Sheets in the most expensive Texas House race of the 2016 cycle.\n\n\nNeave was named the House Democratic Caucus Freshman of the Year.  During her first session, she passed a law to allow \"Texans applying for or renewing their driver’s license the option to donate $1 or more toward rape kit testing.\" As of June 2018, the program had \"collected more than $234,956.\"\n\nNeave was arrested in June 2017 on a  charge after she crashed her BMW into a tree and repeatedly told arresting officers that \"I love you and I want to fight for you, and I invoke the Fifth Amendment.\" Neave said after her arrest that she was \"deeply sorry, and will accept the consequences of my actions, and will work to make this right.\" As a local attorney and legislator, concerns were expressed at favoritism by police, prosecutors and local media towards Neave.\n\nNeave was reelected to her second term in the  held on November 6, 2018, when she defeated the Republican candidate, Deanna Maria Metzger, 28,923 (57.1 percent) to 21,770 (42.9 percent).\n\nIn 2019, Neave passed omnibus legislation to tackle the backlog of thousands of untested rape kits in Texas called the Lavinia Masters Act, or House Bill 8, which also included $50 million from the Texas budget.  As of 2021, there was an 80% reduction in the rape kit backlog.  Neave has also \"[led] the charge at the Texas Capitol to fight these arrangements [nondisclosure agreements] through a bill that would void contractual agreements that prevent employees from notifying law enforcement or regulatory agencies about sexual harassment or sexual assault in the workplace.\"\n\nNeave was selected as one of seventeen speakers to jointly deliver the  address at the .  In 2021, Neave while only in her \"third term, was appointed to a coveted committee chair position in the Texas House\" and is only the sixth Latina in Texas History to chair a committee in the Texas House of Representatives.  She was appointed as Chair of the Texas House Committee on Juvenile Justice and Family Issues. In 2023, Victoria Neave Criado was appointed as Chair of the Texas House Committee on County Affairs.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Annissa Essaibi George''' (born December 12, 1973) is an American politician who served as an at-large member of the . First elected , she served on the council from 2016 to 2022. She was a candidate in the . She placed second in the , but was defeated in the general election by fellow city councilor . Since November 2022, Essaibi George has served as the president of the Board of Directors of the  organization  Boston.\n\nBorn and raised in Boston, Essaibi George began her career as a student services liaison at the Boston Private Industry Council. After receiving a master's in education, she later entered the field of education and worked as a  teacher at . A , Essaibi George entered electoral politics by running unsuccessfully for an  seat on the  in .  Two years later, she won election to an at-large seat in the . She was reelected to the Boston City Council in both  and . On the Boston City Council, she was regarded to be an ally of Mayor , who had been an acquaintance  of Essaibi George dating back to their childhoods. Having been first elected on a -centered platform, Essaibi George undertook work in that realm. She founded the Boston City Council's Homelessness, Mental Health, and Recovery Committee in 2016, which was later disestablished by in 2020 during the council presidency of  to the disagreement of Essaibi George. Essaibi George organized needle clean-up drives. She opposed the idea of the city establishing supervised consumption sites (in the mold of ) as a response to public safety concerns regarding drug use. Martin J. Valencia of '''' partially credited Essaibi George's advocacy as a city councilor as contributing to the city acting to supply each of the city's public schools with a full-time  and a full-time .\n\nIn January 2021, Essaibi George announced her candidacy in that year's election for mayor of Boston. Her candidacy was considered  in comparison to that of the other leading candidates. She placed second in the election's nonpartisan primary, outperforming then-acting mayor Kim Janey and other candidates including  and . She faced Michelle Wu in the general election, and was defeated by Wu by a .\n\n\nAnnissa Essaibi George was born on December 12, 1973, in Boston, Massachusetts. Her parents met while studying in . Her mother was born to  parents in a displaced persons camp in  but grew up in . Her father, Ezzeddine, was from . They relocated to the United States in 1972, settling in the  neighborhood of Boston. Essaibi George and her three siblings were raised Catholic while her father was a practicing Muslim.\n\nAfter graduating from Boston Technical High School (now the ), Essaibi George attended , a business school in Waltham, Mass., for two years, before transferring to , where she was a political science major. While in college, she interned in the , office of . After graduating from B.U., she worked as the student services liaison at the Boston Private Industry Council. She continued her education by earning a master's degree in education from the , later teaching  electives at  from 2001 to 2014.\n\n\n in 2015]]\n\nEssaibi George is affiliated with the . She first ran unsuccessfully for  in the  for  seats.\n\n\nEssaibi George became an at-large member of the Boston City Council in January 2016 after she was elected in the . She was re-elected in both  and .\n\nWhile on the City Council, Essaibi George was considered an ally of then-Mayor , whom she has known since childhood.\n\nEssaibi George chaired committees, including both the Committee on Education and the Committee on Homelessness, Mental Health, and Recovery.\n\nEssaibi George's successful 2015 campaign, which first elected her to the Boston City Council, focused on , including  counseling and services for the . In 2016, she established the council's Homelessness, Mental Health, and Recovery committee. She was critical of 's move in 2020, as city council president, to disestablish this committee. For several years, Essaibi George proposed ordinances requiring  to provide safe  disposal. An ordinance sponsored by Essaibi George that requires pharmacy chains with more than three locations in the city to do so was passed unanimously by the City Council in October 2020. Essaibi George also organized needle clean-up drives. In 2019, Essaibi George expressed her disapproval for the prospect of creating supervised consumption sites (in the mold of s) in response to drug use in the city. In 2019, Essaibi George advocated for the city to place a full-time er and a full-time  in every public school. The city, ultimately, implemented this, with Martin J. Valencia of '''' later attributing this, in part, to her advocacy on the matter. \n\nIn 2016, Essaibi George pressed the city to lessen the amount of  in city parks, expressing concern over the amount of  geese were leaving.\n\n\nEssaibi George was an early supporter of Ayanna Pressley's successful  Democratic  challenge to  U.S. Congressman . During the Democratic primary election of , Essaibi George  incumbent 's ultimately-successful reelection campaign over the candidacy of challenger .\n\nEssaibi George was involved in efforts to have the city hire additional licensed social workers to work alongside  in addressing  calls related to mental health problems and similar matters. In 2021, she voted against legislation that was passed by the City Council to restrict the use of s, , and  by the .\n\nIn early 2021, amid the , she partnered with fellow city councilor  to propose a measure that would provide paid leave to municipal employees that feel ill after receiving the vaccine.\n\nIn July 2021, amid her mayoral campaign, Essaibi George denied allegations made in an investigative article published in ''The Boston Globe'' that she had used her office to try to prevent the construction of a building that would block the views of a building owned by her husband, a real estate developer. If the allegations are true, they pose a potential violation of a state  law.\n\nIn September 2021, a resolution authored by Councilor  and co-sponsored by Essaibi George and Michelle Wu was passed by the City Council. The ordinance extends paid child leave for municipal employees to all forms of pregnancy loss, including  (as opposed to the existing law, which only covered loss of pregnancy by ), and also extends it to those welcoming a new family member or acting as a . The ordinance was signed into law by Acting Mayor  soon after.\n\n\n\n\n\n speech]]\n\nOn January 27, 2021, Essaibi George confirmed that she would run in the 2021 Boston mayoral election, considered a \"wide open\" race due to the then-expected confirmation of Mayor Walsh as ; Walsh was confirmed to his  post in March.\n\nEssaibi George was often described as a \"centrist\" or \"moderate\" candidate in comparison to the other candidates. Among her endorsers is former Boston police chief , who is also heading one of the two s that backed her candidacy in the nonpartisan primary. That super PAC received $495,000 from  owner and longtime Republican donor , who in 2016 contributed nearly $400,000 to the Trump Victory PAC. Her ties to pro- groups resulted in some of her critics characterizing her as aligned with Trump or Republicans, characterizations which Essaibi George repudiated.\n\nAs a candidate, Essaibi George touted her experience as an educator.\n\nIn the preliminary election on September 14, her campaign placed second with 22.4% of the vote, outperforming acting mayor  and several other challengers to advance to the general election with first-place winner Michelle Wu, who earned 33.4% of the vote.\n\nEssaibi George was often described as a police-friendly candidate compared to her opponents. On  and , Essaibi George supported police reform. However, she was the only one of the election's five major candidates to oppose cutting the 's budget. She expressed her belief that the city needed to increase the size of its police force. Her public safety platform also touted  as being a means to address shortcomings in the city. Essaibi George's campaign platform described gun violence as a \" issue, a  issue and a public safety issue\".\n\n of '''' described Essaibi George as promising \"more harmonious dealings\" with real estate developers than her opponents. Barry described Essaibi George's stances on development as one of the two greatest contrasts between her and her general election opponent Wu, who took stances on development and housing (such as Wu's support of  and dissolving the Boston Planning & Development Agency) that Essaibi George had criticized as strongly detrimental to development in the city. The other greatest contrast between Essaibi George and Wu, per Barry's opinion, was their aforementioned differences on whether to make cuts to police funding.\n\nPromoting herself as being a  centrist, Essaibi George criticized Wu's policy approach as \"abstract\" and \"academic\".\n\nOn September 21, Essaibi George publicly urged super PACs to refrain from involvement in the general election. Her opponent Wu, the following day, made public remarks that only urged super PACs to refrain from . Essaibi George's public demand for super PACS to avoid involvement in the election came in the aftermath of the ''Dorchester Reporter'' revealing Jim Davis' contributions to one of the super PACs supporting her candidacy.\n\nIn the general election, Essaibi George placed emphasis on the fact that she is a native Bostonian. Her opponent, Wu, was originally from . During a radio interview, Essaibi George declared her belief that it was \"relevant\" that she was a native Bostonian. After these remarks, some analysts pointed out that, per the , 57% of Bostonians were born outside of the state of . In addition, Essaibi George touted herself as having a different leadership style than her opponent, claiming that she makes herself more available to residents and community leaders. However, an early September 2021 poll had shown that more of the primary election's likely voters recalled having personally met Wu than had recalled having personally met Essaibi George.\n\nEssaibi George embarked on a \"listen and learn\" tour of various Boston neighborhoods, which she claimed would inform her \"equity, inclusion and justice agenda\". She released the resulting agenda on October 8.\n\nEssaibi George faced a  by Wu in the general election.\n\n\n]]\n\nIn 2022, Essaibi George returned to her roots of teaching, working as a  in Boston's public schools. She did so amid a shortage of substitute teachers in the city's schools. In April 2022, amid the , Essaibi George made a  trip to  to provide supplies to s near the . In October 2022, Essaibi George was appointed president and chief operating officer of  Boston by the 's board of directors. She began her tenure on November 28, 2022.\n\n\nEssaibi George is the founder and owner of a retail store in Dorchester called Stitch House, which sells yarn and fabrics and offers classes in knitting, sewing, quilting and crochet. She is married to Doug George, a real estate developer. She and her husband have four sons, including a set of .\n\n\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n*\n* | City of Boston\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He is a member of the  and represented the Fifth Suffolk District, comprising the  neighborhood of .\n\n\nCarvalho was born in . He emigrated to  when he was 15 years old. After graduating from , he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in legal studies from the  and a  from the .\n\n\nHe worked in the office of the  as an assistant district attorney from 2011 to 2013.\n\nHe won the   for the Fifth Suffolk seat on April 1, 2014, and was unopposed in the general election on April 29, winning with around 739 votes. He was sworn in May 14.\n\nIn 2018, Carvalho did not run for re-election in his seat, instead launching a campaign for the Democratic nomination for . He lost the primary to , finishing third in a field of five candidates. Carvalho ran in the  open-race for the fourth district seat on the . While he progressed from a crowded nonpartisan , he was defeated by political newcomer  by a large margin in the general election.\n\n\nIn 2006 he was a legal intern with the Immigration Law Project at South Coastal Counties Legal Services, Inc. in . From 2007 to 2010 he was a summer associate and later associate with . From 2013 to 2014, he was a field legal counsel with . From 2011 to 2014 he served on the board of directors of Teen Empowerment.\n\nSince August 2019 he has served as executive director of the Boston Human Rights Commission.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Pamela Sturdivant Stephenson''' (May 11, 1951 – June 17, 2024) was an American politician from . Stephenson was a  member of  representing the state's 90th district, which includes parts of  and  counties. On September 10, 2020, \nStephenson's daughter submitted a resignation on her behalf due to dementia.\n\nThe 90th district is 86% African American according to figures from the .\n\n\n\n\nStephenson received her undergraduate degree from  and has two master's degrees from the . She attended the Woodrow Wilson College of Law in Atlanta. Grady Health |url=https://www.gradyhealth.org/about-us/our-leadership/ |website=www.gradyhealth.org |access-date=4 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210204163320/https://www.gradyhealth.org/about-us/our-leadership/ |archive-date=4 February 2021}} There has been some debate over whether or not she graduated from law school. The registrar for the school does not show that she graduated.\n\n\nStephenson was elected to the  in 2005. She had been the  executive director of the State Health Planning agency and had served on the State Medical Education Board.  She served on the Grady Memorial Hospital Corporation Board of Directors.\n\nIn 2018, Stephenson was hired to defend Asa North, who had been accused of causing the deaths of his children after leaving them in a hot car in Carroll County, Georgia. During the trial, she was accused of being \"woefully unprepared\". She did not subpoena any witnesses and repeatedly talked on her cell phone, even during opening statements. Affidavits state that the judge asked Stephensen if she was on pills. The family of Asa North has since hired another attorney. As a result of the case, on September 20, 2019, Stephenson was suspended from the practice of law in Georgia.\n\nStephenson won her primary in June 2020, and was running unopposed for her seat. However, her daughter, acting as her guardian with power of attorney, filed a resignation with the Georgia Governor's office on September 10, 2020. Stephenson was suffering from degenerative dementia. Stephenson died on June 17, 2024, at the age of 73.

    "pages": }\n'''Ronald Joseph Mariano''' (born October 31, 1946) is an American politician currently serving as the  of the . A  from , he was first elected to the House in a December 1991 special election. He was appointed assistant majority leader in February 2009 and majority leader in January 2011 by then-speaker , who he succeeded as speaker upon DeLeo's retirement in 2020. He represents the  district.\n\n\nMariano was born and raised in Quincy, where he attended public school. He received his  from  in  and his  from the . He became a teacher and was elected to the Quincy School Committee, where he served from 1989 to 2009. He also served on the Ward 2 Democratic Committee, the  Advisory Board, and the  Board of Governors.\n\nIn January 2023, Mariano was reelected to a second term as Speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives. His priorities for the  include child care affordability, public transport reliability, and oversight of hospital . Mariano also outlined a focus on revising Massachusetts' state law to comply with the  2022 ruling in '''', which declared may-issue permitting for firearms unconstitutional, as opposed to shall-issue permits.\n\nIn October 2023, Mariano indicated that he intends to run for Speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives during the 2025-2026 legislative session.\n\n\nFrom 1997 to 2000, Mariano served as Vice Chair of the Massachusetts House of Representative's Joint Committee on Insurance, becoming Chair in 2001. In 2005, he became chair of successor Joint Committee on Financial Services. In these roles, he oversaw the 2006  and 2008 auto insurance deregulation, for which he was received the 2008 Insurance Professional of the Year Award.\n\nMariano was the 2014 recipient of the Quincy Parks Conservatory's  Award. In December 2021, Mariano received the  Excellence in City Building Award in the environment category. Mariano was the 2022 recipient of the Massachusetts Immigrant & Refugee Advocacy Coalition's Change Maker Award. In June 2023, Mariano was awarded the Legislative Champion Award by the  for supporting .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n* . .\n* . .\n*  (campaign website)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jeffrey Eugene Mullis''' (December 27, 1959) is an American politician and a former member of the . A member of the , he represented the 53rd district from 2001 to 2023 after an unsuccessful run for state senator in 1998.\n\nMullis is from .  He currently serves as executive director of the  and chairman of the Top of Georgia Economic Development. He was appointed to the Stone Mountain Memorial Association Board by Governor Kemp in 2023. He is married to Teresa Nichols and has three children.\n\nIn 2021, Mullis sponsored election reform legislation in Georgia. The bill would end no-excuse absentee voting and restrict absentee voting to those who are over 75, have a physical disability, or are out of town.  He sponsored the legislation during the COVID-19 pandemic and shortly after the 2020 elections, when Democratic candidates won one of Georgia's U.S. Senate seats as well as Georgia's electoral college votes in the presidential election.\n\n\nMullis has served in the , ,  and  .\n\n\n*  Committees\n** Rules - Chairman\n** Chairman of the Economic Development Subcommittee of Senate Appropriation\n** Appropriations - Member\n** Banking and Financial Institutions - Member\n*  es\n**  Caucus – Vice-chairman\n** Sportsman's Caucus – Co-chairman\n\n\n* 2020 Legislative Champion of the Year.     "pages": }\n\n'''Tito Jackson''' (born April 11, 1975) is an American politician who was a member of the . He represented council District 7, representing parts of the  neighborhood and parts of , . , he ran unsuccessfully for mayor of Boston against  mayor . After leaving the Boston City Council, Jackson worked in the  industry. In 2022, Boston Mayor  appointed Jackson to the city's Commission on Black Men and Boys.\n\nJackson is considered to be a political .\n\n\nJackson was born to a  who had been impregnated in a . He was  by Rosa and Herb Jackson after months in . Jackson is . His adoptive father was a  and his adoptive mother ran a home . In his activism, Jackson's father supported the election of political candidates  through s and applied pressure to construction companies in the city to employ more local workers and . Jackson's father died in 2002. Jackson has credited his adoptive parents'  politics for shaping his own progressive politics.\n\nJackson grew up in the Grove Hall  of the city. As of 2017, he was living in the same Grove Hall home that he had grown up in. The home is located in the border-area of the larger neighborhood of  and . it is not considered as one of the city's \"main\" neighborhoods. Dorchester and Roxbury are among the city's main neighborhoods (per the accounts of the city government and unofficial sources). Hence, why Jackson's residence in the Grove Hall neighborhood would also be considered to also be within either of the aforementioned \"main\" neighborhoods.Different government agencies and entities disagree as to whether Jackson's home is located in Roxbury or in Dorchester. As of 2017, the city's zoning and planning maps labeled the home as being in Roxbury, while its assessing department listed it as being in Dorchester. The  serves the Grove Hall neighborhood through its Dorchester post office, but had prior to 1967 served it through its Roxbury post office.The question of which neighborhood (Roxbury or Dorchester) Jackson lived in garnered minor attention during his 2017 mayoral campaign, as Roxbury is considered the city's most well-known African American community, while Dorchester is a more  neighborhood from which the incumbent mayor that Jackson was challenging had hailed. At the time, local leaders commented on how the boundary lines between the neighborhoods are not strictly-defined.}} Jackson has identified himself with the Roxbury neighborhood, and his city council district was centered around Roxbury.\n\nJackson attended  and later graduated from the  with a Bachelor of Arts degree in history. At university, Jackson founded a \"Black Student Union\" group which urged the university to work to diversify the makeup of its student body. Jackson was also elected the . His alma mater granted him an additional  in 2018.\n\nIn 2018, Jackson reunited with his biological mother. His biological mother is one of the subjects of the -winning book  by , which focused on .\n\n\nFrom 2004 until 2006, Jackson worked as a marketer for the drug manufacturer .\n\nIn 2007, Jackson served as the industry director for information technology in Governor ’s Executive Office of Housing and Economic Development. Later, Jackson worked as the political director of Governor Patrick's successful  reelection campaign.\n\n\n, , and ]]\n\nIn the  , Jackson ran as an  candidate. He lost in this first attempt at running for elected office by 11,676 votes.\n\nJackson ran in the  for the 7th district Boston City Council seat to succeed , who had been expelled from the City Council after a public corruption investigation by the . Jackson finished first out of seven candidates in the nonpartisan  and defeated Cornell Mills (the son of former  ) 82 percent to 16 percent in the general election.\n\nCouncillor Jackson was the Chair of the Committee on Education, and the chair of the Special Committee on the Status of Black and Latino Men and Boys. Councillor Jackson also served as vice chair of the Committee on Healthy Women, Families and Communities. In addition, he was a member of six other Committees: City, Neighborhood Services and Veteran Affairs; Homelessness, Mental Health and Recovery; Housing and Community Development, Jobs, Wages and Workforce Development; Public Safety and Criminal Justice; and together with all other Councillors, the Committee of the Whole.\n\nIn 2012, after Mayor  opted to  the City Council's first two proposals for its  map, Jackson made his own proposal amending the previously proposed map. The City Council passed Jackson's map, which was then approved by Mayor Menino.\n\nAfter the , Jackson briefly attempted to gather support to be elected the next , but found himself unable to secure pledges of support from a majority of councilors. His candidacy came after  was unable to secure pledges from a majority, and  (a -leaning councilor) had managed to secure sufficient pledges. After Jackson failed to secure enough pledges, councilor  made an unsuccessful last minute bid against Linehan. Linehan defeated Pressley 8–5 (with Jackson voting for Pressley).\n\nIn 2014, the City Council passed an ordinance by Jackson to create a commission on  men and boys. Mayor  vetoed the ordinance, arguing that such a commission would, \"duplicate and complicate efforts that my administration is already engaged in\", and that the ordinance was written in such a way that he believed it would violate the . Such a commission would eventually be formed in 2021; with the City Council passing a resolution to form a similar commission that was signed into effect by the acting mayor, , in September 2021.\n\n\n\nIn 2015, Jackson applied pressure to the non-governmental committee behind  for them to release the non-redacted copy of its original bid for the games. After the collapse of Boston's bid for the Olympics, the organization  (which had opposed the bid) endorsed Jackson and three other incumbent Boston City Council members for re-election, praising them as \"demonstrat[ing] leadership by asking tough questions\" to the leaders behind Boston's Olympic bid.\n\nJackson partnered with Suffolk County Sheriff  to organize a city council committee hearing at the South Bay House of Correction. The hearing, held in September 2015, focused on soliciting input on strategies to decrease , and was the first hearing in the history of the Boston City Council to be held in a .\n\nJackson was a prominent opponent of , which would have authorized an expansion of the number of s in the state. In August 2016, the City Council voted 11–2 to adopt a resolution by Jackson and Matt O'Malley that voiced the council's opposition to the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn January 2017 Jackson announced he would run for  in the 2017 mayoral election against the incumbent, . In launching his candidacy, Jackson positioned himself as the \"progressive\" candidate in the race, and cited issues such as  and housing as being central to his candidacy.\n\nIn the nonpartisan primary election held on September 26, 2017, Jackson received 29 percent of the votes to Walsh's 63 percent. Jackson moved onto the  on November 7, 2017. Only 14 percent of the city's voting population cast votes compared to 31 percent in the previous preliminary mayoral contest.\n\nJackson focused much of his efforts on aiming to win the city's Black vote.\n\nJackson lost the general election race with 34 percent of the votes to Walsh's 65 percent.\n\n\nFollowing his city council tenure, Jackson has been involved in ventures related to legal  sales. Jackson has served as the chief executive of Verdant Medical, a Massachusetts medical and recreational marijuana company. He has also worked as the chief executive officer of the Apex Noire marijuana company.\n\n in ]]\n\nJackson tested positive for  in March 2020, early into the \n\nIn the , Jackson endorsed the unsuccessful primary election campaign of Acting Mayor Kim Janey. After Janey was eliminated in the primary, he endorsed the successful general election campaign of .\n\nOn March 16, 2022, Jackson was one of fourteen names put forth by the Boston City Council as nominees serve on the newly-established Boston Commission on Black Men and Boys. Mayor Wu had the authority to select seven of those nominees to appoint to the commission. The commission has 21 members, seven of which are selected by the mayor after being first recommended from the Boston City Council, while the remainder are selected by the mayor independently from a pool of applicants. On May 19, 2022, Mayor Wu announced that she would appoint Jackson to the commission.\n\nIn October 2022, Jackson spoke before the Boston City Council in support of a proposal by the City Council to raise the pay of city councilors by 20%. He claimed in his remarks that after his election to the city council, he nearly lost his house to . While the amendment was passed by the council, Mayor Wu ed it. Wu supported an 11% increase, which had been the recommendation of Boston’s compensation advisory board, but opposed a 20% increase.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n*  at cityofboston.gov (March 26, 2011)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James A. \"Bubber\" Epps''' (born September 7, 1943) is an  politician. Epps is a retired paving contractor, living in . He previously served as a member of the  from the 144th District, serving from 2008 until Jan. 14, 2019. He is a member of the Republican party.\n\n\nHe was born in Bibb County and graduated from Twiggs County High School. He studied at Brewton Parker College and , gaining a Bachelor of Science in Political Science and a master's degree in Education. He spent the early years of his adult life in education working at the  and then joined his family's paving business, Epps Brothers Construction Company, Inc. where he retired in 2007.\n\nHe is married to Kathryn. They have three children, eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Epps is a lifelong member and a Deacon of Antioch Baptist Church in Dry Branch.\n\n\nEpps represented the 144th district, covering Bleckley, Twiggs and Wilkinson Counties as well as parts of Bibb, Houston, Jones and Laurens Counties, from 2009 to 2019.\n\nHe was chairman of the House Motor Vehicles Committee and secretary of the House Transportation Committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christopher Nicholas Speranzo''' (born October 24, 1972) is an American lawyer and politician from .\n\n\nHe was born on October 24, 1972, in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, and graduated from . He graduated from  with a  degree in political science and later a  degree in history from the . He later earned his  degree from  in 2001.\n\nAfter graduating from the University of Cambridge he worked for the municipal government of Pittsfield negotiating city and state projects with .\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school he served as an Assistant Attorney General in the office of the Attorney General of Massachusetts rising through the General Counsel's Office to directing the Western Division's Public Protection Unit. While serving under  he served on the  Violence Prevention Task Force and the Attorney General's Safe Neighborhood Initiative. In 2004 he was nominated to serve as the Solicitor of Pittsfield by Mayor James M. Ruberto. He would be replacing Jeffrey Honig who resigned in May 2003. He was later confirmed by the Pittsfield City Council and served in that position from January 2004 until January 2005 when he resigned to campaign for state representative.\n\nAfter he resigned in January 2005 the city solicitor position remained vacant until 2006 when Mayor Ruberto decided to privatize the city's legal services because he was unable to find someone to replace him. From 2006 until 2012 the city's legal service was operated by an attorney who worked for Freedman, DeRosa & Rondeau (now DeRosa Dohoney LLP). In 2012 Mayor Daniel L. Bianchi nominated Kathleen E. Degnan to succeed Speranzo as solicitor. She was later confirmed by the city council and sworn in as the new solicitor of the city.\n\n\nFrom January 2005 until April 2005 he campaigned and won a special election to fill the 3rd Berkshire district seat in the state house which was vacated by Peter J. Larkin. He defeated Republican challenger Terry M. Kinnas and was sworn in on April 25, 2005. He represented the 3rd Berkshire district in the  until July 13, 2011, when he resigned to accept a position that he was appointed to by Governor Deval Patrick.\n\n\nOn June 7, 2011, he was nominated by Governor  to serve as Clerk Magistrate of the Pittsfield District Court, replacing Leo F. Ryan who retired in 2009. On July 6, 2011, he was confirmed by the  in a 5–4 vote with Lieutenant Governor  casting the tie breaking vote. He was sworn in on July 13, 2011.\n\n\nHe and his wife Jenelle Dodds live in Pittsfield.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Viola Davis''' (born March 19, 1963) is an American businesswoman, nurse, and politician who has served as a member of the  from . A member of the , she defeated Democratic Party incumbent Earnest \"Coach\" Williams in November 2018.\n\n\nDavis grew up in , and in 1979 was part of the third phase of '''' after schools began to drift back to segregation following a change to open enrollment. She earned a Bachelor of Science degree in nursing from the .\n\n\nPrior to entering politics, Davis worked as a critical care nurse and community missionary. She also operated a hair salon and served in the . She received her real estate license in 1997.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
