    "pages": }\n\n'''Alyson Kennedy''' (born June 11, 1950) is an American activist and member of the  (SWP). A , she was a candidate in the . She was the SWP's nominee for  in the ,  in the  as well as their nominee for president in .\n\n\n\n\nOriginally from , Kennedy joined the socialist movement in 1973 in . She has worked in s in Alabama, Colorado, Utah, and West Virginia. Today she works at a  in .\n\nIn 1977 she ran as the SWP candidate for mayor of ,  against incumbent Republican , garnering 1,225 votes and losing by a wide margin to . She first joined the  (UMWA) in 1981, and was one of the leaders of a strike in  2004, also being involved in litigation. In  as a certified . She and one other certified write-in candidate combined for 13 votes (out of nearly 2.4 million votes cast).\n\nIn 1984, she was chosen by the Socialist Workers' Party to be a presidential elector from .\n\n\nAs the vice-presidential nominee of two parties, Kennedy ran a campaign focused on the youth. There were two different candidates at the head of the ticket,  and ; Harris was an alternate in some states because Calero was constitutionally ineligible because he is a  of the United States (holding a ), and not a US citizen. They were the first pair to qualify for the ballot in   Calero/Kennedy won 5,127 votes and Harris/Kennedy 2,424.\n\n\nOn February 12, 2016, Kennedy was announced as the  on the Socialist Workers Party ticket alongside . Kennedy is the second woman to be the presidential nominee of the SWP, following .  She was on the ballot in eight states: Utah, Louisiana, Colorado, Maine, Minnesota, Tennessee, Washington and New Jersey. The ticket received 11,743 out of almost 137 million votes cast.\n\n\nIn January 2019, Kennedy declared her candidacy in the , advocating for the improvement of the , a public jobs program to provide \"union-scale wages\", and for the  to address claims of police brutality, pointing to the  as an example of such claims. She received 469 votes (0.58% of the vote) which placed her last among the candidates running.\n\n\nIn February 2020, Kennedy was announced as her party's nominee for president. Her vice-presidential nominee is , an African-American activist and cook from , . The two kicked off their campaign with speeches at campaign headquarters in  on February 8. The ticket received 6,791 votes, out of 158 million votes cast.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \"\", ''The Militant'', January 14, 2008 (accessed February 15, 2008).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Garland Turk Byrd''' (July 16, 1924 – June 1, 1997) was United States  politician from , who served as the  from 1959 to 1963, and as Senator from the 17th District in 1963-4.\n\nHe was born in  in  in west central Georgia. Byrd graduated in 1941 from . During  he served in the  from October 1942 to October 1945 in engineer combat units. He fought in , Northern , Germany and . He was discharged at the rank of .\n\nByrd attended  at  from 1946 to 1948, where he was a member of , and earned  degree from  in 1948.\n\nA lifelong farmer and real estate businessman, he served as a member of the  from 1947 to 1949 from Taylor County. He resigned from the legislature to become director and then assistant director of the state's Veterans Service Department from 1949 to 1952.\n\nElected Lieutenant Governor in 1958 he served this post from January 13, 1959, to January 15, 1963, under fellow Democrat,  \n\nAfter he left the lieutenant governor's position, Byrd was Democratic nominee for U.S. Representative from  in 1964. However, he lost to  nominee (and 1966 gubernatorial standard-bearer nominee) . Byrd hence was the first Georgia Democrat to lose to a Republican congressional candidate since the .\n\nIn 1966, Byrd ran as a  in the Democratic primary for governor to succeed the term-limited Carl Sanders but finished in a distant fifth place. In the heated , Byrd endorsed former Governor , considered  the  candidate, who was defeated for the nomination by  of , a segregationist who had closed his Pickrick Restaurant in 1964 to avoid serving African American customers. Maddox termed Byrd's support of Arnall \"a sellout.\" The state legislature then elected Maddox over the Republican Howard Callaway when neither candidate obtained an outright majority of the vote in the general election, as was then required by the Georgia State Constitution.\n\nByrd was a . He was married to the former Gloria Elizabeth Whatley (born September 22, 1925). Byrd is interred at Hillcrest Cemetery in his native Reynolds, Georgia.\n\n\n\n'''Georgia's 3rd congressional district, 1964 (Democratic primary)'''\n*Garland T.     "pages": }\n|death_place  = , U.S.\n|restingplace = \n|party        = \n|education    =  (, )\n|allegiance   = United States\n|branch       = United States Army\n|serviceyears = 1942–1946\n|rank         = Second Lieutenant\n|battles      = \n}}\n'''Frank Bradford Morse''' (August 7, 1921 – December 18, 1994) was a member of the  from . He had a notable career in the  and the . In Congress, he served in various capacities for nearly twenty years, the last twelve as Congressman from . In 1972, he became  and in 1976, the Administrator of the . He received a   for his career as an international public servant.\n\n\nMorse was born in  on August 7, 1921, and graduated from  in 1948 and from  in 1949. He served in World War II in the  from 1942-1946 and was discharged as a second lieutenant. After the war, he served as a private practice lawyer, business executive, law clerk to the Chief Justice of the , and professor at Boston University School of Law, 1949-1953. He was elected to the  in 1952 and served there until 1953 when he was employed as a staff member for , a position he held until 1955. From 1955 until 1958 he served as an executive secretary and chief assistant to United States Senator , and later as a deputy administrator of  from 1958-1960.\n\nDuring his time in the House, Morse supported the , the , the , the  program for the elderly, the , and alongside fellow House Republicans ,  and , co-sponsored the Health Security Act, a bipartisan health care bill that would have established a government-run health insurance program to cover every person in America.\n\nAfter the death of  in September 1960, he was selected by the  to take her place on the ballot and was elected as a Republican to the  in November 1960. He was then re-elected to the five succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1961- May 1, 1972.  In 1966, along with three Republican Senators and four other Republican Representatives, Morse signed a telegram sent to Georgia Governor  regarding the Georgia legislature's refusal to seat the recently elected  in their state House of Representatives. This refusal, said the telegram, was \"a dangerous attack on representative government. None of us agree with Mr. Bond's views on the Vietnam War; in fact, we strongly repudiate these views. But unless otherwise determined by a court of law, which the Georgia Legislature is not, he is entitled to express them.\"\n\nHe became Under Secretary General for Political and General Assembly Affairs at the  from 1972-1976. He was then promoted to be the third Administrator of the  from 1976-1986.  From 1986-1991, he served as the seventh president of the , a  based in , Austria whose mission is to challenge current and future leaders to develop creative ideas for solving global problems.  He died at his home in  on December 18, 1994, and was cremated and placed in  in .\n\n\n\n Retrieved on 2009-05-18\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n\n'''Lindsay Sabadosa''' is an American activist and politician. She is the first woman to hold the  seat in the .\n\n\nLindsay Sabadosa has a doctorate in Law and Policy from , an MSc from the , and an AB from . \n\nA native of Massachusetts, Sabadosa spent time abroad, studying at the  and the . Upon completion of her AB, she was the recipient of the Wellesley-Yenching Program Fellowship, which led her to spend a year in  as a fellow at  at . She later moved to Italy where she worked in marketing and communications at , a company in .\n\nFluent in French and Italian, she opened her own small business in 2004, a translation firm, specializing in legal and financial translation with a focus on international litigation, contract law, and finance. She moved to Edinburgh to complete a MSc at the  in translation, writing her dissertation on the markers of creativity in the Italian translations of Emily Dickinson's poetry while continuing to work full-time.\n\n\n\nSabadosa organized her first protest march at the age of nine to protest the closing of her hometown library due to budget cuts. She quickly became involved in political campaigns starting in high school, volunteering on campaigns for former Congressman , former Senator , and several local officials. She soon began to focus her electoral work on women candidates, working for both local and state-wide women candidates, and ultimately joining the Board of Directors of Emerge Massachusetts in order to deepen and expand her interest in building benches.\n\nPrior to her election, she volunteered with the  Advocacy Fund of Massachusetts as well as being on the Board and Intake team of the Abortion Rights Fund of Western Massachusetts. She was also a founding board member of DARLA, the Doula Association for Reproductive Loss and Abortion, which brought abortion and reproductive loss doula training to the Pioneer Valley. She sat on the statewide organizing committees for  and helped found the Western Massachusetts Safe Communities Act coalition. She was a member of the Northampton Democratic City Committee and represented her ward at the Democratic State Convention.\n\nSabadosa was first elected to the State House of Representatives in 2018, becoming the first woman to represent the . In 2020, 2022, and 2024, she was re-elected in an uncontested race.\n\nIn the 2020 Presidential Election, Sabadosa was a Massachusetts Co-Chair for the  campaign.\n\n\nIn 2023-2024, Sabadosa was the Vice Chair of the Joint Committee on Municipalities and Regional Government. She also serves on the Joint Committee on Health Care Financing and the Joint Committee on Transportation. She has previously served on the Joint Committee on Cannabis and the Joint Committee on Election Laws in prior terms. \n\nSabadosa is a long-standing member of the Massachusetts Caucus of Women Legislators and served as an at-large board member in 2023-2024. She is also a member of the Criminal Justice Reform Caucus, Progressive Caucus, the Trails Caucus, and the Regional Transit Authority Caucus. Along with Senator , she founded the first state-level Medicare for All Caucus in 2019, which they co-chair. \n\n\nIn the 2019-2000 legislative cycle, Sabadosa passed legislation with Representative  and Senator  to reexamine the Commonwealth's flag and seal, legislation that had been filed for nearly twenty years before its passage. \n\nShe quickly focused on reproductive health care and maternal health, passing over the next two terms legislation to require medication abortion readiness on public college campuses (in partnership with Senator Jason Lewis, to raise awareness about pregnancy loss, to designate pregnancy loss as a qualifying event to take earned sick time (in partnership with Senator , to codify MassHealth coverage of doula care (in partnership with Senator , and various provisions of her Full Spectrum Pregnancy Coverage legislation, which removed deductibles and copays for abortion care in Massachusetts and made full spectrum pregnancy care fully covered, without cost-sharing, by MassHealth (in partnership with Representative  and Senator . She also worked with Representative  and Senator  to pass legislation allowing pharmacists to prescribe hormonal contraception, which was implemented in the Commonwealth in 2024.  \n\nA long-time supporter of rail trails, Sabadosa also passed legislation, in partnership with Representative  and Senator , to allow Community Preservation Act dollars to be used to purchase defunct rail lines, helping to spur the creation of more greenways. \n\nSabadosa's legislative priorities span the gambit from bills to support solar installation on disturbed lands to criminal justice reform to workers' rights legislation to Medicare for All.\n\n\n\nIn 2016, Sabadosa joined the Massachusetts Chapter of the  mere days after the November election, organizing contingents travelling to Washington DC and Boston as well as a local march in Northampton. In February 2017, she created the Pioneer Valley Women's March (PVWM), which organized dozens of community events on a variety of social justice issues with particular focus on involving the community in state-level advocacy. In January 2018, PVWM held its anniversary march in Northampton with over 5,000 participants, the largest march ever held in the city.  PVWM later joined the Pioneer Valley Resist Coalition, a group of over 30 grassroots activist and advocacy organizations that focus on social and .\n\n\nIn 2024, Sabadosa completed her  at , writing her doctorial thesis on Abortion and Bias within the Supreme Court. As part of her research, she created the Sabadosa Supreme Court Repository. The repository includes analysis of all abortion-related cases heard by the  from 1965-present, coding them based on seven constitutional issues (due process, privacy, free speech, states' rights, fetal personhood, equal protection, and stare decisis). The repository is publicly available.  \n\n\nSabadosa lives in Northampton with her daughter.  \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n}}\n'''Colin Zachary Allred''' (born April 15, 1983) is an American politician,  lawyer, and former professional  player serving as the  from  since 2019. The district includes the northeastern corner of , as well as many of its northeastern suburbs, such as , , , , and the . \n\nBefore entering politics, Allred was a  who played for the  of the  (NFL) for four seasons. He was released after 4 years and no other team signed him so he left football to pursue a degree in law, receiving his  from the , followed by positions in the , first at the  and later at the . A member of the , Allred defeated 11-term incumbent  in the .\n\nAllred challenged Republican incumbent  in the . He was defeated by Cruz in the general election. He was seen as one of the only Democratic senatorial candidates who could plausibly defeat a Republican incumbent that cycle. Not having ran for re-election as a U.S. representative, he will be succeeded by .\n\n\nAllred was born in , Texas. He was raised by a single mother who was a  teacher. A fourth-generation Texan, Allred attended  in Dallas, where he played baseball, basketball and football, and served as .  He earned a scholarship to play  at .\n\nIn 2001, Allred began to play for the  as a  under head coach . In 2005, he was selected as the  and defensive . In December 2005, Allred graduated from Baylor with a Bachelor of Arts in history. As a senior, he received  honorable mention from the . He was also selected as a first-team Academic All-Big 12 in 2004 and 2005.\n\n\n\n\n\nAllred was signed by the  as an  following the  on May 4, 2006. He was waived on August 29 but re-signed on January 26, 2007. Allred was waived again on September 1 during final cuts and signed to the  on September 2. \n\nHe was promoted to the active roster as  on December 15 and made his NFL regular season debut on December 16, 2007. In four seasons for the Titans between 2007 and 2010, Allred appeared in 32 games and recorded 46 tackles.\n\nOn October 10, 2010, during a Titans game with the , he was severely injured in the neck during a game when he collided with Cowboys player . He subsequently decided to retire from football and go to law school, and he became a free agent before the 2011 season without signing with another team.\n\n\n\nIn 2011, Allred enrolled at the . He worked as a  for professor and author  and graduated in 2014 with a  degree.\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Allred worked for  as its  Regional Director of Voter Protection, overseeing the state's first coordinated voter protection program. His responsibilities included overseeing the  efforts of hundreds of volunteers and managing a comprehensive  program that helped thousands of North Texans vote. In 2016, he worked as a special assistant in the 's Office of General Counsel alongside then-Secretary  in the Obama administration.\n\nSubsequently, Allred worked as a civil rights attorney at the law firm , where he was a  litigator and counsel to clients including national and state political candidates and advocacy organizations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n for |upright]]\nOn April 21, 2017, Allred announced his campaign to challenge incumbent   in 2018. In a crowded Democratic primary that included two other  administration alums, Allred finished first, by 20 points, but did not get 50% of the vote. In the May 22 , Allred defeated  businesswoman , receiving 69.5% of the vote.\n\nAllred faced Sessions in the general election. As of November 2016, this was considered a  district because Democratic presidential candidate  received marginally more votes than  even as Sessions was reelected with no major-party opposition. Allred described himself as a moderate Democrat. U.S. Representative  rallied in support of Allred in October.\n\nOn November 6, 2018, Allred was elected to the House of Representatives for the . His victory was considered an upset because Sessions had been in Congress since 1997 and represented the 32nd district since its creation in 2003. Allred became the second person to represent this district and the first Democrat. Sessions had represented the neighboring , and transferred to the 32nd after the 5th was seemingly made less Republican in redistricting. As a measure of how Republican this area had been, much of what is now the 32nd had not been represented by a Democrat since 1968, when it was part of the neighboring . Allred was one of two former NFL players to win a seat in Congress that year, along with .\n\n\n in  and pushes for the bipartisan  bill in 2023.]]\nAllred was elected co-president of the Democratic freshmen of the , alongside fellow Obama administration alumna . \n\nHe endorsed his former boss and fellow Texan, former  , in the . After Castro withdrew from the race, he endorsed .\n\nAllred voted for the two  in his first impeachment in 2019. He also voted to impeach him during his  in 2021 following the .\n\nDuring his tenure, Allred has worked with Senator  on the . He also initiated efforts to establish the  , and was instrumental in the bipartisan passage of legislation for new veterans' facilities, including a  in  and a spinal cord injury center in  in 2022. Additionally, he supported the , which secured funds for infrastructure upgrades at the  Port Ship Channel and improved various transportation networks in Texas.  He also sought $241 million in  for his district, for projects largely at  in 2021.\n\n\n asks questions at a hearing on the  in 2022.]]\n* \n** \n* \n** \n** \n** \n* \n** \n\n\n\n* \n* \n* Bipartisan Paid Leave Working Group Representative Colin Allred |url=https://allred.house.gov/about/committees-and-caucuses |access-date=September 23, 2024 |website=allred.house.gov |language=en |archive-date=December 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231217213954/https://allred.house.gov/about/committees-and-caucuses |url-status=live}}\n* Supply Chain Caucus; Co-chair\n* Future Forum; Co-chair of Communications\n\n\n\nOn May 3, 2023, Allred announced his candidacy for the  in , challenging Republican incumbent . In March 2024, he won the primary nomination for the Democratic Party. \n\nAllred's endorsements include the , , and .\n\nIn September 2024,  endorsed him. The Common Ground Committee, an organization dedicated to reducing political polarization and promoting civility, recognized Allred as the most bipartisan member of Congress from Texas.\n\nOn November 5th, 2024 Allred lost to incumbent Ted Cruz by 8.6 points in the election. \n\n\n to discuss the  bill in 2022]]\nThe , which often backs Republican candidates, endorsed Allred, a Democrat, in the 2022 House election, citing his support for \"free enterprise and the American business community.\" Similarly, the  union group has noted that Allred has consistently voted in favor of unions, with a 100% voting record since taking office. \n\nOver 70% of the bills he has cosponsored have had bipartisan support.\n\n\nAllred opposes the , and supports the restoration of '''' through codification.\n\n\nAllred emphasized the importance of , and criticized others for spreading . In 2021, he stated that, while supportive of the economic stimulus proposed at the time, vaccination was the most important step people could take, noting that \"[n]o amount of aid of any kind is going to allow us to outspend this virus.\" He has also opposed overriding the  and  rules around requiring health care workers to be vaccinated.\n\n\n back to the United States, 2023.]]\n\n\nAllred voted in December 2023 to provide Israel with support following the . He voted two months later in favor of House Resolution 894 condemning  as .\n\n\nAllred voted in 2023 against H.Con.Res. 21 which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\n\n\nIn the wake of the , Allred stated that he supports \"common-sense actions like s and s to ensure dangerous individuals don't have these deadly weapons.\" In 2022, after the , he voted for the ; this law incentivized states to pass  and significantly narrowed the so-called , which had allowed  partners to obtain guns so long as they were not married to the survivor of the abuse. He has also supported a .\n\n\n in 2024.]]\nAllred has stated that he wishes to take a \"pragmatic approach to reforming our broken immigration system\", emphasizing the need to \"secure our border and our ports of entry\" using recent technologies. In 2019, he opposed deploying troops along the southern border. In January 2024, Allred was one of only 14 Democrats who voted for a resolution to \"denounce the Biden administration's open-borders policies\".\n\n\nAllred defended his support for  in 2024, focusing on the need for protections against discrimination based on sexual identity. He highlighted that Texans largely value personal freedom, saying, “In the Texas that I believe in and that I grew up in, we mostly want to leave folks alone.\" Allred emphasized that his goal is to extend existing protections for race, gender, and national origin to include sexual identity.\n\n\nAllred led a group of House Democrats in 2021 in sending a letter to their Senate colleagues urging them to pass the \"Freedom to Vote Act\". A year later, he was a lead cosponsor for the Sustaining Our Democracy Act which would upgrade voting equipment, improve , expand early voting, and hire and train poll workers.\n\n\nAllred married Alexandra Eber on March 25, 2017. They have two sons, born in 2019 and 2021. Allred is related to former  .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n*  official U.S. House website\n*  campaign website \n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n()|years=}}\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David Matos Simas''' (born January 5, 1970) is an  lawyer, former government official, and a former politician. He was the President of the  from 2021 to 2023, having previously served as its CEO from 2016 to 2021\n* Also available at:  and served in  as the  from 2014 to 2016.\n\n\nSimas was born and raised in , the son of  immigrant parents, António and Deolinda Simas. Deolinda lost two of her fingers in a faulty machine at the silver factory where she worked when David was a child. The Portuguese immigrant lawyer who worked on the case inspired David to become a lawyer. He attended  and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from . He later earned a  from the  in 1995.\n\n\nSimas began his political career working as an intern in Senator 's office in 1989. He was later elected to the Taunton School Board in 1993 and the Taunton City Council in 1997 and 1999. He later served as president of the council and worked as an advisor to the mayor of Taunton.\n\nAfter leaving the city council he served as an assistant register of deeds for the Northern district office of the  Registry of Deeds. He was later elected as the new Register of Deeds of the Northern district of Bristol County in 2004. He won reelection in 2006 but later resigned to accept a position in Governor Deval Patrick's administration.\n\nHe formerly served as deputy general counsel to the  Post Audit and Oversight Bureau and practiced law with the law firm of Gay & Gay Associates, PC.\n\nHe worked as deputy chief of staff to   from 2007 until 2009. In 2009, he joined the Obama  as a deputy assistant to the president, working under Senior Advisor .  \n\nHe worked as director of opinion research for President Obama's  and then served as a liaison between the president and Democratic officials for two and a half years.\n\nSimas was appointed CEO of the Obama Foundation in December 2016.\n\n\nSimas married his high school sweetheart, Shauna. They have two daughters and live in  in Chicago.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n|-\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robin Wonsley'''  (born 1991) is an American activist and politician affiliated with the  who has been a member of the  from the 2nd Ward since 2021.\n\n\nWonsley was born in  in 1991 and grew up on the . She attended  as a  Scholar and graduated in 2013 with a B.A. in Women’s and Gender Studies. After graduation, she was awarded a  that supported her travel to Canada, Australia, South Africa and Ireland, where she studied criminal justice policies and practices. She moved to Minneapolis in 2014 and became the program coordinator for the  Women's Center and a board member for Restorative Justice Community Action.\n\nShe completed a mini MBA in Nonprofit Management from St. Thomas University in 2015 and began a Ph.D. program at the University of Minnesota in 2018. During her Ph.D. program, she conducted research on housing and racial disparities in the Gender, Women, and Sexuality Studies Department.\n\n\nAfter the 2015  by police officers in Minneapolis, she became politically active over the next several years, including in the  movement and  organizing efforts to raise the minimum wage in the city. She joined the Twin Cities chapter of  in March 2020. In the summer of 2020, she participated in the . She also became an organizer in the  movement, an effort to reallocate some community resources towards crime prevention services and programs.\n\n\n\nIn 2021, she became the first Black  to win a seat on the  after she defeated 14 year incumbent , a member of the . The election also became the first time Minneapolis elected a majority of people of color to the city council.\n\nWonsley represents the 2nd Ward, which includes the neighborhoods of , , , , , , and the . After the election, she identified housing as a major issue for the ward, and  as one of her policy priorities. She also advocated for the development of policy to address  and the needs of encampment residents and joined four other councilmembers in supporting the development of a rent control policy. In January 2022, she called for a stop to evictions from homeless encampments, and was joined at a protest against eviction at the Near North homeless encampment by councilmembers , , , and .\n\nAs of January 2024, Wonsley serves as the chair of the Administration & Enterprise Oversight Committee and the vice-chair of the Public Health & Safety Committee.\n\n\nShe resides in the  neighborhood of .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Grace Holmes Carlson''' (November 13, 1906 – July 7, 1992) was an American  politician.\n\n\n\nGrace Holmes Carlson was born on November 13, 1906, in , and studied in local Catholic schools. \n\n\n\nCarlson was a professor of psychology at the . In 1940, Carlson was the Socialist Workers Party candidate for  in Minnesota, receiving almost 9,000 votes. In 1941, as a leading member of the  she was imprisoned under the  together with  and many other SWP leaders for opposing the US involvement in . After her 16-month prison sentence, she became an activist for better conditions for women prisoners.\n\nIn 1948, Carlson ran as the Socialist Workers Party vice presidential candidate in  with Dobbs as presidential candidate.  In 1950, she ran again as a U.S. House of Representatives candidate for Minnesota's 5th district 1950.\n\nIn 1952, Carlson left the SWP, citing conflict with her  beliefs. , the central leader of the SWP famously penned the article \"How We Won Grace Carlson and How We Lost Her\" following her resignation; it focused on the extreme right-wing pressures of the McCarthy period as the material basis for Carlson's departure.\n\n\n\nGrace Carlson died age 85 on July 7, 1992.\n\n\n\n*  \n*  \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Marvin Rashad Pendarvis''' (born October 13, 1989) is an American politician who represented the 113th District (parts of ) in the  from 2017 to 2024. He is a member of the .\n\n\nPendarvis attended Garrett Academy for Technology, a high school in , where he was a  on the football team. He graduated in 2011 from the  with an undergraduate degree in political science, and in 2014 with a J.D. from the University's School of Law. He was a member of the  fraternity. Pendarvis served on the North Charleston Board of Zoning Appeals from 2016-2017.  \n\nPendarvis worked as an attorney in  for Pendarvis Law, LLC,   as the attorney for the  town of , and as a member of the legal team for the Charleston-based Racial Justice Network. He also had a backlog contract with the Ninth Circuit Public Defender's Office, which ended in 2022. \n\n\n'''2017'''\n\nWhen long-time Democratic state legislator  resigned in August 2017 to become a  in , Pendarvis became a candidate for his seat in District 113. He ran against Angela M. Hanyak and Chris Collins in the Democratic primary. Pendarvis won with 79.9% of the vote. In the general election, he defeated Republican Theron Sandy II of  to win by 1,118 votes.\n\n'''2018'''\n\nPendarvis was unopposed in the Democratic primary and general election.\n\n'''2020'''\n\nPendarvis won his primary on June 9, 2020, and was unopposed in the general election on November 3. In June 2020, he hired his only major staffer,  communications director, Jackson Hamilton. Pendarvis introduced legislation to reduce the high rate of evictions in South Carolina, working with advocacy groups on the issue.  \n\n'''2023'''\n\nAfter the announcement that North Charleston Mayor Keith Sumney would not run for re-election, Pendarvis declined to run for the seat, expressing his decision to remain in the House of Representatives.\n\n'''2024'''\n\nPendarvis filed unopposed for re-election for the seat he occupied at the time.\n\nPendarvis resigned his seat on September 16, 2024. Because information did not come in time to remove Pendarvis' name from the ballot, a special election has been scheduled for March 25, 2025.    \n\nCharleston County School Board member Courtney Waters has announced her intention to run for the seat.\n\n\n*Medical, Military, Public and Municipal Affairs Committee\n*Legislative Oversight\n\n\n\n\n\nOn May 17, 2024, Chief Justice  of the  released a decision to temporarily suspend Pendarvis' license to practice law, in connection with a lawsuit filed against him alleging legal malpractice and forgery.   After the lawsuit was filed April 11, 2024,  First Circuit Solicitor  requested an investigation by the  (SLED). SLED confirmed the following day that it had begun an investigation into the matter.  \n\nOn September 16, 2024, in a letter to House Speaker , Pendarvis resigned his seat, effective immediately.   \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Harold Columbus \"Hal\" Suit''' (April 1, 1922 – November 20, 1994) was an American local television news personality and political figure who won the 1970  nomination for  but lost the November  to future  .\n\nA native of , and styling himself as a \"\", Suit had  ancestry, as both his parents were born in .  A 19-year-old college student in 1941 at the time of the ese , he studied history and political science at the  at ,  and later studied at  in . During the remaining years of , he served in the , was twice wounded and decorated for valor with a Silver Star, and two Bronze Stars. He lost a leg in the war on October 11, 1944, in Germany.\n\nUpon leaving the military, he became, in 1947, a radio news announcer. In 1954, he moved to , where he was part of the founding staff of the city's first, and sole  television station, , which began broadcasting on April 7, 1954. After five years, Suit moved to  in , the state's first television station, which first went on the air in September 1948. Gaining recognition in a major  as a top local , political editorialist and news executive, he received the 1967 National Headliner Award. During that period, WSB-TV was affiliated with NBC, and Suit became known to a national audience by doing frequent reports from the South for the network's news broadcasts.\n\nIn 1970, Suit was named his state's most outstanding citizen by . That year, according to '''', his picture was identified by 91 percent of registered voters who watched WSB, the station described as \"the most powerful and influential in Georgia\".\n\nIn 1970, Suit, an opponent of , was an upset winner in the Republican gubernatorial primary over the Democrat-turned-Republican state Comptroller General , who carried the backing of the 1966 nominee, former   but had backed Callaway's opponent, Democrat  in the previous deadlocked contest. In a measure of just how little infrastructure existed in the Georgia Republican Party at the time, 107,555 votes were cast in the first-ever Republican gubernatorial primary held in Georgia, but the Democratic turnout surpassed 798,000. Additionally, fewer than a hundred Republican ballots were cast in ninety-nine counties, and fewer than ten votes were tabulated in eight other counties. The Republican vote came mostly in urban areas favorable to Suit but at the expense of Bentley. Four years later in 1974, the Georgia Republican primary turnout barely exceeded 22,000.\n\nSuit subsequently lost the general election to Carter, 424,983 (40.6 percent) to 620,419 (59.3 percent).\n\nThereafter, Suit became president of the Atlanta-based communications company, Production 70's, through which he continued to deliver opinion pieces on radio and in newspapers.  In 1972, Suit announced that he would run again for governor in 1974. However, he did not get the nomination.\n\nHal Suit and his wife were longtime residents of the Atlanta suburb of , where they reared four children. He died there at the age of seventy-two.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Richard J. Ross''' (born July 6, 1954) is a former  for the former  district, which included parts of , , , and , and all of , Ross's home town of , , , , , , and . He is a , and served as the Senate .\n\n\nRoss grew up in Wrentham, Massachusetts. He attended . After the sudden death of his father, Ross returned to Massachusetts and assumed the family business, R. R. Ross Funeral Home, in Wrentham. Ross attended the  of Anatomy, Science & Embalming, and graduated with highest honor in 1975.  Prior to serving in the Massachusetts legislature, he served on the Wrentham Board of Health and the Wrentham Board of Selectmen. He still resides in Wrentham, where he is the owner of R. J. Ross Funeral Home.\n\n\nRoss has served in the state senate since May 2010, when he won a special election to succeed . This was the third time Ross was elected to a political office to succeed Brown. From 2005 to 2010, Ross was a member of the  for the 9th Norfolk district.\n\nIn the  of , Ross was defeated by Democratic challenger  by approximately a two percent margin.\n\n\nIn 2013, state senator Ross filed S787, which would restrict the dating and sex lives of people going through a divorce if they have children:\n\nIn divorce, separation, or 209A proceedings involving children and a marital home, the party remaining in the home shall not conduct a dating or sexual relationship within the home until a divorce is final and all financial and custody issues are resolved, unless the express permission is granted by the courts.\n\nIn Massachusetts, divorces are not finalized until 120 days after the final paperwork is signed.  On March 24, 2014, Ross defended his submission of the bill in a  post, \"This was a free petition that I filed at the request of a constituent. I am not the sponsor of this legislation, nor have I ever endorsed or spoken in favor of it.\" The Massachusetts Executive Office of Administration and Finance defines a 'free petition' as: \"In Massachusetts all citizens have the right to petition the state legislature. This procedure is called the right of free petition. A citizen drafts and files a Petition and accompanying Bill. A legislator sponsors the Bill in the General Court. If a legislator disagrees with the contents of the Bill, he/she may indicate this by placing the phrase 'By request' after his/her name.\" The text of S787 specifies that it was filed by \"Richard J. Ross, (BY REQUEST)\".\n\n\n•Joint Committee on Rules\n\n•Joint Committee on Economic Development and Emerging Technologies\n\n•Joint Committee on Education\n\n•Joint Committee on Higher Education\n\n•Joint Committee on the Judiciary\n\n•Joint Committee on Mental Health and Substance Abuse\n\n•Joint Committee on Municipalities and Regional Government\n\n•Joint Committee on Public Safety and Homeland Security\n\n•Joint Committee on Ways and Means\n\n•Senate Committee on Ethics and Rules\n\n•Senate Committee on Ways and Means\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| birth_place         = , U.S.\n| party               = \n| spouse              = Andrew Evans\n| children            = 2\n| education           =  (, )\n| residence           = , , U.S.\n| website             = \n}}\n\n'''Stacey Godfrey Evans''' (born May 5, 1978) is an American politician and  for District 57 starting in 2021. She received 56.8% of the primary vote, and was uncontested in the general election. A member of the , she was the  for District 42 from 2011 to 2014. She was succeeded by .\n\nEvans was reelected three times in District 42, most recently receiving 73.25% of the vote in 2016. She resigned her legislative seat to focus on her bid for the ; she finished second in the Democratic primary. In addition to serving in the legislature, Evans also founded her own law firm, S.G. Evans Law, LLC.\n\n\n\nEvans has received numerous awards for her legislative advocacy, including two Arnie awards, the \"Super Woman Award\" in 2012; and the \"Teach Your Children and Colleagues Award\" in 2013.\n\nRepresentative Evans opposed the 20-week abortion ban during the 2012 legislative session. She was 9 months pregnant during the vote, which was scheduled for the day she was to be induced into labor. She spoke out against the bill in a video statement played on the House floor hours before she gave birth. This was one of the first times that a video statement was allowed on the Georgia House floor.\n\nShe served on the Judiciary Committee in the Georgia House. In 2015, Evans helped stop Josh McKoon's religious liberty bill from becoming law. She fought to include civil rights protections in the bill and then joined with the majority of her colleagues on the House Judiciary committee in voting to table the legislation. She was commended for her work by Georgia Equality.\n\n\n\nIn the legislature, she quickly became known as a fighter for HOPE. She opposed the changes pushed by Governor  and Georgia legislative leaders that, Evans claimed, would push many Georgians off of the scholarship and out of school.\n\nThe  program began by promising that all those who graduated from Georgia high schools with a B average would be able to go to college with the cost paid for by taxpayers.\n\nDespite the opposition of Evans, a proposal was made to limit the full scholarship only to those who achieved a 3.7 GPA and 1200 on the SAT. Evans responded by claiming that this would prevent many of the students who most needed the help from attending college at all and said in remarks to the House chamber that had these limitations been in place when she graduated from college she wouldn't be standing there that day. \n\nIn the end, the proposal to limit the scholarship was successful.\n\n\n\nRepresentative Evans ran for  in the 2018 Democratic primary election. She lost  in the primary election to former state representative and House Minority Leader .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Donald F. Humason Jr.''' (born July 31, 1967) is an American politician who served as  of  from 2020 to 2022 and current  of , beginning September 6, 2022. A member of the , he previously represented the  in the  from 2013 to 2020, and as representative for the 4th Hampden District in the  between 2003 and 2013.\n\n\n\nIn his first bid for public office, Humason was elected on November 5, 2002 with 63% of the vote and was re-elected in 2004, 2006, 2008, 2010, and 2012. He resigned on November 20, 2013 after he was elected to the State Senate.\n\nHumason's committee assignments were as follows.\n\n;186th General Court (2009–2011)\n* Joint Committee on Consumer Protection and Professional Licensure\n* Joint Committee on Higher Education\n* Joint Committee on Public Health\n* Joint Committee on Transportation\n* Joint Committee on Economic Development and Emerging Technologies\n;187th General Court (2011–2013)\n* Joint Committee on Consumer Protection and Professional Licensure\n* Joint Committee on Rules\n* Committee on Rules\n;188th General Court (2013–2015)\n* Joint Committee on Consumer Protection and Professional Licensure\n* Joint Committee on Economic Development and Emerging Technologies\n;189th General Court (2015–2017)\n* Joint Committee on Children, Families and Persons with Disabilities\n* Joint Committee on Public Service\n* Joint Committee on Veterans and Federal Affairs\n* Joint Committee on Ways and Means\n* Committee on Intergovernmental Affairs\n* Committee on Bonding, Capital Expenditures and State Assets\n* Committee on Ways and Means\n* Special Committee to Improve Government\n\n\nOn August 9, 2013, incumbent State Senator  resigned to become Executive Director of Advancement at . As Minority Whip, Humason worked to coordinate votes within the Senate Republican Caucus and assist the Minority Leader in developing policy. He submitted his letter of resignation to    on December 4 upon being elected  of . A special election was scheduled for March 31, 2020, but was delayed by the COVID-19 pandemic until May 16; it was won by Representative John Velis, who previously won the 2014 special election to succeed Humason in the House.\n\nDuring his tenure in the Senate, Humason's committee assignments were as follows:\n;188th General Court (2013–2014)\n* Joint Committee on Children, Families and On March 21, Humason ran for mayor against Michael McCabe, a 34-year captain of the Westfield Police Department. Humason narrowly defeated McCabe in a close race, winning 4,983 votes while McCabe received 4,886. Neither side declared victory as the results were within the margin of error, but McCabe chose not to seek a recount and conceded.     "pages": }\n'''Jason Chauncey Spencer''' (born November 14, 1974) is an American  and  politician.\n\nSpencer was elected to the  in 2010, representing district 180, and serving into July 2018. He was defeated by  in the May 2018 Republican primary for Georgia House of Representatives District 180. He strongly opposed the  and helped prevent  expansion in Georgia.\n\nSpencer faced widespread criticism in July 2018 for his behavior during an episode of the  television show '''' in which British comedian , disguised as an Israeli  expert, led Spencer to drop his pants and shout multiple racial slurs. Criticized by Republican leaders, Spencer announced later that month that he would resign from the Georgia House of Representatives, and was replaced by .\n\nThe family moved in 1978 to  in , and a year later to . Spencer graduated from  in 1993. He attended  before transferring to , a , on a full athletic scholarship for tennis. He transferred again to the , from which he graduated in 1997 with a degree in exercise & sport science. Spencer studied and trained as a , receiving a second  from  in Savannah and a master's degree in  from the  in 2005.\n\n\n\nAn active member of the  in coastal Georgia, Spencer was first elected to the  in 2010 after defeating incumbent Cecily Hill in a  runoff. His district centers on  in southeastern Georgia. He was reelected in 2012, 2014, and 2016.\n\n\nSpencer served on the following committees in the Georgia State House: Science and Technology; Games, Fish and Parks; Juvenile Justice; Human Aging and Relations, and served as the Secretary to the House Special Rules Committee. He voted for legislation that relaxed “live-aboard” boating restrictions and legalized home brew beer competitions in Georgia.\n\nSpencer served as an advocate for survivors of child sexual abuse, introducing and gaining passage in 2015 of a landmark civil  reform legislation, known as the  (HB 17, 2015).  This legislation removed or extended the civil SOL so survivors can gain justice and expose the identities of hidden child abusers in the state of Georgia. The Hidden Predator Act was instrumental in leading to the unraveling of one of the largest sex scandals in U.S. sports history: the exposure of , who was later convicted of serial child molestation committed while serving the USA Gymnastics organization.  Rep. Spencer received Voice Today's \"Voice of Gratitude Award\" for his efforts authoring the legislation.\n\nIn 2018, Spencer attempted to amend this 2015 law to strengthen it and provide more time for survivors to file cases, but the bill was weakened by lobbying efforts from the Atlanta Archdiocese of the , the , and other powerful interest groups. It narrowly failed to pass on the last day of the 2018 legislative session.\n\nIn 2017, Spencer introduced and passed legislation, known as the Georgia Space Flight Act (House Bill 1, 2017), to attract the commercial space industry to Georgia as part of an ongoing effort to establish the state's first commercial .\n\n\nSpencer was one of the strongest opponents in the Georgia House to President 's administration's  (ACA). He authored legislation that effectively blocked  in Georgia. Spencer also blocked the establishment of the state's , and forced the University of Georgia to terminate its  under the Act. In 2014, Spencer introduced legislation to block the state from \"using of its resources to implement any portions of the health care law.\" When this legislation was tabled by Senate Majority Whip Cecil Station (R-Macon) and other opponents in committee, Spencer issued a press release blaming fellow Republicans for an \"eleventh hour betrayal\" and likening them to \"s, the  and his .\"\n\nIn 2016, after facing bipartisan opposition, Spencer withdrew a bill that was perceived to have banned Muslim women from wearing religious garments such as s or s in driver's license photographs or while driving cars. The legislation aimed to amend an existing 1951 Georgia law intended to prohibit members of the   from wearing masks and hoods; it had been constitutionally upheld by the Georgia Supreme Court in ''State v Miller'', 1990 to unmask members of the group. Many, including the  (CAIR) and , accused Spencer of .\n\nSpencer accused a constituent of treason and supporting terrorism for donating $10 to CAIR Georgia in response to his bill. Spencer supported his charge of potential treason in a letter written to his constituent stating that the  (CAIR) was designated as a terrorist organization by the United Arab Emirates due to the organization's alleged ties to , an organization which has been designated a terrorist organization by the U.S. Department of State.  In addition, Spencer stated that  was named by the U.S. Justice Department as an  in the largest terrorism funding trials in U.S. history, known as ''United States v Holy Land Foundation, et. al.'', claims which CAIR has rejected. As a result of the backlash of submitting this legislation, Spencer said he had received death threats.\n\nIn 2017, Spencer attracted controversy in the debate over the . In a  post, he issued a warning to , an  attorney, former Georgia House colleague and current State Director for ' Presidential Campaign, that she might \"go missing in the ,\" a swamp in southern Georgia (and partly in Spencer's district), if she followed through on her intentions to bring advocates to southern Georgia to remove Confederate monuments.\n\n\nIn May 2018, Spencer was defeated in the Republican primary by a primary challenger, 24-year-old political newcomer Steven Sainz. A local party leader attributed Spencer's loss in part to his \"antics\" in office. Spencer said \"if he rubbed anyone the wrong way,\" he was doing so by standing up to powerful special interest representing the plight of \"little guy.\"  “My tactics won against them and that is one of the reasons why I stayed in office for eight years, because I effectively beat them at their own game,” said Spencer to the ''Brunswick News.'' In a radio interview with WGIG 1440 AM, Rep. Jason Spencer said that he had often been a target of individuals on the ideological left and establishment politicians for introducing legislation that challenged powerful special interests. He believed such opponents blocked a bill in 2018 to strengthen a law extending civil justice to survivors of child sexual abuse.\n\n\nSpencer was featured in an episode of the  television show '''' that aired on July 22, 2018. The episode showed British comedian , disguised as an Israeli  expert, leading Spencer to drop his pants, imitate a Chinese tourist using  that mixed various , use a  to take an  under a woman's , and repeatedly yell \"\".\n\nGeorgia House Speaker  urged Spencer to resign, saying that he had disgraced himself. Governor  tweeted that Spencer's actions were \"appalling and offensive\". Spencer apologized for what he described as \"this ridiculously ugly episode\" but initially refused to step down, saying that the show's producers had exploited him \"for profit and notoriety\". He said that Baron Cohen and the television crew had falsely promised that he would be able to review and approve the final footage before release. Spencer later announced his resignation on July 24, effective as of July 31.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* , Georgia House of Representatives\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David M. Nangle''' (born December 18, 1960) is an American  and convicted felon who served in the  from 1999 to 2020. He is a  resident and a member of the . While a member of the House, he served as the chair of the House Ethics committee. In February 2021, Nangle pleaded guilty to charges of wire fraud, bank fraud, making false statements to a bank, and filing false tax returns and was sentenced to 15 months in prison and two years of supervised release. He was released from federal custody on November 10, 2022.\n\n\nNangle grew up in Lowell, Massachusetts and graduated from  in 1978.\n\n\nNangle was first elected to represent the  district in 1998 defeating Republican Karen Simao with 60.9% of the vote. Following redistricting after the , Nangle began to serve as the representative for the  district starting in 2003. Under speaker , Nangle became chair of the Massachusetts House Ethics committee and a member of DeLeo's leadership team, serving as one of the floor division chairs. Following the federal indictment, Nangle resigned his leadership positions in February 2020. In November 2020, Nangle lost the 2020 Democratic primary election for the 17th Middlesex District to .\n\n\nOn February 18, 2020, Nangle was arrested by both the  and  on federal charges alleging that he raided his campaign account to pay for personal expenses and sustain a gambling habit at various s around the New England area. According to the , \"NANGLE illicitly used campaign funds to, among other things: (i) pay for personal expenses (ii) defraud his bank lender, and (iii) collect income that he failed to report to the Internal Revenue Service.\"\n\nThe indictment charged Nangle with 10 counts of , four counts of , nine counts of making false statements to a bank, and five counts of filing false income tax returns. He pleaded not guilty and was released $25,000  and ordered to surrender his passport and to refrain from gambling.\n\nOn February 24, 2021, Nangle pleaded guilty to charges of 10 counts of wire fraud, four counts of bank fraud, four counts of making false statements to a bank and five counts of filing false tax returns. On September 15, 2021, Nangle was sentenced to 15 months in prison followed by two years of supervised release. He was also ordered to pay $33,347 to the IRS and a forfeiture of $15,650. He was ordered to report to  to serve his sentence before November 1, 2021. Nangle was released from prison in April 2022 and served the remainder of his sentence in community confinement.\n\n\n* House Committee on Ethics\n* House Committee on Rules\n* Joint Committee on Rules\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Shawn C. Dooley''' is an American politician from the Commonwealth of . He was a member of the  in the 9th Norfolk district, succeeding . The 9th Norfolk District constitutes all or parts of the Towns of , , , , , and . A member of the Republican Party, he was sworn in January 29, 2014. In 2022, he vacated the seat to run for the , he was defeated by incumbent .\n\n\nDooley received his  from , and a  from . He is married to Family Law Attorney Carolyn (CiCi) Van Tine and they have four children.\n\n\nPrior to his election to the state house, he served as the elected Norfolk  as well as the Chairman of the Norfolk School Committee.\n\nDooley was elected to the Norfolk School Committee at the May 11th, 2010 town election. That year he was also appointed to the town's zoning board of appeals by the select board. In 2011 he elected as Norfolk's town clerk and was appointed to Norfolk's Board of Health and the School Building Committee. According to Norfolk's 2011 Annual Report, Shawn Dooley was also appointed a Justice of the Peace by Governor Deval Patrick and performed numerous marriage ceremonies in 2012, many of which were held at the gazebo on Town Hill. On Tuesday, April 30, 2013 he was reelected to the Norfolk School Committee. Upon his election to the state house, Dooley resigned his school committee seat.\n\nDooley made national headlines for his bill on preventing Chinese owned and other non-market economy nations from participating in the state bid process for critical infrastructure such as rail. The impetus of this bill was when 's government owned CRRC gained the Massachusetts Bay Transit Authority contract for manufacturing orange lines cars. His original opinion piece sparked national coverage including , NPR,  and . Similar bills were filed in both the  and  and passed in a bipartisan fashion.\n\nIn August 2020, the conservative website ''New Boston Post'' published an excerpt from Representative Dooley’s nightly Facebook post on the pandemic criticizing   and calling him \"King Charles\" for implementing  restrictions without consulting the legislature and issuing numerous executive orders under the guise of a state of emergency, after a spike of cases rose .\n\nOn January 3, 2021, Dooley challenged  Jim Lyons for the Chairmanship of the Massachusetts Republican Party in an effort to \"capture that middle ground as opposed to going far hard-right\". Dooley lost to Lyons with a vote of the Republican State Committee 39-36.\n\nIn 2022, Dooley ran for the .  He was defeated by incumbent Democrat , 55-45.\n\n\nRep. Dooley resigned from his seat on December 27, 2022 at 5:00pm, a week before his term was set to expire. Following the resignation, outgoing Governor Charlie Baker appointed Dooley to the Massachusetts Civil Service Commission.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\nDooley faced no opposition in the 2014 General Election.\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He has served as Minority Leader since January 2021.\n\n\nBeverly earned a B.S. in Biology from  in 1990 and a doctorate in optometry from the  in 1994.     "pages": }\n'''Dianne Wilkerson''' (born May 2, 1955) is a former  member of the , representing the  from 1993 to 2008 as the first  female to serve in the chamber.\n\nOn October 28, 2008, she was arrested on  charges by the  for accepting bribes totaling $23,500. She formally resigned on November 19, 2008. On June 3, 2010, she pleaded guilty to eight felony counts of attempted . She was  from the practice of law in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts on November 24, 2010, and served a federal prison sentence from 2011 to 2013.\n\n\nDianne Wilkerson graduated from High School of Commerce in . She earned a  degree in  from  in 1978, and a  from  in 1981. After graduating from law school and passing the bar she served as a civil rights lawyer and was active in the .\n\n\n \n\n\nIn 1993, she became the first African American woman to serve in the Massachusetts Senate, winning election in 1992 after defeating incumbent  in the Democratic primary.\n\nWhen in office, Wilkerson's Senatorial District included the , , , , , , , and some parts of the , , and .\n\nShe lost the September 2008 Democratic primary to , and on October 31, 2008, announced that she was ending her write-in campaign to seek re-election in the November 4, 2008, election. On November 19, 2008, Wilkerson formally resigned from the Massachusetts state Senate.\n\nIn April 2022, following Sonia Chang-Diaz's decision not to run for re-election, she filed papers for another Senate run. She lost the Democratic primary to  , coming in third with 21% of the vote.\n\n\nAs State Senator, she was appointed to the following: the Commission to Eliminate Racial & Ethnic Healthcare Disparities, the Hynes Convention Center & Boston Common Parking Garage Legislative Commission, the Special Commission on Non-Group and Small Group Health Insurance, Co-Chair; and the Massachusetts Workforce Investment Board.\n\n\nSenate Chair, Joint Committee on State Administration and Regulatory Oversight; the Joint Committee on Financial Services; the Senate Committee on Ways and Means; the Joint Committee on Education; the Joint Committee on Mental Health and Substance Abuse; and the Joint Committee on Bonding, Capital Expenditures and State Assets.\n\n\n\n\nWilkerson was sentenced to  in December 1997 after pleading guilty to failing to pay $51,000 in federal income taxes in the early 1990s. She was suspended from practicing law for one year in 1999 because of the conviction and did not seek reinstatement.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2001, she was fined $1,000 by the State Ethics Commission for failing to properly report that a bank she lobbied for as senator was paying her more than $20,000 a year as a consultant.\n\n\nIn September 2005, the   and head of the state's campaign finance office filed a lawsuit against Wilkerson, alleging she had not reported nearly $27,000 in donations and refused to explain more than $18,000 in personal reimbursements. She agreed to pay a $10,000 fine and forgo about $30,000 in debts owed her to settle the allegations.\n\n\nThe state Office of the Bar Counsel filed a complaint on October 3, 2008, accusing Wilkerson of violating the rules of professional conduct by lying under oath at a 2005 court hearing at which her nephew, Jermaine Berry, requested a new trial on a manslaughter conviction.\n\nWilkerson, who joined the bar in 1981 but had not practiced in a decade, gave \"intentionally false, misleading, and deceptive testimony\" at the Suffolk Superior Court hearing and in an , according to the eight-page petition for discipline.\n\nIn both the court appearance and the affidavit, the complaint said, Wilkerson falsely claimed that she was present at a Boston police station when two homicide detectives interviewed another nephew, Isaac Wilkerson, about the 1994 stabbing death of Hazel Mack. Berry was convicted of voluntary manslaughter in Mack's death, but the senator testified that Isaac Wilkerson made statements that implicated himself during the interview.\n\nWilkerson also lied when she testified that the detectives repeatedly turned a tape recorder off and on during the interview, the disciplinary complaint said.\n\n\n\nOn October 28, 2008, Wilkerson was arrested by the  on public corruption charges. A federal criminal complaint was filed against her that alleges she was caught on tape stuffing a cash bribe into her bra and accepted those cash payments in exchange for her official duties and responsibilities.\n\nWilkerson was the subject of an 18-month-long undercover investigation conducted by the  and the FBI in which she allegedly accepted eight bribes in cash totaling $23,500. The payments, ranging in amounts from $500 to $10,000 were received from undercover law enforcement officers and a cooperating witness. The bribes were allegedly accepted in return for her help in obtaining a liquor license for a proposed nightclub and transferring public land to a federal agent posing as a private developer.\n\nOn November 17, 2008, Wilkerson filed a motion in federal court requesting a court-appointed lawyer to defend her against the bribery charges. She stated that she could not afford to pay for a lawyer and asked US Magistrate Judge Timothy S. Hillman to appoint Max D. Stern. Stern had been defending Wilkerson in an unrelated matter.\n\nOn November 18, 2008, a  indicted Wilkerson on eight counts of accepting bribes.\n\nOn December 8, 2008, Wilkerson appeared before Judge Timothy S. Hillman in the  in Boston to plead not guilty to eight extortion charges. After a federal grand jury added a conspiracy charge against Wilkerson, she had to return to court on December 11 along with co-defendant Boston City Councilor  to again plead not guilty to all charges. On April 7, 2009, a federal grand jury added 23 more counts of corruption against Wilkerson. It was alleged that she had been receiving bribes since 2002.\nOn June 3, 2010, Wilkerson pleaded guilty to eight counts of attempted extortion. As part of her plea agreement, other related charges will be dismissed. She remained free on bail while awaiting sentencing.\n\nOn January 6, 2011, Wilkerson was sentenced to three and a half years in prison for bribery.\n\n\nDespite the arrest, Wilkerson initially vowed to continue her write-in candidacy and criticized  , whom she accused of \"engaging in a political calculus to derail her campaign\". However, on October 31, after meeting with members of Boston's Ten Point Coalition and Black Ministerial Alliance, she agreed to suspend her campaign stating \"I am withdrawing from the race. We will not be doing any work on the sticker campaign\".\n\nIn response to the arrest, Senate President  stripped Wilkerson of her chairmanship of the Committee on State Administration and Regulatory Oversight and stated that she would initiate a Senate Ethics Committee investigation. On October 30, 2008, the Massachusetts Senate removed her from all her committee assignments and unanimously passed a resolution calling on her to resign. In response, Wilkerson sent a letter to Senate President Murray stating that she would follow the will of the Senate. Wilkerson was not present during the Senate vote. Wilkerson later released a statement indicating that she would not resign, calling the request \"unreasonable\" and also stating: \"Surely the members of the state Senate could not have believed that such a monumental decision would be made within a few hours. A decision to leave this district without representation, even for 60 days, is one that cannot and should not be made in a matter of hours. Rest assured I am committed to do what is in the best interest of the residents of this district.\"\n\nIn the days following her arrest, calls for Wilkerson's resignation also came from Massachusetts Governor  and in editorials from Boston's two major newspapers, the '''' and ''''.\n\nOn November 5, 2008, in a statement issued by her Senate office, Wilkerson announced that she would resign \"...as soon as humanly and responsibly possible.\" On November 19, 2008, Wilkerson formally resigned from the Massachusetts Senate, the day before the Senate was to vote on expelling her.\n\nWilkerson was released from prison September 27, 2013. In February 2014, Wilkerson received an award as one of 18 \"women of color changing our world\", presented by the , .\n\n\n\n\n\n*''Follow the Money'' – Dianne Wilkerson\n**     campaign contributions\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Peter Vincent Kocot''' (September 18, 1956 – February 22, 2018) was an American politician who was representative to the state legislature of  from April 2002 until his death in February 2018. A member of the , he represented the First Hampshire district, which includes , , , , and . His positions included support of  and opposition to education spending cuts.\n\nKocot easily won re-election in 2006; his  opponent,  Economics professor  (whom Kocot also faced in 2002 and 2004), polled at 18 percent.\n\nIn the state legislature, Kocot was the chairman of the Joint Committee on State Administration and Regulatory Oversight and a member of the House Committee on Ethics.\n\n\nKocot was one of five children (Paul, Joseph, Mary, and Kathy) born to Dorothy and Edward Kocot on September 18, 1956. He was born in Northampton, Massachusetts, but raised in Florence, Massachusetts.\n\n\nKocot had two sons, Jake and Luke, with his wife of 29 years, Shauneen (née O'Donnell).\n\nKocot died on February 21, 2018, after a brief illness, at the age of 61.\n \n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kate Hogan''' (born January 15, 1957, in ) is an  from . A , she is a member of the  representing the 3rd Middlesex district. She was first elected in 2008 and took office on January 7, 2009.\n\n\nThe 3rd Middlesex district, which includes the towns of , ,  and Stow, was represented for 24 years by , who decided not to seek re-election in 2008. Five candidates ran for to succeed her: three Democrats, one Republican and one Independent. Prior to the primary, Walrath endorsed Hogan as her chosen successor.\n\nIn the three-way primary election held on September 16, 2008, Hogan won 50 percent of the vote to the second-placed finisher's 40 percent. She went on to face two opponents in the general election on November 4, narrowly besting the Republican nominee, Hudson selectman Sonny Parente, by 10,156 votes to 9,281. She ran for re-election in 2010, facing no Republican opponent and taking 60% of the vote against an Independent.\n\nHer first action on being sworn in on January 7, 2009, was to turn down a pay raise. She donated the $3,000 increase in legislative salaries to the local libraries in Bolton, Hudson, Maynard and Stow.\n\nOn February 26, 2015, Speaker  appointed Hogan as Chair of the Joint Committee on Public Health.\n\nHogan, a native of , is a graduate of the  and works as vice president of Gnomon Inc., a Boston printing company. She has long been involved in local Democratic politics, having served as an officer of the Stow Democratic Town Committee, the Middlesex and Worcester Democrats and as co-chairman of the Maynard Democratic Town Committee from 1999 to 2006. She has also sat on several of Stow's town committees, including the Community Preservation Committee and the Council on Aging.\n\nHogan, a , is married to Susan Vick.     "pages": }\n\n'''Solomon Adesanya''' (born July 12, 1985) is an American businessman and a politician. He was elected on November 8, 2022, in the 2022 US midterm elections. Adesanya is a Democrat who won the election in his first attempt to the . His constituents in the 43rd District cover mainly Marietta and a small part of Northwest Atlanta. Adesanya won the seat in a district historically held by a Republican. Solomon Adesanya succeeded , who now represents the 45th District due to reapportionment. Solomon assumed office on January 9, 2023.\n\n\nAdesanya is a second-generation American who lives in  and often reflects on his immigrant father's ideals which were of hope and a belief in the American dream. Solomon is of Nigerian descent. His father Olu Adesanya (1948–2009), came to the United States from  in 1971 as a student. Solomon's father completed his undergraduate degree in chemistry at the university of ,  and his master's degree at the university of , Springfield. His father lived between  and Chicago during the 80s and early 90s. His older brother was born in Chicago, while Solomon and his immediate brother were born in . Solomon Adesanya grew up in  and on the  of Chicago. He attended  Masters of Public Policy. Solomon Adesanya is married with two daughters.\n\n\nAdesanya is an entrepreneur; he owns two restaurants in the Atlanta metro area. Kale Me Crazy  and Kale Me Crazy . Adesanya also owns other small businesses. Adesanya laid his campaign platform on helping small businesses. He believes small business is the heart of the community.     "pages": }\n'''David P. Magnani''' (born May 24, 1944) is an American politician and activist. He served as  member of  and  from 1984 to 2004 representing  and .\n\n\nIn 1968, he received a Bachelor of Mechanical Engineering from , followed by a Master of Education and a Doctor of Education from the . He received a Master of Public Administration from 's  in 1989.\n\n\n\nIn , he challenged Andrew Rogers, his former high school fellow for state representative seat and won. In 1992, he was elected to the Massachusetts State Senate.     "pages": }\n\n'''Bill Heath''' (born October 20, 1959) is a former Republican  who served from 2005 to 2021.  He served as the Senate Floor Leader for .  Prior to his election to the state senate, Heath served one two-year term in the .\n\n\nBill Heath's first foray into electoral politics was in 2000, when he challenged , the  Speaker of the , for the 18th State House District.  Murphy had held the seat since 1960, and had skated to reelection time and again.\n\nDespite the state Republican Party taking no initial interest in the race, a very competitive race would materialize.  Heath would raise over $60,000, a very competitive sum for a State House race.  Aiding Heath was the ongoing shift in the district's demographics, with the district becoming more suburban and more Republican as 's outer suburbs had begun bleeding into the district; Republican candidates for other offices had frequently won the district Heath would lose the race by 505 votes, a margin of less than two percentage points.\n\nHeath finally defeated Murphy in 2002, in the final race of Murphy's life. The loss was widely attributed to Murphy's role in the 2001 redistricting, which produced contorted districts that confused and angered voters.\n\nUpon taking his seat in the Georgia House, Heath acquired national attention in 2004, when he added a ban on adult women's ability to choose to get genital piercings onto a bill designed to ban the genital mutilation of children. Adult men would still have been allowed to choose to have their genitals pierced under Heath's amendment. The attention arose from both the difference in the way Heath's amendment treated women and men and from Heath's seeming lack of knowledge regarding the practice he proposed to legislate. The amended bill passed the House 160-0, forcing it back to the Georgia Senate.\n\n\nIn 2013, after an online petition generated by the group Better Georgia, Heath was condemned for his response to legislature creating a $150,000 a year position for former Majority Leader  at Georgia Public Broadcasting. Heath dismissed those who signed the petition as \"childish\" in an email response, and hid in the Secretary of the Senate Office refusing to take questions from the press.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Barry Fleming''' (born May20, 1965) is an American politician who served in the  from 2013 to 2024. He previously served in the Georgia House of Representatives from 2003 to 2009.\n\nIn 2021, he introduced an election reform bill that would restrict voting access. Among its many provisions, it would restrict where  can be located and when they can be accessed, require photo identification for , shift back the deadline to request an absentee ballot, and limit  hours. Most controversially, it would restrict early voting on Sundays, when es traditionally run \"Souls to the Polls\"  efforts; according to '''', Black voter turnout is 10 percentage points higher on Sundays.\n\nOn March10, 2021,  commissioners voted 40 to ask for Fleming’s resignation as the county's attorney because of his sponsorship of House Bill 531, which critics call a \"voter suppression bill\". The 2019 Census shows that \"Hancock County's population is around 71% African-American\" and 2020 election results showed Joe Biden won Hancock County with 71.7% of the vote versus 27.8% for .\n\nGeorgia governor  appointed Fleming to serve as a superior court judge on the Columbia Judicial Circuit on December28, 2023. He was sworn in on January10, 2024.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael O. Moore''' (born January 17, 1963) is an American politician from , who serves as the  for the , comprising his hometown of  and seven other communities including parts of the city of . He is member of the  who has served in the  since January 7, 2009.\n\n\nMoore is a graduate of ,  and . He holds a master's degree in  from .\n\n\n\nBorn and raised in the town of Millbury and a graduate of the Waltham Police Academy, he began his 22-year law enforcement career as a  officer, eventually becoming an investigator in the ’s office.\n\nIn 2005, he was appointed Assistant Deputy Superintendent at the Worcester County Sheriff's office, where he oversaw the Community Service Program, inmate reintegration program, and senior citizen community outreach safety programs.\n\nMoore was elected to the Millbury Board of Selectmen in 2001. In 2004, during his tenure on the board, The Shoppes at Blackstone Valley, the largest economic development project in Millbury history, opened, expanding the town's commercial tax base by approximately $1 million annually. He was re-elected to the Board of Selectmen in 2004 and 2007.\n\n\nMoore was elected to represent the people of the Second Worcester District in the  in November 2008, earning 60% of the vote.\n\nDuring his first term, Moore chaired the Joint Committee on Community Development and Small Businesses, overseeing legislation to protect the Commonwealth's small and family-owned businesses. Moore also served as Vice Chair of the Joint Committee on Elder Affairs, and sat on the Joint Committee on Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture, the Senate Committee on Bonding, Capital Expenditures, and State Assets, and the Senate Committee on Post Audit and Oversight.Moore also serves on various boards and legislative advisory committees advocating for issues such as higher education,  or issues of statewide importance for the. Currently, he serves on the advisory board for the Dr. Lillian R. Goodman Department of Nursing at , is a member of the Massachusetts Workforce Investment Board, acting-Senate Chairman of the  Legislative Caucus, a member of the Biotech Caucus and a member of the Manufacturing Caucus. Moore is also a vice-chair of the ' Eastern Regional Conference's Education Committee. He also serves as the co-chairman of the Council of State Governments' Intergovernmental Affairs Committee and Chair of the Council of State Governments' Eastern Region Education Committee. He is a member of the New England Board of Higher Education Legislative Advisory Committee and serves on the ' Federalism Task Force and is a member of the ' International Committee.\n\n\nMoore represents the Second Worcester District, comprising eight communities in . The district includes the towns of , , , , , , precincts 2 and 4 in , and wards 5-7 and precincts 1 and 5 in ward 8 of the city of .\n\n\nMoore serves on nine legislative committees in the .\n\n* Joint Committee on Higher Education (chair)\n* Joint Committee on Public Safety and Homeland Security (Vice Chair)\n* Senate Committee on Ways and Means\n* Joint Committee on Ways and Means\n* Joint Committee on Labor and Workforce Development\n* Senate Committee on Intergovernmental Affairs\n* Senate Committee on Post Audit and Oversight\n* Senate Committee on Bonding, Capital Expenditures and State Assets\n* Special Senate Committee on Opioid Addition Prevention, Treatment and Recovery Options\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
