    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert Pruitt''' is an  politician and businessman from Georgia. Pruitt served as a  member of the  for District 149 from January 2021 to January 2023.\n\n\n\nRobert Pruitt was born in . His parents were serving in the  at the time of his birth and were stationed at . Throughout the course of his childhood, Pruitt lived in Germany; Oklahoma; Orlando, Florida; Augusta, Georgia; Japan; and Chauncey, Georgia. Pruitt has lived in Georgia for the majority of his life.\n\n\n\nPruitt attended  in Eastman and obtained a diploma in Flight Technology in 1997. He was a member of the first graduating class of this institute. Pruitt attended  and obtained a degree of Associate of Applied Science in 1997 also. In 2000, Pruitt obtained a Bachelors of Science degree in Professional Aeronautics from .\n\n\nPruitt is a pilot, pilot instructor, businessman, and entrepreneur. Pruitt is chief executive officer and President of SoPoly Outdoor Furniture.\n\nOn June 9, 2020, Pruitt won the Republican primary election and was unopposed in the general election on November 3, 2020, therefore he became a  member of  for District 149.\n\nOn January 11, 2021, Pruitt was sworn in as a member of the  for District 149 succeeding .\n\nWhile a member of the House, Pruitt served on the House Economic Development & Tourism Committee, the House Industry and Labor Committee, & the House Small Business and Development Committee.\n\nOn January 9, 2023, he left office and  replaced him.\n\nFollowing his departure from the Georgia House of Representatives, he became Executive Director of the Eastman-Dodge County Development Authority.\n\n\nPruitt's wife is Kelly Rogers Pruitt. They have three children. Pruitt and his family reside in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ayanna Soyini Pressley''' (born February 3, 1974) is an American politician who has served as the  for  since 2019. This district includes the northern three quarters of , most of , parts of , as well as all of , , , and . Before serving in the United States House of Representatives,  as an at-large member of the  from 2010 through 2019. She was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 2018 after she defeated the ten-term incumbent  in the   for Massachusetts's 7th congressional district and ran unopposed in . Pressley was the first black woman elected to the Boston City Council and the first black woman elected to Congress from Massachusetts. Pressley is a member of \"\", a group of  Congress members.\n\n\nPressley was born in , , and raised in , .  Her father, Martin Terrell, struggled with addiction and was incarcerated throughout Pressley's childhood, but eventually earned multiple degrees and taught at the college level. Her mother, Sandra Pressley (née Echols), worked multiple jobs to support the family and also worked as a  for the  advocating for tenants' rights.   The marriage ended in divorce.\nPressley grew up on the north side of Chicago and attended , where she was a cheerleader, did modeling and  work, appeared in  bus advertisements, and was a . During her senior year of high school, she was voted the \"most likely to be mayor of Chicago\" and was the  for her class.\n\nPressley's mother later moved to , where she worked as an executive assistant and remarried. When Pressley was elected to the Boston City Council, her mother would often attend the public meetings, wearing a hat that said \"Mama Pressley\".\n\nFrom 1992 to 1994, Pressley attended the  at , before leaving school to take a full-time job at the Boston Marriott Copley Place to support her mother, who had lost her job. She took further courses at .\n\nPressley has publicly recounted having been a survivor of a \"near decade of \". She has also publicly recounted surviving a  on the campus of Boston University while a student there.\n\n\nAfter leaving Boston University Metropolitan College, Pressley worked as a district representative for   (−), for whom she had interned during college. She became Kennedy's scheduler, then worked as constituency director, before becoming the political director and senior aide for   (D-Mass.) In 2009, Pressley served as Kerry's political director.\n\n\n\n\n Boston City Council campaign march in the 2009 Dorchester Day Parade]]\n\nPressley was first elected to the Boston City Council in . Upon being sworn in on January 4, 2010, she was the first  to serve in the 100-year history of the Boston City Council.\n\nPressley placed a strong focus to women's and children's issues. Pressley founded the Committee on Healthy Women, Families, and Communities, which addresses issues such as , , and . She worked collaboratively with community members to develop a  and health curriculum which was implemented in .\n\nIn June 2014, the Boston City Council unanimously passed an ordinance Pressley coauthored with Councilor , which prohibits its city government \"from contracting with any health insurer that denies coverage or 'discriminates in the amount of premium, policy fees, or rates charged...because of  or expression\". This ordinance guaranteed healthcare (including , , and  services) to  city employees and their dependents. Pressley declared, \"We can't be a world-class city if anyone is made to feel like a second-class citizen.\"\n\n]]\n\nPressley worked on the issue of s in the city. The ultimate product of Pressley's push was the passage of state legislation in 2014 granting Boston the authority to distribute 75 additional liquor licenses over a three year period, with the aim of distributing them to less advantaged neighborhoods in order to increase economic activity in those neighborhoods. However, '''''s Meghan Irons observed that an unintentional impact of this was that, \"it created uneven competition. It left out certain neighborhoods. It allowed businesses that were already established to get the licenses.\" Nevertheless, in 2018, '''' called Pressley's work on the matter a \"major accomplishment\". To remedy the shortfalls, Pressley worked with Mayor Walsh to further expand the number of new available liquor licenses. In 2017, Pressley and Mayor Walsh unveiled a proposal to increase the number of liquor license in the city by 152 over a three year period, with the majority of licenses being granted to underserved communities.\n\n, Democratic U.S. Senate nominee , and Suffolk County Clerk of Courts Criminal Business  at the Boston Caribbean Carnival parade in August 2012]]\n\nIn 2017, the Council passed the Equity in City of Boston Contracts Ordinance, which was sponsored by Pressley and Councilor Michelle Wu. It required that the city create a supplier diversity program to conduct outreach to female and minority-owned businesses in regards to the city contracting process. It also required the city to actively solicit bids from at least one female-owned business and one minority-owned business for contracts under $50,000. It also created a quarterly reporting requirement for the city.\n\nAccording to Erin O'Brien, a political science professor at ,  Pressley did not have the reputation for being controversial or an outsider during her time on the City Council. O'Brien, in 2018, observed that the city's \"old guard\" viewed Pressley as a \"showboat\" but that, \"in many , she is viewed as incredibly exciting and voicing issues the council has ignored.\"\n\n campaign of ]]\n\nIn the Boston City council election of , Pressley finished first among at-large candidates with 37,000 votes. She led in 13 of the city's 22 wards and finished second in three others. Pressley won Boston's communities of color and many progressive neighborhoods. In all, she placed first in more than half of Boston's 22 wards. Pressley placed first ticket again in  and , and placed second in  behind only Michelle Wu.\n\nWhile on the Boston City Council, Pressley was one of the first notable Massachusetts politicians to endorse 's successful campaign in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn January 2018, Pressley announced her challenge to incumbent United States Representative  in the 2018 Democratic primary nomination for the . With a  of D+34, the 7th is by far the most Democratic district in New England. The GOP has only nominated a candidate in this district five times since longtime Speaker  retired in 1986.\n\nThe 7th district is traditionally Democratic and is the state's only district where the majority of residents are not white. Capuano received endorsements from civil rights veteran and U.S. Representative  of Georgia as well as U.S. Representative  of California.\n\nFor years before she challenged him, Pressley had been speculated as a likely top-contender to succeed Capuano if he were to retire.\n\nPressley was endorsed by the editorial boards of both ''The Boston Globe'' and the '''' as well as a local chapter of the hotel and electrical worker union. Grassroots movements including ,  and the  supported Pressley. She received the endorsements of former Massachusetts Democratic Party chair , Massachusetts Attorney General , former  mayor  and Boston city councilor . The nomination win in  of  over long-time representative  increased the visibility of Pressley's campaign. While some political commentators distinguished Pressley's campaign from the one of Ocasio-Cortez as Capuano was understood to have one of the most progressive records in Congress, the incumbents both represented districts in which the majority of voters are not white.\n\nLike Capuano, Pressley campaigned as a staunch progressive, admitting that her voting record would likely be almost identical to Capuano's. However, Pressley contended that a reliably liberal voting record was not enough to meet the needs of a district whose demographics and character had changed over the years. She also claimed that the district needed to be represented by someone who would take a more aggressive role in opposing the presidency of . She campaigned with the slogan \"change can't wait\", and promised that she would bring \"activist leadership\".\n\nIn the September 4, 2018, Democratic , Pressley defeated Capuano by a margin of 59% to 41%. The primary victory was a surprise, as the last poll before the election showed Capuano with a significant lead, 48% to 35%. Part of the reason the polls may have been inaccurate was a surge in the number of primary voters. According to Boston NPR station , 24 percent of primary voters in the 7th district primary had not voted in the five previous primaries. The percentage of new voters included a disproportionate number of Hispanic and Asian voters. She won the general election unopposed, though the Democratic primary in her district is seen as .\n\n\n\n\nPressley was unopposed for the Democratic nomination. Rayla Campbell, a claims adjuster and occupational zoning activist from , mounted a write-in campaign as a Republican. Pressley won the election.\n\n\nPresley defeated Republican Donnie Palmer in the general election.\n\n\n\nPressley is the first black woman elected to represent Massachusetts in Congress. With the November election victory of  in , they became the first women  to be elected to Congress from .\n\nPressley is a member of the informal group known as \"\", whose members form a unified front to push for  changes such as the Green New Deal and Medicare-for-all. The other original members of \"The Squad\" are  (D-MN),  (D-MI), and  (D-NY). Pressley is the oldest and most politically experienced of the four, and she was asked by the group to act as their spokesperson after then-President Donald J. Trump attacked them.\n\nIn an interview with '''' in July 2019, Pressley said her office received  after President Trump's tweets on July 14, 2019, and in general since her election.\n\nIn May 2019, Pressley gave the  address to the graduates of University of Massachusetts Boston, saying they are \"President Trump's worst nightmare\". In her speech, she said, \"Represented here today are dreamers and doers, immigrants, people of every race identity, every gender identity and sexuality, sisters rocking Senegalese twists and hijabs.\"\n\nOn September 17, 2019, Pressley filed a  that called for the House Judiciary Committee to launch  proceedings against Supreme Court Justice .\n\nIn November 2019, Pressley introduced a criminal justice reform resolution that called for decriminalizing consensual , abolishing , , abolishing  and , and shrinking the U.S. prison population by greater than 80 percent. The house resolution was called The People's Justice Guarantee.\n\nIn July, 2021, Pressley joined  and  in sleeping on the steps of the U.S. Capitol to protest the expiration of the eviction moratorium during the .\n\nOn November 5, 2021, Pressley was one of six House Democrats who broke with their party and voted against the , as it was decoupled from the social safety net provisions in the .\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n* \n\n\n* '''''' (co-chair)\n* ''''''\n* ''''''  (Pressley co-chairs it with )\n* ''''''\n* ''''''\n* '''''' (founding co-chair)\n*''''''\n\n\n\n\nPressley is an advocate of .\n\nIn May 2019, Pressley and Senator  introduced the Healthy MOMMIES Act, legislation that would expand Medicaid coverage in an attempt to provide comprehensive , labor, and  care with an extension of the Medicaid pregnancy pathway from 60 days to a full year following birth for the purpose of assuring new mothers have access to services unrelated to pregnancy. The bill also directed Medicaid and the 's Payment and Access Commission report its data regarding  care coverage under state Medicaid programs and subsequently develop strategies aimed at improving access to doula care.\n\n\nPressley has supported the , which have been used to bring attention to the disproportionate rate of which  affects black people.\n\nOn March 5, 2019, Pressley proposed lowering the  from 18 years old to 16 in an amendment she introduced in Congress. This was her first amendment on the House floor and was intended to amend the . Her amendment was defeated 305–126–2, with a slight majority of the Democrats and one Republican voting in favor.\n\nOn December 5, 2019, Pressley, Cory Booker, and Representatives , , and  introduced the Create a Respectful and Open World for Natural Hair (CROWN) Act to ban discrimination based on hair textures and hairstyles that are commonly associated with a particular race or national origin.\n\n\nIn June 2018, Pressley called for the defunding of , saying the law enforcement agency poses an \"existential threat\" to immigrant communities. In June 2019, Pressley was one of four Democratic representatives to vote against the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Humanitarian Assistance and Security at the Southern Border Act (H.R. 3401), a $4.5 billion border funding bill sponsored by  that required Customs and Border Protection enact health standards for individuals in custody such as forming standards for individuals for \"medical emergencies; nutrition, hygiene, and facilities; and personnel training.\"\n\n\nIn 2018, Pressley said that she would make ending sexual violence a major priority of her work in Congress.\n\nPressley supports , saying it \"would improve the health and safety of sex workers and put them on the path to greater stability.\" She argued that sex work is the only work available to some , especially  of color, and that they would be less at risk if they could self advocate and report unlawful acts committed against them.\n\n\nOn April 9, 2019, Pressley was one of four House Democrats to introduce the Be HEARD Act, legislation intended to abolish the tipped minimum wage along with ending mandatory arbitration and pre-employment . The bill would also give workers additional time to report harassment.\n\n\nOn July 23, 2019, Pressley voted in favor of , a House Resolution introduced by Illinois Congressman  that formally condemns the  movement against . The resolution passed 398–17; Pressley was the only member of \"\" to vote in favor of it. On September 23 Pressley was one of eight Democrats to vote against the funding of Israel's  missile defense system.\n\nSpeaking at a fundraiser with  in , Pressley condemned the  that killed Iranian general , saying: \"It is consistent with the impulsive, reckless, short-sighted foreign policy of the occupant of this White House who I think proceeds as if he's engaging in a game of Battleship and does not prioritize diplomacy.\"\n\nIn 2023, Pressley was among 56 Democrats to vote in favor of H.Con.Res. 21 which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\nOn July 18, 2023, she voted against, along with eight other   (, , , , , , , and ),   proposed by  which states that “the State of Israel is not a  or an \", that Congress rejects \"all forms of antisemitism and xenophobia\" and that “the United States will always be a staunch partner and supporter of Israel.\"\n\nShe condemned . On October 16, 2023, Pressley signed a resolution calling for a ceasefire in the . She said on the press call: \"Let me make it plain: the murder of innocent Israeli civilians by Hamas is horrific and unacceptable. And the murder of innocent Palestinian civilians is a horrific and unacceptable response from Israel. Vengeance should not be a foreign policy doctrine.\"\n\n\nIn early February 2021, Pressley supported a plan to cancel up to $50,000 in  for approximately 44 million Americans who have federal student loans. She has asked President Biden to forgive this debt by using  rather than going through the legislative process that would likely get bogged down in . Pressley told ''The Boston Globe'', \"It's about an equitable economic recovery. If people really do believe that Black Lives Matter, then the only receipts that matter in this moment are budgets and policies.\"\n\n\nAs a city councilor, Pressley introduced an ordinance that would have prohibited the use of credit scores by employers in assessing prospective and existing hires.\n\nAs a congresswoman, Pressley was the author of a credit report reform bill titled the \"Comprehensive Credit Reporting Enhancement, Disclosure, Innovation, and Transparency Act\" (\"CREDIT Act\"). It passed the House 221-to-189 in January 2020. The resolution would have:\n*Placed limits on employers' use of credit scores in their hiring process\n*Provided greater oversight of the credit score industry by the \n*Decreased the amount of time which most negative credit information remains in credit scores from a seven-year period to a four year period.\n*Decreased the amount of time that bankruptcy information remains on credit scores from ten years to seven years\n*Made it easier for individuals to request that \"potentially material\" errors on their credit reports be remedied\n*Provided expanded opportunities for those with student loans to improve their credit scores\n*Prohibited debt from \"medically necessary\" procedures from being reported\n*Placed greater delays on the reporting of other debt incurred from medical expenses\n\n\n in November 2019]]\nDuring the , Pressley endorsed .\n\nIn November 2019, Pressley endorsed Senator Elizabeth Warren for president ahead of the . This set Pressley apart from the other three members of \"The Squad\", who had endorsed . Pressley, who was named one of Warren's three national co-chairs, became a prominent surrogate on the campaign circuit. After Warren's withdrawal, Pressley did not transfer her support to  or Bernie Sanders until the time of the , when she endorsed Biden for president.\n\n\nPressley is a supporter of prison reform and supports programs for  that starts well before an inmate has been released from incarceration. In 2020, Pressley's husband, who spent ten years in prison, testified before the  saying \"All the other things that organizations can offer, like identification cards, are important, but it all starts with where you lay your head at night.\" In the autumn of 2019, Pressley introduced a resolution calling for an overhaul of the criminal justice system called the People's Justice Guarantee.\n\nIn early June 2020, Pressley and  representative  introduced the End Qualified Immunity Act. The act would remove from law enforcement officers, and other officials, the protection of  that had routinely protected them from prosecution when they could claim that acts that would otherwise trigger criminal charges had been committed as part of performing their official duties.\n\n\n (second from right) promoting their \"Freedom to Move\" legislation. They are joined by Boston Mayor  (second from left) and others]]\n\nPressley advocates for making  fare-free for users. In 2020, she co-authored the Freedom to Move Act with Senator , which would have offered $5 billion in annual competitive grants to  that offer fare-free transit access. She and Markey reintroduced the bill in April 2023.\n\nOn November 5, 2021, Pressley was one of six House Democrats who broke with their party and voted with a majority of Republicans against the , a $1.2trillion infrastructure spending bill.\n\n\nIn January 2023, Pressley was one of 13 cosponsors of an amendment to the  extending the right to vote to citizens sixteen years of age or older.\n\n\nPressley was among the 46 Democrats who voted against final passage of the  in the House.\n\n\n\n\nPressley lives in 's  neighborhood with her husband, Conan Harris, and her stepdaughter.\nIn January 2019, her husband resigned from his position as a senior public safety adviser at Boston City Hall to form his own , Conan Harris & Associates.\n\nPressley has stated that she is a \"woman of faith\" who \"grew up in the church\" and she is the granddaughter of a Baptist preacher.\n\nShe has been public about her experience as a survivor of child sexual abuse, and also of having been sexually assaulted while a student at Boston University.\n\nIn January 2020, Pressley revealed that she had been diagnosed with , resulting in the loss of all of her hair; she said in a public announcement, \"I want to be freed from the secret and the shame that that secret carries with it.\" In 2022, she appeared in the docuseries '''', where she discussed her experience of alopecia.\n\nPressley is a member of the  social and service organization .\n\n\n* 2012: Aspen-Rodel Fellow in Public Leadership, Class of 2012\n* 2012: Truman National Security Project Partner\n* 2014: Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce, 10 Outstanding Young Leaders\n* 2014: , Leadership Award\n* 2015: '''' magazine, 50 Most Powerful People\n* 2015: ,  Rising Star Award\n* 2016: '''', 14 Young Democrats to Watch\n* 2018: '''' magazine, 100 Most Influential People in Boston, #20\n* 2020: Children's HealthWatch Champion\n*2021: Doctor of Laws, '''' from \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n write-in votes\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\nEnd Qualified Immunity Act. Qualified immunity was created by the Supreme Court in contravention of the text of the [Civil Rights Act of 1871] and the intent of Congress, Amash argued in a letter urging colleagues to support his bill. It is time for us to correct their mistake [ ... and] ensure that those whose rights are violated by the police aren't forced to suffer the added injustice of being denied their day in court.\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* \n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n\n*  at \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Lincoln Hough''' (/ˈlɪŋkən hʌf/; born June 17, 1982) is an  politician. He was first elected to the Missouri House of Representatives in 2010, where he served three terms. He served as Greene County Commissioner from 2016 to 2018. In November 2018, he was elected to represent the 30th District, including the city of , in the Missouri Senate.\n\nHough is a candidate in the .\n\n\nHough is a first generation rancher. In 7th grade, he began raising cattle on his family's 40 acres after buying three heifers with a loan from his parents. He went on to work for a neighbor's dairy farm and learned skills to expand his own operations. \n\nHough graduated from  with a Bachelor’s Degree in Political Science. He has volunteered for the Greene County and Missouri Cattlemen's Association and currently serves on the Greene County Farm Bureau Board of Directors. \n\n\nIn the Missouri Senate, Hough sponsored the 2022 tax cut and pushed to expand infrastructure spending in Parson's plan to expand I-64. He has opposed hardline conservative members, the \"Freedom Caucus,\" in senate proceedings. In 2021, Hough voted to fund voter-approved  expansion. As appropriations committee chair, Hough set reimbursements for  to $0 in the 2024 state budget, a move the state supreme court ruled unconstitutional.\n\nHough's campaign for lieutenant governor received a total of $120,000 in a single day from PACs managed by former Missouri politician .\n\n\nHough has two sons.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Felicia A. Moore''' is an American politician who served as the president of the . She was elected to the office in a December 2017 runoff election. She previously held the post of City Council member for District 9, serving for 20 years.\n\nShe graduated from  in with a Bachelor of Arts in communication, where she became a member of the  sorority. She holds a Master of Science in Administration degree from  with a concentration in Public Administration.\n\n\nOn January 28, 2021, Moore announced her candidacy for Mayor of Atlanta in the . Her platform focuses on safer neighborhoods, government transparency, fiscal stability, and guaranteed city services.\n\nMoore placed first in the first round of the election, held on November 2, but lost the November 30 runoff to , winning 37% against Dickens' 63% of the vote. After her loss, she blamed the rappers  and  for turning public opinion against her, after they posted on social media that she had pledged to close all s in the city if elected. According to , Moore said that the claims originated from a quote taken out of context, when she expressed her opposition to issuing new permits to certain businesses, such as recording studios, and accused the rappers of spreading misinformation.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Martha Mary Coakley''' (born July 14, 1953) is an American lobbyist, lawyer, and former politician who served as  of  from 2007 to 2015.  Prior to serving as Attorney General, she was  of  from 1999 to 2007.\n\nCoakley was elected as attorney general of Massachusetts in 2006. She was the  nominee in the  to fill the  seat long held by  (and held in the interim by ), but was defeated 52% to 47% by   in what was widely considered an upset. She was re-elected as attorney general in the 2010 general election. Coakley ran for  in  as the  nominee but lost in another upset to Republican . Coakley was a lobbyist for the e-cigarette company  until June 2022.\n\n\nCoakley was born in , to Edward J. and Phyllis E. Coakley. Her father was a  veteran,  veteran, and small business owner. Her mother was a homemaker. When Coakley was one year old, she and her parents moved to . There, she attended  and , graduating in June 1971.\n\nCoakley graduated ''cum laude'' with a  from  in 1975 and a  from  in 1979. In the summer of 1978, while a law student, Coakley clerked for the law firm of Donovan and O'Connor of .  After graduating from law school, Coakley began work as an associate at the law firm of Parker, Coulter, Daley & White and later practiced at both in .\n\n\nShe joined the DA's office in 1986 as an Assistant District Attorney in the , District Court office. A year later, she was invited by the  to join its Boston Organized Crime Strike Force as a Special Attorney. Coakley returned to the District Attorney's office in 1989 and was appointed the Chief of the Child Abuse Prosecution Unit two years later.\n\nIn 1997, while serving under ,  , she and Gerry Leone led the courtroom prosecution of then 19-year-old English au pair , who was later convicted in the shaking death of eight-month-old Matthew Eappen of .\n\n\nIn 1997, a special election was held for Boston's 16th Suffolk district to replace , who was resigning. Five candidates, who all lived in the same Ward 16 neighborhood, including a \"thoughtful, but unknown assistant DA named Martha Coakley,\" entered the race. Coakley lost the race to , receiving 11.7 percent of the vote.\n\n\nIn December 1997, Coakley resigned her position in order to campaign for District Attorney in Middlesex County.\n\nIn 2001, Coakley successfully lobbied Acting Governor  to deny clemency to , a defendant in the , whom many regarded as a victim of . Clemency for Amirault had been recommended unanimously by the Massachusetts Parole Board.  Amirault's co-accused mother and sister had already been released from custody. ''Wall Street Journal'' editorial board member  cites Coakley's pursuit of the case despite lack of corroborating evidence as an example of questionable judgment on Coakley's part.\n\nCoakley's actions as District Attorney in the sexual abuse case of a 23-month-old girl in 2005 have drawn sharp criticism. Coakley, who oversaw the  for the case, did not immediately indict Keith Winfield, a  police officer. On August 1, 2006, after a criminal complaint was threatened to be filed by Larry Frisoli, attorney for the victim's single mother and the Republican candidate running against Coakley for Attorney General, she indicted Winfield. She requested for him to be released without cash bail. The District Attorney succeeding Coakley subsequently secured a conviction. Winfield was given two life sentences for the crime. Coakley later defended her actions by saying she acted appropriately with the evidence that was available at the time. As of 2012, film producer Steve Audette was making a documentary about Winfield's prosecution, conviction, and continued assertion of innocence; Audette was denied access to recordings of the trial in March 2013.\n\n\n\n\nCoakley was elected  in the  as a , defeating Republican Larry Frisoli with 73 percent of the vote. She was sworn in on January&nbsp;17, 2007. Coakley became the first woman to serve as Attorney General in Massachusetts.\n\nDuring the  in January 2007, Coakley was widely quoted in the press defending the reaction of Boston's emergency services. Small electronic signs advertising a cartoon had been mistaken for bombs; Massachusetts authorities halted traffic on two bridges and closed the Charles River before realizing the signs were harmless. Coakley defended the precautions because the LED signs had looked suspicious: \"It had a very sinister appearance, it had a battery behind it, and wires.\"\n\nBoth of those accused of putting up the signs which caused the bomb scare were given plea bargains, received community service and apologized publicly.\n\nIn May 2007, Coakley testified before the Massachusetts State Legislature in support of the passage of a  that created a  buffer around entrances and driveways of reproductive health care facilities that offer abortion services. The law was signed into effect by Governor Deval Patrick on November 13, 2007, and was subsequently challenged by opponents and overturned by a unanimous decision of the Supreme Court as a violation of the .\n\nThe next month, she signed a ''Guide to Consumer Credit'' and activated a Consumer Complaint and Information Hotline for helping people in financial difficulties.\n\nIn September 2008, Coakley worked with  and the  to have Apple redesign the popular  so it would comply with the federal , as well as the Massachusetts Equal Rights Act.\n\nIn November 2008, Coakley unsuccessfully argued the case of '''' before the .\n\nOn February 5, 2009, she led an 18-state coalition, as well as the  for the  and the  of , urging the  to take action in response to the 2007  ruling in .  Though the Supreme Court ruled that the EPA did have the authority to regulate greenhouse gases under the , the Agency had yet to make an official decision on whether it believes that greenhouse gas emissions pose dangers to public health or welfare.\n\nCoakley inherited litigation of the fatal 2006  from outgoing Attorney General Tom Reilly in 2007. On March&nbsp;26, 2009, she settled the final lawsuit pertaining to the incident.  Through eight lawsuits attached to the incident, Coakley's office recovered $610.625&nbsp;million on behalf of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.\n\nCoakley declined to conduct a criminal investigation of an aide to , Mayor of Boston, for allegedly violating laws regarding the destruction of public e-mail records, describing the request as politically motivated.\n\nOn July 8, 2009, Coakley  challenging the constitutionality of the . The suit claims that Congress \"overstepped its authority, undermined states' efforts to recognize marriages between same-sex couples, and codified an animus towards gay and lesbian people.\"  Massachusetts is the first state to challenge the legislation.\n\nIn 2009, Coakley won settlements of $60&nbsp;million from  and $10&nbsp;million from Fremont Investment & Loan for their abuse of subprime loans and lending.\n\nIn 2010, Coakley helped draft a Massachusetts law regulating obscenity on the internet. In a decision celebrated by civil rights advocates, the law was overturned by a federal judge after a coalition of booksellers and website publishers sued, claiming the new law was unconstitutional and would hold criminally liable anyone who operates a website containing nudity or sexual material, including subjects such as art or even health information such as pregnancy or birth control. They said the law failed to distinguish between open websites and obscene material. Federal Judge Rya W. Zobel stated that the plaintiffs demonstrated \"without question\" that the law violated the First Amendment by infringing on and inhibiting free speech.\n\nDuring Coakley's tenure as Attorney General, misconduct at Massachusetts' crime laboratories led to the reexamination of tens of thousands of drug convictions.  Chemist  was accused of forging reports and tampering with samples to produce desired results. Similarly, Sonja Farak was accused of tampering with the evidence she was tasked with analyzing by using it to get high herself. The actions of both women, who acted independently, resulted in tens of thousands of drug counts being dismissed, the largest single mass dismissal of criminal cases in U.S. history.  '''' is an American   miniseries that was released on  on April 1, 2020, that was created by , who followed the aftereffects of this notorious case.  ''How to Fix a Drug Scandal'' depicts the role of Martha Coakley, who was accused of political cover up.\n\n\n\n\nMartha Coakley finished  with 12% of the primary vote in her first run for office against future Boston Mayor and US Secretary of Labor  (33%), neighborhood activist Charles Tevnan (16%) and Edward Regal (10%).\n\n\nMartha Coakley won the Democratic primary (48%) against  (28%) and Timothy Flaherty (25%) and coasted to a 71–29% general election win against Republican Lee Johnson.\n\n\nMartha Coakley was unopposed in both the primary and the general election.\n\n\n\nMartha Coakley was unopposed in the Democratic primary.  She won the General election (73%-27%) against Republican Larry Frisoli.\n\n\n\nOn September 1, 2009, Coakley was the first candidate to take out nomination papers to run in a special election to succeed the late  in the  in the . Two days later, on September 3, Coakley officially announced her candidacy on her website. She won the Democratic primary on December 8, 2009. Her opponents were Republican  and Libertarian  (no relation to the ). Coakley was endorsed by '''' on January 14, 2010.\nIn her last television debate January 11, 2010, at the , when asked about the prospects of victory in , Coakley stated, \"I think we have done what we are going to be able to do in Afghanistan. I think that we should plan an . Yes. I'm not sure there is a way to succeed. If the goal was and the mission in Afghanistan was to go in because we believed that the  was giving harbor to terrorists, we supported that. I supported that. They're gone. They're not there anymore. They're in, apparently , they're in . Let's focus our efforts on where  is.\" This statement drew criticism from  and his supporters, including .\n\n, Rappaport Professor of Law and Public Policy, hosted the roundtable.]]\n\nCoakley committed a number of gaffes during the campaign. When criticized for leaving the state for a Washington fundraiser instead of campaigning, Coakley responded by saying \"As opposed to standing outside Fenway Park? In the cold? Shaking hands?\" , in reflecting on his presidency, cited this comment as an instigating factor for Coakley's election loss, as well as a hurdle for the . Coakley also referred to  star  and Brown supporter  as \"another  fan,\" making her a target of derision.\n\nCoakley admitted to making a mistake while filing the financial disclosure forms for her Senate run, claiming to have no personal assets when she had an account under her husband's name with over $200,000 and a personal  containing approximately $12,000.\n\nOn January 19, 2010, Coakley was defeated by Brown 52% to 47% in the special election. Brown received 1,168,107 votes, Coakley received 1,058,682 votes, and Joseph L. Kennedy received 22,237 votes.\n\n\n\nCoakley successfully ran for reelection, defeating her main challenger, Republican nominee Jim McKenna.Estes, Andrea (January 21, 2010). \".\" ''The Boston Globe''. Retrieved February 19, 2010.Phillips, Frank (September 16, 2010). \"\" ''The Boston Globe.'' Retrieved September 17, 2010.\n\n\n\nOn September 15, 2013, WCVB-TV learned of Coakley's intention to run for the Massachusetts governorship when incumbent Democrat  retired in 2014. Coakley was set to formally announce her entry into the race the following Monday. She won the Democratic nomination on September 9, 2014. On November 4, 2014, she was narrowly defeated in the general election for governor by Republican , who was endorsed by the ''Boston Globe'' despite the ''Globe'''s having endorsed Coakley four years prior in her Senate campaign.\n\nAfter the election, the ''Globe'' wrote that Coakley had been \"redeemed, even in defeat,\" saying that she had been \"haunted\" by her failed bid for the U.S. Senate four years earlier and had been a \"relentless, and frequently terrific, campaigner. Coakley worked her heart out meeting voters across the state. She arrived at the rationale for her candidacy that eluded her four years ago: She had proven she cares about the state's most vulnerable citizens.\" The ''Globe'' added that \"this person of remarkable accomplishments, grace, and resilience looks to be leaving public life. That's a big loss.\"\n\n\nFrom 2015 through early 2019, Coakley worked for , a Boston-based , as a lawyer and . While at the firm, Coakley represented the fantasy sports website  and student-loan firm  when state governments were examining the practices of these industries.\n\nIn April 2019, it was announced that Coakley had taken a full-time role with  maker  on their government affairs team. As a former attorney general, lobbying attorneys general for the vaping industry has called into question the ethics of Coakley's work for Juul, a leader in the electronic cigarette industry accused of marketing addictive nicotine products to youths.\n\n\nCoakley resides in . She is married to retired police Deputy Superintendent Thomas F. O'Connor Jr.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*  official Massachusetts government website\n* \n* \n*  at the ''''\n*  Collected news and commentary] at ''''\n*  from \n* , Martha Coakley, '''', January 15, 2010\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Donna T. McLeod''' (born March 19, 1968) is a Jamaican-born  politician from Georgia. McLeod is a former member of the  from the 105th District from 2019 to 2023. She is the first Jamaican-American to become a Representative in Georgia. She defeated   in the  to replace retiring Representative .\n\n\nShe served as the  Committee Chair for Voter Outreach and Outreach for the Gwinnett County Democratic Party and continues to be an active member of the Gwinnett Democrats.\n\nMs. McLeod was a grassroots organizer for Senator Obama’s 2008 campaign. In 2012, she was National Director for Voter Outreach for Black Women for Obama.\n\nIn 2016, she ran for State House Representative, District 105, in Gwinnett County, GA. Ms. McLeod was endorsed by President Barack Obama. She lost the race by 222 votes. Ms. McLeod ran again for State House Representative, District 105 in 2018. On November 6, 2018, she was elected State Representative for District 105, winning with over 4000 votes. In 2018, she also earned the endorsements of both President Barack Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder.\n\nDuring the 2019 Legislative Session, Representative McLeod worked with the Department of Corrections and the Department of Community Services to update their release documents to ensure that Ex-Felons that have served their time will be informed that their Voting Rights are restored.\n\nMcLeod is a co-founder of C.A.N.I, Inc., (Community Action Network Initiatives) a non-profit 501c3 organization that helps educate and inform people of their civic and societal rights and responsibilities.\n\n\nOn March 19, 1968, McLeod was born in . She migrated to Canada in 1977, where she grew up. She moved to Georgia in 1998 and became a US citizen in 2012.\n\n\nIn 1989, McLeod earned a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from Humber College.\n\n\nDonna McLeod is a chemical engineer with over 30 years of experience in quality assurance management/ engineering; she is now the president/CEO of Enviroqual, LLC, a quality assurance/regulatory consulting company specializing in medical devices, food, plastics, and pharmaceuticals.\n\nMcLeod first ran to represent District 105 in the Georgia House of Representatives in 2016, but lost the general election to incumbent . In 2018, she ran again, and defeated Republican . In 2020 she ran for a third time and defeated Erik Dieks.\n\nMcLeod sat on the following committees:\n* Code Revision\n* Human Relations & Aging\n* Interstate Cooperation\n* Science and Technology\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2018, Mcleod was unopposed in the Democratic primary for the District 105 seat.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nShe was awarded the Georgia Secretary of State Outstanding Citizen Award in 2015, RevUp’s Sankofa Leadership in 2017, Gwinnett County Democratic Party Leadership/Service Award in 2017, and Freedom Fighter Award from the Family in 2018. She also sits on the STEM Board at Discovery High School.\n\nIn December 2022, Donna McLeod was recognized by the Jamaican Museum and Cultural Center (JMCC) in Atlanta for her outstanding representation as a leader and mentor to her constituents as the first Jamaican-American to become a Representative in the state of Georgia.\n\n\n in 2019]]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ryan C. Fattman''' (born July 1, 1984) is an American politician who currently serves in the . Previously, Fattman represented the  in the  as a .\n\n\nA native of , Fattman graduated from  in 2003. He then received a  in  from  in 2007 and a  from  in 2010. While at Tufts, Fattman received a Public Policy Summer Fellowship from the  of .\n\n\nIn 2006, while a student at Suffolk, Fattman launched his political career by announcing his candidacy for the Sutton Board of Selectman. On May 23, he earned seventy-percent of the vote, defeating two long-term incumbents. At the age of twenty-two, Fattman became the youngest  in the history of the town and . He was reelected in 2009 for a second term that lasted until 2011. During Fattman's tenure, he was credited with the restoration of Marion's Camp, a public  in Sutton, senior citizen property tax relief, town capital stabilization, and improved  coverage. He also worked as a  Analyst for MassHousing during this time.\n\nIn 2010, Fattman ran for a seat in the . In a close race, he defeated the eight-year incumbent  for the  seat. The ''Worcester Telegram'' described the win as \"the most surprising upset\" in . The '''' called Fattman the \"...new standard bearer for beleaguered Massachusetts Republications.\" He remained in the House for two terms from 2011 through 2015.\n\nIn 2014, Fattman was elected to the , becoming the first Republican to hold the  seat since 1938. He defeated the twenty-two year incumbent .\n\nOn March 17, 2021, Fattman and members of the Republican Town Committee in Sutton filed a lawsuit against Michael Sullivan, Director of the Massachusetts Office of Campaign and Political Finance, concerning the manner in which the office was conducting investigations into potential violations of state campaign finance rules by Fattman and related campaign committees. A request by Fattman and the other  to block Sullivan from providing evidence to the  was denied on March 30. Fattman has denied the allegations and insisted that all campaign contributions were legal and common practice.\n\n\nFattman met his wife, Stephanie Kotseas, at Sutton High School. She is currently the  . The couple, who has four children, currently resides in , .\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Geoffrey G. Diehl''' (born April 23, 1969) is an American politician from the  of . A , he represented the  in the  from 2011 to 2019.\n\nDiehl was the unsuccessful Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate in  and for governor of Massachusetts in , losing both elections in landslides to   and  respectively.\n\n\nGeoff Diehl was born in Austin, Texas. At the age of 3, his family moved to . He attended  and graduated from  in 1992 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in government and urban studies.\n\n\nAfter graduating, Diehl moved to New York City and worked in advertising. He later worked in television production in . In 2001, he moved to his wife's hometown of , where he worked as a business development executive in the sign industry. He also supported his wife in successfully starting and running a performing arts school, Boss Academy.\n\n\n\nDiehl began his campaign to represent the 7th Plymouth District on February 22, 2010. Diehl received support from previous representatives from the same district, including , , Ned Kirby, and . Diehl also received the endorsement of U.S. Senator .\n\nOn November 2, 2010, he upset incumbent  and was sworn in on January 5, 2011.\n\nHe was a member of the Joint Committee on Housing, House Committee on Global Warming and Climate Change, and the House Committee on Technology and Intergovernmental Affairs.\n\n\nGeoff Diehl was a lead supporter of the successful  in 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn April 2017, Diehl announced his intent to challenge  for her . In the Republican  held on September 4, 2018, Diehl finished first in a field of three candidates. The incumbent, , defeated Diehl by 24 percentage points.\n\n\n\nOn July 4, 2021, Geoff Diehl announced he was running for . In October 2021, Donald Trump endorsed Geoff Diehl for governor.\nHe was  Massachusetts state co-chair of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and a Trump delegate to the . Diehl also supported , the chairman of the Massachusetts Republican Party, who in January 2021 was reelected to the party chairmanship after defeating a challenge from .\n\nAs a candidate, Diehl criticized federal and state mandates put in place during the  and continuously supported workers and first responders being fired for not taking the vaccine. He is a proponent of parents who want to decide for their children whether or not they would like a vaccine.\n\nAt the state party convention on May 21, Diehl was officially endorsed by the Massachusetts Republican Party with 71% of the delegates' votes. He won the Republican nomination on September 6. On November 8,  and Democratic nominee  handily defeated Diehl in the general election.\n\n\nOn December 11, 2023 Diehl filed campaign finance paper, changing his accounts' office sought to the Second Plymouth and Norfolk, currently held by Senator . Diehl had previously matched up against Brady in a 2015 special election for the same seat.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBefore he entered politics, Diehl was a member of the Whitman Finance Committee. He remains a member of the MetroSouth Chamber of Commerce and South Shore Chamber of Commerce. Diehl is also an . Diehl and his wife, KathyJo, have two daughters. They live in .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| birth_place         = , , U.S.\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| education           =  (, , )\n| signature           = Nikki Fried signature (PNG transparent).png\n| website             = \n| spouse              = Jake Bergmann (engaged)\n}}\n'''Nicole Heather Fried''' ( ; born December 13, 1977) is an American lawyer and politician who has served as the chair of the  since 2023. Prior to her election as chair, Fried served as the 12th  from 2019 to 2023. Fried graduated from the  in 2003. She has previously practiced various forms of law, including , , and . Fried has also been a prominent  for the  in the state of .\n\nShe won the , narrowly defeating state representative  by less than 7,000 votes out of over eight million votes cast, a margin of 0.08%. Fried is the first woman to be elected to the position and was the only Democrat to win a statewide race in the . During her tenure, she redesigned gas pump stickers, promoted a  bill, partook in '''' over waters within the , and appointed two lobbyists for the Florida Sugar Cane League.\n\nFried was selected as one of 17 speakers to jointly deliver the  address at the . She did not seek re-election in 2022, instead running in the . Fried was defeated in the Democratic primary by U.S. representative and former Republican governor .\n\n\nNicole Heather Fried was born December 13, 1977, in , to Ronald, an attorney, and Lori, a stay-at-home mother. Her parents divorced when she was 13, leaving Fried and her younger sister to be raised primarily by their mother, who became a preschool teacher after the divorce. Fried graduated from .\n\nFried graduated from the , where she was  and a member of , receiving her  in  and her  in . In 2003, she received her  from the University of Florida.\n\n\nAfter graduating, Fried worked at the law firm of  in , alongside , a friend of Fried from the University of Florida who would later serve alongside her as the . Unhappy working as a , Fried left Holland & Knight in 2006 and became a  for , which covers much of , including .\n\nFried was a  lawyer from 2009 until 2011, when she joined the law and lobbying firm of Colodny Fass. Among her major clients as a lobbyist were the , the , , and .\n\nIn 2016, Fried established her own lobbying firm, called Igniting Florida, in . Her main clients were the  and the statewide  industry, which had recently blossomed following the passage of , which legalized medical marijuana, in the 2016 elections.\n\n\n\n\nFried won the  nomination for  in , easily defeating Jeff Porter, the mayor of  and R. David Walker, an environmental activist, despite her primary opponents criticizing her for her past campaign contributions to .\n\nIn the general election, Fried faced off against the Republican nominee , a  from . Fried ran on a platform in favor of removing obstacles to  in Florida. She described herself as \"a fierce advocate for expanding access to medical marijuana for suffering Floridians\", and called for placing regulation of medical marijuana under the jurisdiction of the  rather than the .\n\nDuring the campaign, Fried also pledged to \"ensure full background checks are completed on gun permits\", a task which falls under the jurisdiction of the Florida Department of Agriculture. Fried endorsed , a  which restores  for , excluding murderers and felony sex offenders.\n\nOn August 19, 2018,  announced it was closing Fried's campaign bank account because of her ties with medical marijuana. Fried's campaign transferred the $137,000 in the account to a new bank account with . However, on August 29, 2018, BB&T also announced the closure of Fried's campaign bank account on the same grounds.\n\nFried was endorsed by the '''', the '''', and the ''''. Fried also received the endorsements of the , , , and the , while Caldwell received the endorsements of business and industry groups, including the Florida Farm Bureau, the , and the Associated Industries of Florida.\n\nFried defeated Caldwell by an extremely narrow margin. While initial returns on  showed Caldwell in the lead, by the completion of the count, Fried had narrowly taken the lead with a margin of just 0.06% of votes separating the two candidates. Following both a machine recount and a manual recount, Fried ultimately defeated Caldwell by 6,753 votes (0.08%) out of over eight million votes cast. Fried became the first Democrat to win the Florida Commissioner of Agriculture position since 1998, as well as becoming the only woman elected to the position. She was also the only Democratic candidate to win a statewide race in Florida in 2018.\n\n\n in 2019]]\nShortly after entering office in 2019, Fried's office redesigned the Florida Department of Agriculture's certified  stickers, which verify to customers the gas pump is state approved. Previous commissioners had put their own names on the stickers for decades, but Fried was the first to put a color photograph of herself on the sticker. The  accused Fried of using taxpayer funds to increase her political exposure, and the  quickly passed a law limiting the taxpayer-funded stickers to only \"a combination of lettering, numbering, words, or the department logo\". The stickers were quickly replaced with a new design that did not have her photograph.\n\nFried opposed the , the  that officially replaced the 1994 , on the basis that it contained insufficient protections for Florida farmers.\n\nFried also crafted legislation with Democratic state representative  targeting . The bill, HB 809, would have required retention of  records, require proof of completion of  for a license to be renewed and reduce the term for a  from seven to five years. It did not pass the legislature in 2019.\n\nIn August 2019, the Florida Department of Agriculture appointed two registered lobbyists for the Florida Sugar Cane League to consult on the  System Operating Manual Project Delivery Team, which was set to advise the  on procedures for lake levels. Environmentalists called for lake levels to be lowered to prevent harmful discharges and s, while the  advocated for keeping levels high to avoid the threat of low water supply for farmers and municipalities. Republican  , whose district includes part of Lake Okeechobee, sent a letter to the Army Corps of Engineers seeking the lobbyists' removal, alleging the appointments were an attempt to force sugar industry influence into the process. Seven Florida environmental groups, including  and Everglades Trust, called for the members to be removed and criticized their appointment. While Fried originally defended the appointments as expert consultants, she later fired their consulting firm and removed them from working on the project.\n and Governor, in 2019]]\nIn December 2019, Fried abstained from a  vote for the nominee for commissioner of the Florida Office of Financial Regulation, Russell Weigel. However, Florida state law states that cabinet officials can not abstain from cabinet votes unless there is a conflict of interest. Fried said she had concerns over the transparency of the nomination and said her interpretation of the law did not mandate her to vote yes or no.\n\nIn 2020, Fried's office requested and was granted federal waivers to provide  to students, despite schools being closed because of the .\n\nLater in 2020, Fried partly delivered the  at the , joining 16 other speakers designated as \"rising stars\". Fried critiqued President 's response to the , and reiterated the Democratic Party's commitment to fighting .\n\n\n\nBeginning in 2018, Fried was engaged in a lawsuit against the state of , claiming it was siphoning too much water for use from the , a part of the  system, which flows south into Florida before draining into . The lawsuit alleged that Georgia's use of too much water caused an increase in  in the  estuary, subsequently causing the collapse of the estuary's  , resulting in income and job losses of 98% of the value of Florida's oyster industry.\n\nThe lawsuit, initiated by the state of Florida in 2013 following a , was dismissed in 2016 by  appointed by the . However, the Supreme Court ruled 5–4 in  (2018) that the case should be reheard and reviewed.\n\nIn April 2021, the US Supreme Court ruled 9–0 in favor of Georgia in  (2021). The unanimous opinion, written by Justice , stated that Fried had not provided sufficient evidence that Georgia's water use had resulted in the oyster fisheries' collapse.  Fried had chosen not to present the testimony of either  or , instead relying only on reports from  and .\n\n\n\nOn June 1, 2021, Fried declared her candidacy for  in the . She lost to , a  and the former governor of Florida, in the Democratic primary.\n\nBefore her entry into the race, Fried heavily criticized DeSantis, calling him an \" dictator who is borderline \", and attacked him for his response to the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as his signing of an  that she called . Fried also criticized the \"rigged system in Florida\", which she called corrupt and .\n\nFried differentiated herself from Crist, who has been a politician since his election to the  in 1992, by taking the campaign slogan \"Something New\". She described Crist's former affiliation with the Republican Party and criticized him for his support for  legislation throughout his career. Fried blamed Crist for creating Florida's contemporary unemployment system, which collapsed during the COVID-19 pandemic; however, the system was not created by Crist, but by his gubernatorial successor .\n\n\nOn April 3, 2023, Fried, now the chair of the , was arrested alongside , the minority leader of the , following a protest of an anti-abortion bill being considered by state lawmakers. The bill would ban abortions after six weeks. Fried and ten others were arrested for trespassing after the  instructed them to disperse by sunset, which they did not do.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFried is vocal about her practice of . While in high school, she was a participant in , a Jewish . Fried also actively considered making  to  and joining the . After her election as agriculture commissioner, Fried was sworn into office using the first  published in the United States.\n\nFried is a registered  in the state of Florida. In 2023 she was named to the board of directors of the  (NORML).\n\n\nFried's fiancé, Jake Bergmann, is a prominent  entrepreneur in Florida. Her relationship with him has been criticized as a conflict of interest, as Bergmann's business often results in dealings with the Florida Department of Agriculture.\n\nIn June 2020, Fried and Bergmann engaged in a verbal argument at a hotel in  resulting from a car accident in the hotel's parking lot. A security guard who witnessed the incident claimed Bergmann threw a trash can and shoved Fried, though Fried denies the latter.  escorted Bergmann off the property and a formal police report was filed; no arrest was made. Following the incident, Fried denied Bergmann was physically abusive to her and replaced a number of high-level staffers who criticized him.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n|years=2019–2023}}\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Valencia Stovall''' (born December 16, 1969) is an American politician who served as an  state representative in the  from 2013 to 2021. She ran as an independent in the  as well as for the  from  in 2022.\n\n\n\nValencia Stovall was raised in Southeast Atlanta with her two sisters by parents Lovett and Nancy Stovall. She attended Benteen Elementary School and Southside High School where she received the Coca-Cola Fanta Sports Award for excellence in basketball. She also played softball, and ran track. Valencia studied business administration at Fort Valley State College and management at Georgia State University. She is a member of  sorority.\n\nShe first got involved in politics through her father Lovett Stovall who was a part of President Jimmy Carter's Peanut Brigade. He also was a key component in the elections of Atlanta Mayors Maynard H. Jackson and Shirley Franklin.\n\nStovall served as PTA President for her children’s elementary and middle schools and as Secretary & Treasurer of Atlanta Council of PTAs where she was a recipient of the Apple Core Service Award.\n\n\n\nValencia's mother and father started a T-shirt printing business in 1983 which later became Stovall's T-shirts. For 30 years the commercial printing business contracted with public and private educational institutions, 100 plus businesses, over 75 athletic teams, 200 plus family reunions with a minimum of 100 members, over 50 civic organizations, over 100 religious organizations that has 100 plus membership, and over 50 governmental agencies, conducted training classes in printing and business development to local residents, and operated multiple retail stores across Metro Atlanta.\n\nIn 1991, Stovall's Enterprises entered into a joint venture contract with Facility Merchandising Inc. to oversee retail development and merchandising operations for the Georgia Dome. For 14 years FMI-Stovall managed the retail operations for the NFL Atlanta Falcons, SEC Championship Games, two NFL Super Bowls, Chick-fil-A Peach Bowl, Atlanta Hawks, Motorsport Events, The Rolling Stones, and U2.\n\nFMI-Stovall also managed the retail and parking operations for the 1996 Olympic Games held in Atlanta, Georgia.\n\nStovall Enterprises, Inc. also managed retail operations for the University of Georgia Stanford Stadium, Coco Cola/Lakewood Amphitheater, and Atlanta Fulton County Stadium.\n\n\n\nValencia served as the Board Chair of Scholars Academy Special State Charter School which she restructured the organization through strategic planning, lead real estate acquisition and development, directed financial and legal negotiations, implemented growth capital programs, ensured personnel restructuring and development, re-engineered business processes, instilled urgency for financial discipline, and capitalized on growth opportunities with local community partners.\n\nShe also served as the Executive Board Member for the Atlanta Council of PTA’s in which she oversaw the executive financial operation and development for 90 schools.\n\nFor two years she served as the co-founder of the Morrow Community Fall Festival which drew over 5,000 attendees to this unity in the community event.\n\n\n\nA moderate Democrat, Stovall worked with both liberals and conservatives to develop a $45 million grant for local governments, passed legislation to protect special needs students, authored legislation to reform Georgia’s education funding formula, co-authored legislation for teacher loan forgiveness and co-sponsored over a dozen bills to improve the lives of Georgians that have been signed into law.\n\nShe instrumented the development of a House Study Committee to support Georgia farmers through the revitalization of the Atlanta State Farmers Market, developed a special House Committee to engage stakeholders across Georgia on school redesign and have served on over twenty-one committees, state commissions and non-profit boards including:\n\n* Chair, House Study Committee on the Revitalization of the Atlanta State Farmers Market\n* Chair, House Education Special Sub-committee on School Redesign\n* Vice Chair, House Education Sub-committee on Academic Achievement\n* Chair, Environmental Assessment Survey Project\n* Vice-Chair, Medical Cannabis Working Group\n* Co-Chair United Way THRIVE Clayton\n* Co-Founder Georgia Single Parent Day Legacy Builders Event\n* Co-Founder Yoruba African Tribe Festival\n\nStovall also served as Chairman of the Clayton County Delegation, Secretary of the Clayton State University Dean of Arts & Science Advisory Committee, Commissioner on Governor Nathan Deal's Education Reform Commission, and member of the Georgia Quality Rated Advisory Committee. She is a 2015 Council of State Governments Henry Toll Fellow and was recognized as a Woman in Politics Making A Difference by the National Council of State Governments.\n\n\n\nStovall served on the following committees:\n\n*Economic Development and Tourism\n*Education\n*Interstate Cooperation\n*Small Business Development\n\n\n* \n\n\n \n \n \n \n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

Williamson and his family live in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
