    "pages": }\n'''Larry Paul Langford''' (March 18, 1946 – January 8, 2019) was an American politician who had a one-term tenure as the mayor of the city of , Alabama. At the time of his death, Langford was hospitalized on compassionate release from serving a 15-year federal prison sentence.\n\n\n\nLangford was born in Birmingham on March 18, 1946. He graduated from  before entering the . He graduated from the  in 1972 with a Bachelor of Science degree in social and .\n\n\nLangford was a  for WBRC-6, which at the time was the  affiliate in Birmingham, during the mid 1970s. He was the community's first African-American TV news reporter. He was later a  director for a Birmingham  distributor. Prior to entering politics, Langford was a well known local television personality.\n\n\nLangford, a , was elected to the county commission in 2002. His colleagues on the five-member commission elected Langford as commission president, the first African-American to hold the office.\n\nHe also served as mayor of , and served one term on the Birmingham City Council.\n\nLangford raised money and generated public interest and support for Visionland Theme Park (now known as ), located near . The park was built largely by  issues backed by a  of municipalities in the western part of the county, as well as the city of Birmingham and the county government. The park later declared bankruptcy, and was sold to  for just over $5&nbsp;million at auction.\n\nAs Fairfield mayor, Langford spoke publicly many times about his plans to run for higher office, particularly . After the bankruptcy of Visionland, Langford's political fortunes seemed to wane, and his talk of higher office diminished. After losing the county commission presidency, Langford announced on June 5, 2007, that he would run for mayor of Alabama's largest city.\n\nLangford stunned many when he emerged as a top contender in a field of 10 candidates that included incumbent mayor . Preliminary results credited him with 26,277 of 52,111 votes cast in the election, meaning that he avoided a runoff with challenger Patrick Cooper by 170 votes. Cooper then challenged the election in court, saying that Langford was still a resident of Fairfield and did not legally reside within Birmingham's city limits. Cooper later withdrew his case after a judge declared Langford's downtown loft a legal residence.\n\nWhile in office Langford was a member of the ,  an anti-gun group with a stated goal of \"making the public safer by getting illegal guns off the streets and that at the time was co-chaired by Boston Mayor  and New York City Mayor .\n\nLangford was long a proponent of a d stadium for the city, intended to replace the aging  as a venue for  on the collegiate and professional levels. He previously promoted a tax hike to pay for the dome, which was soundly rejected by voters a decade earlier under then-Mayor , although later analysis of votes showed an overwhelming support for the dome inside city limits. After taking office as Birmingham mayor, Langford vowed that a domed stadium would be built in the city no matter what.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n sack, speaks to a crowd at Boutwell Auditorium on April 22, 2008]]\nLangford, who converted to Catholicism in 1996, was both praised and criticized for the degree to which his Christian faith informed his political agenda. He held Bible studies for municipal workers at City Hall each week and was a frequent speaker at public prayer services and church events.\n\nOn April 22, 2008, Langford issued a proclamation on city letterhead proclaiming the following Friday to be \"It's Time to Pray\" in the City of Birmingham. He called upon \"all Bishops, Priests, Pastors, s and all of our citizens of various denominations and creeds\" to join him in donning  sacks and having their heads smeared with ashes during a prayer rally at .  Inspired by a custom described in the Bible of putting on “sackcloth with ashes” as a sign of mourning, the display was intended to show humility and restore God's favor to a city Langford described as wracked with violence. Anticipating complaints from defenders of the , Langford stated that \"the Constitution of the United States calls for a separation of church and state – it never said anything about a separation of church from state.\"\n\n\nLangford injured relations with the Birmingham  community in May 2008 when he refused to sign a proclamation for the annual Central Alabama , an event that had been held on the city's south side every year since 1989. He refused to allow banners on city property for the event. Langford further stated that it was inappropriate for the government to condone a lifestyle. He was quoted as saying: \"My policy is don't ask because it's not my business, and don't put me in the position to make it my business.\"\n\n\"I thought I had stated my position very clearly. If I were to sign the permit to put up banners on city right of ways I would be condoning that which I don't condone,\" he said. \"To give a proclamation is totally under the purview of the mayor.\"\n\n, an LGBTQ legal advocacy group, and Birmingham civil rights attorney David Gespass filed suit on behalf of the Central Alabama Pride group against Larry Langford seeking an order from the courts to prohibit the mayor from discriminating against LGBTQ organizations in administering city services. The organization hoped to use a ruling in their favor to discourage further discriminatory practices in Birmingham and other cities where the legal precedent would apply. A settlement agreement was reached on September 1, 2009. The settlement, reached after a federal judge ruled against the city and mayor in their efforts to have the case dismissed, comes after Lambda Legal and local attorney David Gespass filed the lawsuit in August 2008 in the Northern District of Alabama on behalf of CAP based on Mayor Langford's actions in refusing to allow city workers to attach Pride banners on city light posts. Members of CAP were allowed, however, to hang the banners on their own after paying the expense of bucket trucks. CAP members alleged that they had been allowed in previous years to hang Gay Pride banners displayed in accordance with the city's practice of attaching banners for a variety of organizations that have held events in the city. However, in May 2008, the mayor announced that he would neither sign a proclamation nor allow city workers to hang the banners based on his religious beliefs that do not \"condone that lifestyle choice.\" This lawsuit followed initial unsuccessful efforts to negotiate the passage of an even-handed policy.  represented the city and the mayor.\n\n\nIn addition to advocating the construction of a domed football stadium, Langford frequently proposed unique and ambitious projects for Birmingham. To overcome the city's mass transit problems, he suggested spending millions on retro-style trolleys. Though Birmingham is more than  inland from the , Langford proposed that a canal be constructed from the  so that cruise ships could dock in the city. He also suggested building a new structure, modeled after , which would house the city jail, police headquarters, fire department headquarters, a police academy, and public works offices. Langford told the Birmingham City Council that he intended to file the paperwork, along with the $500,000 fee, necessary for Birmingham to be a contender to host the 2020 Olympics.\n\nOn March 3, 2009, Mayor Langford proposed to the city council that a DVD video be distributed to inner city youth. The video decries \"black on black\" violence, calling black on black crimes a cultural genocide. The highly controversial DVD, which the local NBC news affiliate referred to as having striking images with racial overtones, depicts images of slavery and the 1960s civil rights movement.\n\n\nOn July 21, 2009, Langford gave the entire Birmingham City Council small ceramic unicorns as a response to Birmingham City Council President  comment that agreeing to the finance director's projection of available revenue in 2010 was the equivalent of saying, \"We believe in unicorns.\"\n\nFollowing the gift, Langford explained his belief that the unicorn had been a unifying symbol during the reign of  who brought together England and Scotland. According to Langford, the gift was meant as a gesture of solidarity.\n\n\nIn May 2008, the  Department of Health began posting advertisements on buses in Birmingham to promote testing and treatment for . At the time, Jefferson County faced the highest concentration of syphilis cases in the United States, prompting the public outreach campaign. Soon after, Langford controversially ordered the advertisements to be removed, arguing that public recognition of the public health crisis would discourage businesses from investing in the city.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2007, Langford was investigated by the  (SEC). On April 30, 2008, the SEC charged Langford in federal court with corruption. The lawsuit alleged Langford accepted more than $156,000 in cash and benefits from Montgomery investment banker  in exchange for county bond business.\n\nOn December 1, 2008, Langford, along with Blount and former state Democratic Chairman Al LaPierre, were arrested by the  on a 101-count indictment alleging , bribery, fraud, , and filing false tax returns in connection with a long-running bribery scheme. Langford was led into the courtroom in leg-irons.   His public corruption trial ended on October 28, 2009, with convictions on 60 counts, and resulted in his automatic removal from office.\n\n\nWhile Langford was head of the Jefferson County commission, he engaged in a variable-rate auction and bond swaps to raise money to help improve the county's sewer system. Langford was convicted of receiving $235,000 in bribes to help influence the bond deals. According to the indictment, William Blount helped Langford receive a $50,000 loan, which was used to purchase jewelry, including a Rolex watch, and designer clothes. Blount's firm earned $7.1&nbsp;million in fees from the bond deals while LaPierre was paid $219,500 by Blount for his help the scheme. Jefferson County banks made approximately $120&nbsp;million by encouraging the county to refinance nearly all of its bonds using swaps. The bonds resulted in a $3.2&nbsp;billion sewer debt, contributing to the Jefferson County commissioners voting to declare bankruptcy on November 10, 2011, in what at the time was the largest municipal bankruptcy in U.S. history. The U.S. government sought $7.6&nbsp;million in forfeiture from the three men.\n\nAfter being convicted in a trial in federal court in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, Langford was serving out a 15-year federal felony sentence until he was released resentenced to time served in light of life-threatening health issues.\n\nHe was inmate #27349-001 at , a Federal prison hospital near Lexington, Kentucky. He was released on December 28, 2018, after U.S. District Court Judge Scott Coogler commuted his sentence to time served due to deteriorating health conditions.\n\n\nOn April 27, 2015, Langford was transported from prison to a hospital due to a case of . Langford was first rejected for a compassionate release after describing himself as \"terminally ill\".\nOn December 28, 2018, a federal judge reduced Langford's sentence for corruption to time served. He was granted compassionate release from prison in December 2018 due to his failing health.\n\nLangford died on January 8, 2019. He was 72. His interment was at .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  profile at Bhamwiki.com\n*  Larry Langford: Before Obama, There Was Fairfield's Beloved Black Mayor---TV Crime Sky\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ann-Margaret Ferrante''' (born June 26, 1972) is an American legislator in the , representing the 5th Essex district, which consists of , , and . A member of the , she was first elected in 2008 after defeating incumbent representative  in the Democratic primary. Currently, she is the Vice Chair of the House Committee on Ways and Means and sits on the House Committee on Post Audit and Oversight, House Committee on Operations, Facilities and Building Security, and the House Committee on Steering, Policy and Scheduling. She is also co-chair of the Tech Hub Caucus, which focuses on fostering growth of Massachusetts’ high-tech businesses and startups.\n\nA graduate of  with a major in Economics & International Relations, she furthered her education at . After graduating from law school, she practiced law in Gloucester and Rockport, specializing in fisheries issues. She has served on numerous boards and commissions in the community, including Cape Ann Commercial Fisherman’s Loan Fund, Sawyer Free Library, and as an incorporator with Cape Ann Savings Bank.\n\n\nAnn-Margaret Ferrante was born on June 26, 1972, in Gloucester, Massachusetts. Her mother was a librarian in the local high school, and her father became a fisherman in Gloucester after immigrating from Sicily. She graduated from Gloucester High School and went on to study Economics and International Relations at  in Boston.\n\nAfter receiving her Bachelor of Arts in 1994 from Tufts University, Ferrante went to work as the legislative aide for State Representative . In 1996, she left her position with Tarr in order to pursue a Juris Doctor from . Ferrante was admitted to the  in 1999. Shortly after graduating from Suffolk Law, Ferrante started her own law firm in Gloucester, where she focused on land use and fishing issues. She also served as counsel for the Northeast Seafood Coalition, where she began working to reform the regulatory practices affecting commercial fisherman. Ferrante holds a Master of Public Administration from the  at .\n\n\n\n\n'''2008'''\n\nFerrante first ran for State Representative in 2008, challenging incumbent Democrat  on a platform of promoting Gloucester's port as a state asset, advocating sustainable regulations for the fishing industry, encouraging research and investment in education and workforce training, as well as many other issues affecting residents of the 5th Essex District. She received 46.9% of the vote in the Democratic primary, compared to Verga's 39.8%, with Gloucester attorney Astrid AfKlinteberg taking 13.3% of vote.\n\nIn the general election, Verga mounted a write-in campaign to retain his seat, but was defeated by Ferrante by a large margin.\n\n'''2010'''\n\nIn 2010, Ferrante defeated Gloucester business consultant Janet Holmes, a Republican, to win a second term in the Massachusetts House of Representatives with 7,485 votes to Holmes' 4,078.\n\n'''2012'''\n\nFerrante ran unopposed in 2012 and was re-elected to a third term in the Massachusetts House of Representatives.\n\n'''2014'''\n\nIn 2014, Ferrante defeated former Rockport selectman and financial adviser Michael Boucher, a Republican, to win a fourth term in the Massachusetts House of Representatives with 6,490 votes against Boucher's 4,279.\n\n'''2016'''\n\nFerrante ran unopposed in 2016 and was re-elected to a fifth term in the Massachusetts House of Representatives.\n\n'''2018'''\n\nIn 2018, Ferrante defeated Rockport Department of Public Works Commissioner and retired management consultant James Gardner, an independent, to win a sixth term in the Massachusetts House of Representatives with 13,551 votes against Gardner's 5,422.\n\n'''2020'''\n\nFerrante ran unopposed in 2020 and was re-elected to a seventh term in the Massachusetts House of Representatives.\n\n\n in 2023, after Ferrante received the MassBio \"Legislator of the Year\" award]]\n\nFerrante is currently the Vice Chair of the House Committee on Ways and Means and sits on the House Committee on Post Audit and Oversight, House Committee on Operations, Facilities and Building Security, and the House Committee on Steering, Policy and Scheduling. She is also co-chair of the Tech-Hub Caucus. During her time in the Massachusetts House of Representatives, Ferrante has served as the First Division Chair of the Massachusetts House of Representatives, House Chair of the Joint Committee on Economic Development and Emerging Technologies, House Chair of the Joint Committee on Community Development and Small Businesses, House Vice Chair of the Joint Committee on Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture, House Vice Chair for the Joint Committee on Economic Development and Emerging Technologies, and as a member of several committees.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n| birth_place         =\n| residence           = \n| party               =\n| partner             =\n| website             =\n}}\n'''Rashad Jamal Taylor''' (born March 21, 1981) is a political consultant and former  from . A , he served from 2009 to 2013 in the , representing the City of  from the 55th House District. He was first elected in November 2008, at 27 years old, making him the youngest serving member of the General Assembly. After re-election in 2010, he was elected Vice Chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, the fourth highest ranking leadership position in the House. At 31, Taylor was the youngest member of the General Assembly leadership, House or Senate, Democrat or Republican.\n\n\nTaylor was born and raised in , where he attended , graduating from . Rashad was the first high school student ever selected for an internship via the  College Internship Program; he interned in the office of Rep.  (D–Georgia) before moving to Atlanta where he attended college. He moved to Atlanta to attend , where as a student, he led a  campaign for the school's janitors and helped found Atlanta Jobs with Justice, which ended in a salary increase for janitors. Taylor also worked as a Finance Assistant for US Senator .\n\nHe subsequently worked as a political consultant and campaign manager, managing the campaigns of , elected to the Georgia House in 2002, and Khaatim S. El, elected to the  in 2003. Morgan and El were the youngest members to serve in their respective legislative bodies. From 2003 - 2006, Taylor successfully managed several successful campaigns in metro Atlanta for sheriff, Superior Court, Georgia House, Georgia Senate, city council, and county commission. \n\nIn 2006, Rashad became a  and legislative coordinator for  of Georgia. That year, Taylor helped to protect the rights of same-sex marriages to adoption. In May 2006, Rashad Taylor was named one of ten Democratic \"Rising Stars\" in national politics by . In June 2007, Taylor was appointed political director of the , a position he held until joining the Legislature in January 2009.\n\nIn 2009, Rep. Taylor served as deputy campaign manager for Atlanta Mayor 's mayoral campaign and served on Mayor Reed's transition team. As deputy campaign manager, Taylor oversaw the political, field, and policy/communications operations of the campaign. In 2010, Taylor managed the successful re-election campaign of Fulton County Commission Chairman John Eaves. Rep. Taylor has served on the Board of Directors of NARAL Pro-Choice Georgia, the Youth Task Force, and the Joseph Whitehead YMCA. Taylor currently serves on the Board of Directors of The Kindezi School. Taylor is a 2011 graduate of LEAD Atlanta.\n\n\nIn 2008, state representative  decided against seeking re-election, choosing instead to mount an unsuccessful primary challenge to John Lewis in the . Her decision created an open seat in the Georgia House, which attracted two candidates, both Democrats, one of whom was Taylor. In the primary election held on July 15, 2008, Taylor earned 62.8% of the vote and won the Democratic nomination. He faced no opposition in the general election and took office on January 12, 2009.\n\nHe ran for re-election in 2010, facing a primary challenge from Mable Thomas, his predecessor in office. In the Democratic primary election held on July 20, 2010, Taylor won 56.1%, winning by a margin of 349 votes.  Once again, he won the general election unopposed. His second term expired in January 2013.\n\n\nDuring his first term, Rep. Taylor served on the Education, MARTA Oversight (MARTOC), and Ways and Means Committees. He was appointed Chairman of the MARTOC Subcommittee on Infrastructure and Maintenance. Taylor was also appointed Deputy Minority Whip by the House Democratic Leader and Whip.\n\nAfter re-election in 2010, Taylor was elected Vice Chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, handily defeating three other colleagues without a run-off election. Taylor was also appointed Chairman of the Atlanta-Fulton Legislative Delegation Subcommittee on Housing and Economic Development. Taylor sponsored legislation for the City of Atlanta to extend its hotel/motel tax to help fund the construction of a new .\n\n\nTaylor lives in the Historic West End neighborhood of Atlanta and is a member of Destiny World Church in .\n\nOn May 27, 2011, Taylor  as  following the circulation of an e-mail that accused Taylor of being gay and of using his official position to solicit sexual relationships. Taylor's accuser later admitted he had no proof to his allegations against Taylor. He was one of four openly LGBT members of the , alongside Reps.  (D–),  (D–), and  (D–). Taylor was the first openly gay male to serve in the Georgia General Assembly and the second openly gay African American male state legislator in the United States.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Bob Dixon''' (born May 27, 1969) is an American   currently serving as Presiding Commissioner of Greene County, Missouri. He formerly served in the  and .\n\nA resident of , Dixon was first elected to the House in 2002 and served four terms. Between 2004 and 2008 he served as Majority Caucus Chairman and chaired the House Transportation Committee.\n\n\nDixon has a  degree in Human Services and a  degree in , both from . Dixon graduated high school from the Christian Schools of Springfield. He is a member of the Alpha Xi Chapter of  National Honor Society.\n\n\nDixon lived as a homosexual for five years as a teenager, attributing his sexual orientation to abuse he endured as a child.  In his early 20s, he renounced homosexuality and declared himself heterosexual.  He is currently married and he and his wife, Amanda, have three daughters: Grace, Rose, and Olivia. They live in Springfield, Missouri where they are regular members of a local church.\n\nDixon is a licensed , and he also teaches online classes at Drury University.\n\n\nDixon is member to the , , and  chambers of commerce, as well as the Missouri Farm Bureau, the James River Basin Partnership, the North Springfield Betterment Association, the  of Springfield North, and the  (ALEC).\n\nDixon serves on the board of trustees of the History Museum for Springfield-Greene County, the board of Directors of the Girl Scouts of Dogwood Trails Council, Inc. and the Board of Associates of New Covenant Academy. Dixon and his wife also serve on the Association of  Family and Friends Executive Council. (edited)\n\n\nDixon is a conservative and is part of the Republican Party. He most recently won the election for the Greene County Presiding Commissioner in 2018.\n\n\nDixon is serving or has served on the following House committees:\n\n*National Conference of State Legislatures\n*Standing Committee on Economic Development\n*Trade and Cultural Affairs\n*Criminal Justice Task Force\n*Internet Cyber Crime Task force\n\n\nDixon briefly entered the , announcing his bid in July 2015 and then dropping out of the race four months later.\n\n\n\n\n\n*''Official Manual, State of Missouri''  Jefferson City, MO: Secretary of State.\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carter Barrett''' ('''J. Carter Barrett'''; born June 27) is an   politician from Georgia, currently representing the 24th district in the .\n\n\nBarrett attended high school in , Italy, and he graduated from the  with a  in .\n\n\nOriginally from , Barrett moved to  in 1990 working as a banker for . He co-founded -based Community Business Bank in 2008, before selling it to Community and Southern Bank in 2015. He later worked for Affinity Bank. Barrett is on the board of directors of Forsyth County Chamber.\n\nBarrett is opposed to .\n\nIn 2022, Barrett defeated incumbent  in the primary following a runoff; Gilligan previously opposed aspects of then-Speaker 's mental health bill, and Ralston's campaign committee supported Barrett, helping him to raise over $280,000. He went on to defeat Democratic challenger Sydney Walker in November 2022.\n\nIn an interview in 2022, Barrett said the 24th House district is \"the only political office I ever intend to run for.\" The Coalition of Advocates for Georgia's Elderly honored Barrett as 2023 Outstanding Legislator of the Year.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBarrett lives in Cumming, Georgia with his wife Jamie; they were married in 1995 and have two daughters.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Bud Williams''' is a  who represents the 11th Hampden District in the . He represents the city of . Williams serves as the Vice Chair of the House Committee on Redistricting, and on the House Committee on Ways and Means, the Joint Committee on Economic Development and Emerging Technologies, the Joint Committee on Education, and the Joint Committee on Ways and Means.\n\nHe is a member of the Massachusetts Black and Latino Legislative Caucus.\n\nBefore being elected to the state house, Williams was a member of the  City Council, serving two tenures. He first served on the City Council from 1993 to 2008, and again served from 2011 to 2017. After being elected to the state house, he decided that he would continue to coincidently serve out the remainder of his term on the City Council, but not seek reelection afterwards.\n\nIn 2002 he ran unsuccessfully for State Representative, losing the Democratic primary for the 11th Hampden district seat to . In , he challenged incumbent  , losing the mayoral election by a roughly 2–3 margin. Before being elected to the City Council, he had run unsuccessfully for it in 1989 and 1993.\n\nIn early 2023, Williams cosponsored a bill to allow Massachusetts prisoners to earn time off from their sentences by immediately forfeiting some of their vital organs and/or bone marrow to the state.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Rex Richardson''' (born August 18, 1983) is an American politician who has served as the  of  since 2022. A member of the , Richardson previously served as a member of the , representing the 9th District from 2014 until 2022.\n\n\nRichardson was born on August 18, 1983, at  in Illinois. His father was a member of the  and his mother worked for  as a  on their . His parents divorced when he was three or four years old, and he and his siblings relocated with their mother, living in Michigan, Minnesota, and Missouri before settling in , before moving to California when he was 11 years old. He graduated from  and enrolled at . He served as , but dropped out of college without graduating to take a job as a community organizer for the  Local 721.\n\nIn 2010, Steve Neal, the member of the  for the ninth district, hired Richardson as his  and tasked him with organizing community groups in the district. In 2014, Neal ran for the , and Richardson was elected to the city council to succeed him. In 2015, he rolled out the  to Long Beach. He was elected vice mayor of Long Beach in 2016. Richardson returned to college through remote learning in 2020, and completed his  from Cal State Dominguez Hills.\n\n\n\n\n\nRichardson announced his candidacy for the  in January 2022, upon 's retirement to run for the . He received the endorsements of Senator , Governor , and the outgoing Mayor Garcia.\n\nIn the June 7 primary election, Richardson and fellow councilor Suzie Price received the most votes, but since no candidate received a majority of the votes, the election advanced to a runoff. Richardson would win the runoff election on November 8, 2022, becoming the  of Long Beach.\n\n\nRichardson was sworn in on December 20, 2022.\n\n\nThe city of Long Beach, California uses a  system. This means that policy-making authority lies within an elected governing body: the city council. Mayors can, however, make certain appointments.\n\nIn 2022, Long Beach voters approved the formation of a new Police Oversight Commission. To serve as its first commissioner, Richardson appointed former  Inspector General Francine Kerridge. Her duties include investigating instances of unnecessary force and broader trends within the department.\n\nRichardson cited increasing diversity as a major influencing factor in his appointment decisions. He has appointed 32 commissioners, 53% are women and 59% are members of racial minority groups.\n\n\n\n\nThe Long Beach Housing Promise was proposed by Rex Richardson and approved by City Council members in April 2023. Richardson launched the initiative to create more affordable housing opportunities for students and their families and to identify more opportunities for homeless prevention programs in Long Beach. In creating this program, Richardson worked directly with the president of California State University, Long Beach, the president and superintendent of Long Beach City College, and the superintendent of the Long Beach Unified School District.\n\n\nThe Grow Long Beach Initiative is a long-term plan to expand Long Beach's economy. The purpose of the initiative is to find alternative revenue sources in order to help reduce the city's long standing reliance on fossil fuels and oil. The initiative focuses mainly on two industries: tourism and aerospace and aviation. Even so, the city is exploring other highly profitable industries such as healthcare, the Port of Long Beach and its supply chain, education, hospitality, and the arts. One of the recent developments of this initiative is the construction of a Hard Rock Hotel in downtown Long Beach. On November 13, 2023, Richardson formally announced the Hard Rock Hotel project. Richardson said the project aligns directly with the Grow Long Beach Initiative, because the construction of the hotel will help to increase tourism and transform downtown Long Beach into a thriving entertainment district.\n\n\nOn November 14, 2023, Richardson released a comprehensive three-phase plan to address public safety concerns in downtown Long Beach. The purpose of the initiative is to combat serious public safety issues facing downtown Long Beach, including trespassing, drug dealing and lewd behavior. The initiative places a strong emphasis on mental health issues. More specifically, the initiative includes the creation of the Neighborhood Safety Bike Team, increased patrol officers in downtown Long Beach, specialized drugs officers directed toward areas with high crime rates, and the establishment of enhanced Quality of life officers.\n\n\nThe West Side Promise was introduced by Richardson in his 2024 budget reveal, in which he proposed a 10-year investment plan to identify ways to improve West Long Beach's housing supply and economy, while maintaining climate resiliency. West Long Beach has experienced some significant hardships in recent years, including a lack of basic necessities like banks, full-service grocery stores, and pharmacies. West Long Beach is also very close to Interstate 710 and the Port of Long Beach, which causes its residents to experience many health issues. In order to remedy these issues, Richardson's West Side Promise's plans to drive economic and equitable investments, increase open spaces, and work to decrease pollution in West Long Beach.\n\n\nRichardson has made many efforts to reshape Long Beach, California’s economy through his budget proposals leading up to 2024. To support this approach, Richardson has drafted his proposal for Long Beach revolving around Elevate 28, a billion-dollar plan to improve the Long Beach area. The $3.2 billion proposal focuses on helping the homeless and preparing the community for the 2028 Olympic Games. The final budget for this fiscal year was established and planned to begin on October 1. After many revisions, this budget was focused on allocating funds toward the upcoming Olympics, infrastructure, and more. More key motivations of this program were to upgrade the population’s quality of life - aiming to extend life expectancy and decrease homeless rates around the city by finding safe and supportive residences for the homeless. This budget also incorporates strategies to inject money into smaller locally owned businesses to improve the local community around Long Beach, the hope is to support small businesses and spur more tourism.\n\nDuring the $3.2 billion budget proposal, Rex Richardson has advocated for a plan that is meant to supply more resources to the city. This 10-year plan is called the West Side Promise. This promise is meant to fight against the environmental racism that has plagued the city for years, and Richardson believes this will be a beneficial investment for the city. Some key attributes of this program include developing a new cultural center and new parks in the area. The hope for this program is to improve Long Beach's quality of life by providing them with basic necessities and resources. To make this program successful, the city would need funding from private and public industries to provide these resources for the city.\n\n\nRichardson and his wife, Nina, have two daughters. They live in .\n\n\n}} \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

City of Worcester, MA |url=http://www.worcesterma.gov/city-clerk/ordinances-regulations |website=www.worcesterma.gov |publisher=Worcester |access-date=25 April 2020}}\n\nIn 2007, after Murray stepped-down as mayor, Lukes became mayor due to the city charter stating that the vice chair would become mayor in the instance of a vacancy. I can’t believe they did this. Now, he gets promoted to a job at Georgia public television. It’s amazing.\"\n\nIn his 2018 run for re-election he won his seat.     "pages": }\n'''George Dekle Busbee Sr.''' (August 7, 1927 – July 16, 2004), was an American politician who served as the 77th  from 1975 to 1983.\n\n\nBorn in , Georgia, Busbee attended  and  before joining the . After his discharge, he completed his education at the  and its  in , where he was a member of the   and the , having procured a bachelor's degree in 1949 and a law degree in 1952.\n\n\nEstablishing a law practice in , Busbee served nine terms in the  and was floor leader for Governor . In 1967, Busbee was one of thirty  in the legislature who voted for the   in the disputed , rather than the Democratic nominee , a  from . The legislature, acting under the 1824 Georgia Constitution, upheld by the , chose Maddox 182 to 66.\n\nIn 1974, Busbee won the Democratic  for governor in 's final year in that office. In the party runoff, he defeated, 551,106 (59.9 percent) to 369,608 (40.1 percent), former governor and sitting  Lester Maddox, the man whom Busbee had voted against in the legislative election for governor some seven years earlier. In the fall of 1974, Busbee handily defeated , the first Republican to have served as  of .\n\nTwo years later voters approved a wholesale revision of the Georgia Constitution. As a result of these changes, Busbee became the state's first governor to serve two consecutive four-year terms. Lt. Gov. , who wanted to run for governor in 1978, opposed the constitutional amendment, but it was carried anyway.  Busbee won election to his second term in 1978 with an easy victory over Republican  of Atlanta.\n\n\nAfter his service as governor, Busbee joined the Atlanta law firm  and moved to the Atlanta suburb of .\n\nBusbee was married to the former Mary Elizabeth \"Mary Beth\" Talbot (1927–2012), originally from  in north . The sixth child of a country physician, Dr. and Mrs. B. H. Talbot, she graduated from  with a  degree in biological sciences and also did graduate work in pathology at  in . She moved to Georgia to work as a medical technician at Athens General Hospital in Athens, where she met George Busbee, then a law student. In 1952, they relocated to Albany, where they remained until his inauguration as governor in January 1975. As First Lady of Georgia, Mrs. Busbee was known for her emphasis on volunteerism. In 1985, she co-authored a cookbook, ''Guess Who's Coming to Dinner,'' about favorite recipes and guests served at the governor's mansion during her eight years there. Mrs. Busbee was a 40-year cancer survivor.\n\nThe Busbees had four children, Beth Kindt and husband John, Jan Curtis and husband Carlton, George D. Busbee, Jr., and wife Tammy, and Jeff Busbee and wife Kelly. After the governorship, the Busbees started a church in their Duluth home. That congregation is now the Parkway Baptist Church.\n\n\nBusbee died of a  on July 16, 2004, at the  in . George Busbee Parkway and Busbee Drive in the  of  are named in his honor, as is Busbee Hall at the University of Georgia and the Busbee Center at Gwinnett Technical College.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''James R. Miceli''' (March 25, 1935&nbsp;– April 21, 2018) was an American  politician who represented 's 19th district in the .\n\n\nMicelli was born in , . He served on the board of selectmen from 1966 to 1977 and was chair of the board of selectmen. Miceli was first elected to the state house in 1977 and served until his death. He received his bachelor's degree of science in business administration from .\n\nHe also ran in the  to replace  in the . Miceli was a  Democrat. He supported immigration enforcement, the , opposed  and .\n\n\nMiceli died in his hometown of  after collapsing and going into cardiac arrest at a  ceremony.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

  "query":

    "pages": }\n\n\n  \n| office1             =  District Attorney for the \n| term_start1         = January 3, 1999\n| term_end1           = January 3, 2011\n| predecessor1        = Jeffrey Locke\n| successor1          = \n| office2             = Member of the \n| term_start2         = January 3, 1985\n| term_end2           = January 3, 1999\n| predecessor2        = \n| successor2          = \n| constituency2       =   and   \n| office3             = Member of the\n| term_start3         = January 3, 1977\n| term_end3           = January 3, 1985\n| predecessor3        = Laurence Buxbaum\n| successor3          = \n| constituency3       = 19th Norfolk  \n| birth_name          = William Richard Keating\n| birth_date          = \n| birth_place         = , U.S.\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| spouse              = Tevis Keating\n| children            = 2\n| education           =  (, ) ()\n| website             = \n| module              = \n}}\n'''William Richard Keating''' (born September 6, 1952) is an American lawyer and politician serving as the  for  since 2013. A member of the , he first entered Congress in 2011, representing  until redistricting. Keating's district includes  and most of the . He raised his profile advocating for criminal justice issues in both houses of the  from 1977 to 1999 before becoming  of , where he served three terms before being elected to Congress.\n\nRaised in , Keating \"took a traditional route to politics\", attending  and . He was elected to the  in 1976 at age 24 and went on to serve in the  from 1985 to 1999. He authored numerous bills signed into law concerning taxation, drug crime, and sentencing reform. His attempted overthrow of Senate President  in 1994 was a failure but boosted his local name recognition, which contributed to his success in the 1998 election for DA.\n\nKeating followed the path of former Norfolk County District Attorney  to the U.S. House of Representatives, winning election in  to represent the 10th congressional district. In , after redistricting drew his home in  into the district of fellow incumbent , Keating chose to run in the redrawn 9th district, which combined the eastern portion of his old district with new territory on the  taken from the  long represented by . Keating has been reelected five times from this district. As of the  (2021–23), he sits on the House  and . Much of his work has focused on domestic issues central to his district, such as the fishing industry and nuclear safety.\n\n\n\n\nKeating was born in , in 1952 to Anna (née Welch) of , and William B. Keating of . After graduating from , Keating enrolled at , from which he received his  in 1974, and his  in 1982. In 1985, Keating earned his  from  and passed the . He later became a partner at the law firm of Keating & Fishman.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1977, Keating was elected to the  from the 19th  district, where he served for a year. He was then elected from the , serving from 1979 to 1984. He supported 's successful 1985 effort to overthrow  as Speaker of the House. By the end of his House tenure, Keating became vice chairman of the House Criminal Justice Committee.\n\n\n\nIn 1984, State Senator  resigned his Norfolk and  seat to pursue a career in private law, and Keating became the only major Democratic contender for the office. In the general election he faced  Marion Boch, who promoted a plan for dramatic cuts to legislators' pay and hours, invoking the energy of the  campaign.\n\nKeating focused his campaign on expanding resources for crime prevention and education, tailoring his message to the Boston constituency he would pick up as a senator. He was elected with about 64% of the vote.\n\nIn his first year, Keating was named Senate chairman of the joint Public Safety Committee, where he led the legislative action for a statewide  pushed by Governor . He authored a drug sentencing reform package signed into law in 1988, lowering thresholds for possession charges and establishing new minimum sentences, including a one-year minimum sentence for first-time possession of  or  \"with intent to distribute\". The latter provision was widely derided by criminal justice authorities as excessively strict and vaguely worded.\n\nRedistricting eventually placed Keating in the Norfolk and  seat (1989–1994). As a vice chairman of the joint Criminal Justice Committee, he was a lead author of a 1991 sentencing reform bill, signed into law by Governor , that made it easier to try juveniles as adults and pass harsher sentences in the case of major crimes, especially murder. \"What is occurring is a shift away from the rehabilitative stance to a focus on the seriousness of the crime committed by the juvenile\", Keating said. In 1992, as co-chairman of the Taxation Committee, he successfully pushed a proposal to phase out the Massachusetts .\n\nIn 1994, Keating led a group of politicians in a failed  to remove state Senate President  from his position. Keating sought to reform the Senate rules to greatly reduce the president's power. Bulger, who had held the Senate gavel for 15 years, exerted strict control over the body's operations, but was gradually losing his power base, with crops of Democratic freshmen replacing his longtime allies. Keating's campaign failed, but he said during his 2010 election campaign: \"The thought that I took on the most powerful person in Massachusetts, risking my whole career, a member of my own party, is something that is resonating in this campaign, that helps define me as independent.\"\n\nFurther redistricting landed Keating in the Norfolk, Bristol, and  district from 1995 to 1998. During his Senate tenure, he served as chairman of the Judiciary Committee, chairman of the Committee on Taxation, chairman of the Committee on Public Safety, chairman of the Steering and Policy Committee, and vice chairman of the Committee on Criminal Justice.\n\n\nSpeculation emerged in early 1997 that Keating was planning a run for  (DA) of Norfolk County. He faced two former Norfolk assistant DAs, John J. Corrigan and William P. O'Donnell, in the Democratic primary. Keating, whose name recognition was boosted by the attempted Bulger coup, presented his work on public safety, criminal justice, and judiciary committees as a strength.\n\nAfter winning the Democratic nomination, Keating faced incumbent DA Jeffrey A. Locke in the November 1998 general election. A Republican, Locke had been appointed to the position by Governor Weld the previous year after  resigned. With years of experience as a prosecutor, Locke portrayed Keating as a career politician and echoed his primary opponents' criticism of his experience. Keating highlighted a range of endorsements from police organizations, and from Delahunt, as evidence of his criminal justice qualifications. Aided by a Democratic-leaning electorate, Keating won the election with around 55% of the vote.\n\nIn his first year, Keating founded the Norfolk Anti-Crime Council, a 35-member forum for judicial officers, police, and other local parties to discuss and coordinate anti-crime strategies. He established a pilot program for a  under Quincy District Court, which would provide an alternative sentencing pathway for nonviolent drug offenders, in an effort to reduce court backlogs and lower recidivism rates. He also expanded his office's juvenile crime unit. In 2000, he laid the groundwork for the Norfolk Country Children's Advocacy Center, based on similar programs in  and  counties, and it was fully established the next year. Keating's office also began an anti-bullying program in 2001.\n\nIn 2002, Keating's office was the first in Massachusetts to win a murder conviction in a case that lacked a victim's body.\n\nIn advance of the 2002 elections, he was seen as a likely contender to succeed the deceased  in the , but he opted to run for a second term as DA instead, and was unopposed for reelection. He won a third term, still unopposed, in 2006.\n\n\n, as well as much of the .]]\n\n\nWith incumbent U.S. Representative Bill Delahunt choosing to retire, Keating declared his candidacy in the . In order to run for Delahunt's 10th district seat, Keating moved from his longtime home in Sharon (in the neighboring ) to a rental property in .\n\nOn September 14, Keating won the Democratic primary against State Senator . In the general election, he faced Republican State Representative . In the wake of the  and the election of Republican U.S. Senator , the campaign was unusually close for a modern Massachusetts race, which would normally skew heavily Democratic. Keating's campaign largely focused on a 1991 incident during Perry's tenure as a police sergeant in which a teenage girl had been illegally strip-searched by another officer while Perry was on the scene. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee ran a widely aired advertisement highlighting the incident and challenging Perry's character. Keating won the November 2 election with 47% of the vote to Perry's 42%, with two independents receiving the remainder.\n\nDuring his first term in the House, Keating represented a district that served much of the , part of the South Coast, and all of Cape Cod. With the state poised to lose a congressional seat after the , lawmakers released a redistricting plan in November 2011 in which Keating's home in Quincy was drawn into the neighboring , represented by . Under the plan, nearly all of Keating's base in the South Shore was drawn into Lynch's -based district. Most of the southern portion of Keating's old district, including his summer home in  on , was combined with territory centered on the South Coast cities of  and  to create the new 9th district. Rather than challenge Lynch in the Democratic primary, Keating chose to run in the 9th, claiming his summer home as his residence in the district. Keating defeated Bristol County District Attorney Samuel Sutter in the September 6 Democratic primary, and in November 2012 defeated Republican nominee Christopher Sheldon to win a second term.\n\n\n\nKeating is a member of the , the , the  and the .\n\n\nIssues specific to his South Coast and Cape Cod–based district, such as maritime policy, have been a major focus of Keating's work. In June 2012, he organized the Federal Fishing Advisory Board, a body to research and address  concerns between lawmakers and industry stakeholders. Also in 2012, he and other Massachusetts representatives pushed the  to issue a federal disaster declaration for fisheries in the northeastern U.S., which would open up the opportunity for financial aid. In the wake of , Keating proposed to redirect $111 million of relief funding to fisheries throughout the country, but the House Rules Committee did not adopt the proposal.\n\nWhen the  considered a 20-year contract extension for the  in  in mid-2012, Keating repeatedly took to the press. He at first declined to take a position on the plant's reauthorization, saying, \"I wouldn't be the right person to ask, and that's why we have regulatory authorities and people with expertise to deal with that.\" When the commission voted to renew the license, Keating joined other Massachusetts politicians in deriding the decision as premature.\n\nDuring a labor strike later in the year, Keating joined U.S. Representative  in challenging the qualifications of the plant's replacement workers.\n\nAlong with U.S. Senator , Keating helped to finalize the cleanup and sale of portions of a defunct naval air base in  to private developers. The deal, reached in November 2011, was a linchpin for the SouthField development project.\n\nKeating has stressed his opposition to  reductions such as raising the retirement age or privatizing the program, and supported a  the  announced in 2011.\n\nIn 2011, Keating had a 100% rating from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations (), backing all 29 endorsed bills. In 2012, Keating voted for 10 of 12 AFL-CIO backed bills, with the two opposing votes dealing with small business startups and swap dealer exclusions.\n\nOverall, Keating has supported 95% of AFL-CIO-endorsed legislation. He has received an 0% rating from the anti-union WorkPlaceChoice.org. He voted against the NLRB Prohibitions Bill in November 2011.\n\n\nKeating sits on the , where he is the ranking member of the , and formerly served on the . He joined a Congressional delegation to Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Iraq, shortly after the 2011 execution of .\n\nAfter  officers in Boston were accused of  in 2012, Keating requested a Homeland Security Committee hearing into the accusations.\n\n\nIn 2011, Keating founded a Women's Advisory Board for the 10th congressional district, in hopes of gaining insight into how best to serve the women in the 10th district. From October 18 to 21, 2011, he hosted \"Women's Week\" in the district, with events focusing on topics such as breast cancer awareness, domestic violence, and female entrepreneurship.\n\nKeating is , and during his tenure in the House has voted against the Protect Life Act and the .\n\nIn 2010, Keating received a rating of 0% from . In 1997, he was rated 100% by . The same year, he received a 100% rating from the Massachusetts .\n\nKeating is a supporter of . He supported ending the  policy and has promised to push nationwide anti-discrimination laws and marriage rights for gays and lesbians. In July 2011, he recorded a video supporting LGBT youth in Massachusetts in conjunction with other members of Massachusetts's congressional delegation and the .\n\nDuring his 2010 House campaign, Keating promised to increase federal firearm regulations. His proposed changes included closing a loophole that allows people on the FBI Terrorist Watch List to buy guns and requiring child safety trigger locks on all guns. He voted against a bill to require any state offering  permits to recognize such permits issued in other states.\n\n\nKeating and Representative  jointly introduced the  on April 29, 2013. The bill would amend the  with respect to minimum essential health care coverage requirements added by the , to allow an additional religious exemption from such requirements for people whose sincerely held religious beliefs would cause them to object to medical health care provided under such coverage. Individuals could file an affidavit to get this exemption, but would lose the exemption if they went on to later use healthcare. Schock and Keating wrote a letter in support of their bill, saying, \"we believe the EACH Act balances a respect for religious diversity against the need to prevent fraud and abuse.\"\n\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n*  \n**  (Ranking Member)\n** \n\n\n*\n\n\nKeating and his wife, Tevis, live in . They have two adult children.
